column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/103522,2021,"Ethiek, Rationaliteit en Emotie",Nederlands,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. JP Kloeg'],,"Inhoud

Welke rol spelen emoties in de morele oordeelsvorming van mensen? Zijn emoties constitutief voor de morele positie die mensen innemen of zijn het stoorzenders die een redelijke oordeelsvorming in de weg staan? En: wat zijn emoties? Zijn emoties louter gevoelens en is een moreel oordeel daarom altijd de expressie van een bepaald gevoel? Of zijn emoties ook te beschouwen als cognitieve mentale toestanden die ons informatie verschaffen over onszelf en over de wereld om ons heen? Ter beantwoording van deze vragen zullen we in deze cursus niet alleen de meest actuele moraalfilosofische debatten over ethiek, rationaliteit en emoties bespreken, maar ook te rade gaan bij het hedendaagse moraalwetenschappelijke onderzoek naar de oorsprong en aard van emoties en naar de invloed van emoties bij oordeelsvorming (o.m. werk van Frans de Waal, Jonathan Haidt en Antonio Damasio). We zullen nadenken over de lichamelijke basis van gevoelens en emoties en dit verbinden met cognitief psychologisch onderzoek naar de onmisbare (en soms misleidende) rol van emoties in het redeneren en het vormen van een standpunt. Vervolgens zullen we discussiëren over wat dit betekent voor de aard en de betrouwbaarheid van evaluatieve oordelen. Een morele stellingname is meer dan de expressie van een gevoel. Maar in welke zin is het meer en anders?

column5: vinden emoties hun oorsprong in fysieke mechanismen die evolutionair verankerd zijn in het brein, of in culturele cognitieve oordelen? Empirisch en filosofisch emotieonderzoek verslikt zich al honderd jaar&nbsp
column8: en is daardoor niet in staat de existentiële,&nbsp
column9: praktische en morele dimensie van emoties scherp te krijgen.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100958,2021,Ethiek, duurzaamheid en compliance",Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,"['MCP de haan', 'mr. HY Wu', 'mr. I van der Klooster', 'mr. SRMC Vogelsang', 'mr.drs. DE Bos', 'mr.drs. R Bierenbroodspot', 'O el Manouzi, LLM', 'prof.mr. HM Vletter - van Dort']",,"Inhoud

Ethische dilemma’s doen zich regelmatig voor in de financiële sector. Vooral na de financiële crisis van 2007/08 heeft ethiek in de financiële sector meer aandacht gekregen van wetgevers, toezichthouders en de media. Schandalen zoals Enron, Panama Papers en ING worden vaak besproken in ethische discussies en leiden tot bewustwording in de financiële sector. Toch blijven dergelijke schandalen zich voordoen, wat bijvoorbeeld blijkt uit het recente schandaal rondom betaaldienstverlener Wirecard. Hoe dienen wij deze problematiek te benaderen? Hoe kunnen klassieke ethische theorieën ons hierbij helpen? Op welke wijze geven ontwikkelingen in de financiële sector invulling aan ethische kaders? Hoe verhoudt ethiek zich tot het voldoen aan wettelijke verplichtingen en het handelen naar waarden en normen?

Het vak Ethiek, duurzaamheid en compliance is voornamelijk gericht op vaardighedenonderwijs. U wordt – al dan niet in groepsverband – de vaardigheden bijgebracht om een wetenschappelijke bijdrage te leveren aan ethische discussies die betrekking hebben op de financiële sector. Daarnaast worden enkele hoorcolleges verzorgd waarin diverse actuele onderwerpen worden aangesneden die in ethische perspectief worden geplaatst. Hierbij kan worden gedacht aan de ethische overweging bij corporate governance, waarbij gedrag en cultuur een aanzienlijke rol speelt. Daarnaast wordt aandacht besteed aan de ethische implicaties van technologische ontwikkelingen in de financiële sector. Het onderwerp duurzaamheid wordt ook uitvoerig onder de aandacht gebracht met bijzondere aandacht voor de Sustainable Development Goals (SDG’s) van de Verenigde Naties. Voorts wordt stilgestaan bij de wisselwerking tussen compliance en ethiek.

Tijdens het vak wordt getoetst aan de hand van (tussentijdse) vaardighedenopdrachten. Deze opdrachten betreffen achtereenvolgens een debat, een vlog en een schriftelijke groepsopdracht. Het vak heeft geen regulier afsluitend schriftelijk tentamen.
• De student herkent een moreel dilemma en kan hierover een oordeel vormen op basis van de ethische theorieën en presenteert dit in groepsverband.
• De student kan vanuit het theoretische kader argumenteren en debatteren rondom duurzaamheid en ethiek.
• De student kan de samenhang tussen ethiek enerzijds en corporate governance, financieel recht en economie anderzijds beoordelen.

• De student kan zelfstandig een kritische visie geven vanuit een ethisch perspectief over de positie van actoren op de financiële markten in relatie tot maatschappelijke opvattingen en de economie aan de hand van internationale kaders.
• De student kan de financiële en ethische verantwoording van een financiële onderneming toetsen en daarover adviseren.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/99987,2021,Ethnographic Research into Culture Participation,Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['prof.dr. EH Bisschop Boele'],,"Inhoud

Central in the course is the discussion of two strands of literature. The first strand will focus on the elements of ethnographic research. We will read and discuss literature on data collection, data analysis, theoretical backgrounds (the interpretive research traditions, practice theory), and specific ethnographic/ethnography-related traditions such as auto-ethnography or grounded theory. This will be combined with the reading of examples of ethnographic research into culture participation. During the course, specific assignments will be given to practice the various elements of ethnographic research. In the meetings, students will be involved in active discussion as well as practical exercises in, e.g., interviewing and the open coding of ethnographic data. Students carry out a small ethnographic research project of their own choice, which is prepared through various assignments and which will be reported upon in the final essay. The course will provide a firm introduction into the topic and a sound basis for those who wish to carry out ethnographic or ethnograpically inspired research in the future.

<body>This course will provide students with an introductory but thorough understanding of ethnographic research into culture participation. Students will read and discuss key literature on the theoretical backgrounds and methodological issues of ethnographic research. This will be combined with a discussion of examples of ethnographic research into cultural participation. Students will be asked to carry out and report on individual research activities connected to the three main data sources in ethnography (observation, interview, study of documents/artefacts)
column2: this will feed into their final assignment, which will be the production of an essay based on the analysis of own empirical data.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/98495,2021,Etiology of Offender Types and Forensic Neuroscience,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. JDM van Dongen', 'R Marhe']",,"Inhoud

This course has the aim for students to become familiar with different offender types and differentiating these offender types based on their etiology and risk factors. Questions that will be addressed are: ""What risk factors for violence does an offender with a psychopathic personality have?"" and ""which subtypes of offenders with a psychotic disorder can we distinguish on the basis of their background?"" In addition, this course involves using fundamental insights from neuroscience. These insights relate to forensic topics such as the emergence of aggression and antisocial behavior and how different brain networks are associated with psychopathic personality. Questions that will be addressed are: ""How do different processes in the brain contribute to the development of aggression?"" and ""how come that a psychopath feels ‘nothing’?"" But also: ""How can activity in the brain be measured and used in violence risk assessment and management?""

Attention is also paid to the emerging field of science named 'neurolaw'. In court, there is an increase in the use of neuroscientific evidence, for example by giving a court ordered forensic neuropsychological examination of the suspect of a crime. This is also increasingly being used by the defense to reduce the sentence, or even to plea for insanity.</body>
During this course, the student learns to:
• Distinguish different types of offenders on the basis of etiology and risk factors
• Describe functions of different brain structures that play a role in aggressive behavior
• Explain which neurobiological factors are related to the delinquent behavior of different types of offenders.
• Explain how different neuropsychological conditions play a role in forensic practice.
• Distinguish between forensic neuropsychology and forensic neuroscience.

• Assess the added value of neuroscientific information in assessing the risk of violence (compared to the common risk factors used in the risk assessment of violence) and the subsequent risk management.
• To substantiate the advantages and disadvantages of the use of neuropsychological and neuroscientific information within the legal system (""Neurolaw"").

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100043,2021,Europe in a Globalizing World: Migration, Citizenship and Identity","Engels, Nederlands","Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. I Gusc', 'dr. L Green', 'prof.dr. G Oonk']",,"Inhoud
<div>Which passport is the most accepted passport around the world and why is this (un)fair? How many generations does it take for a settler and his family&nbsp
column3: 'native'? What is the potential of global citizenship in relation to patriotic realities? These are just some of the pressing questions which are fully explored in this course on Global Migration, Citizenship and Identity. Migration and ethnic minorities have always challenged the ‘nation’ in the Nation State. In this series of lectures we will discuss the development of cosmopolitan citizenship and its discontents. We will take examples from Europe, the US as well South Africa, Japan, Brazil and India. We discuss issues as slavery and citizenship, birth right lottery, paper citizens, multiple passports and loyalties. Global migration has forced us to re-think the construction of the nation state. States increasingly compete with each other for international prestige and economic development. They wish to attract skilled laborers (including sportsmen and women and scientist) and investors or rich consumers. In addition, however, especially western welfare states wish to restrict migration from poor countries to protect the welfare levels of its citizens. Cosmopolitism may be seen as an asset, a challenge and a burden.

column1: Students study three different perspectives on migration and citizenship
column2: (1) Egalitarian liberalism, (2) Communitarian and (3) libertarian perspectives. With these three perspectives in mind they learn how to debate national self-determination, migration and multiculturalism and global distributive justice and migration. By the end of the course they are able to write a critical review of an academic monograph on migration, citizenship and identity.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/98548,2021,Europe in the World,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['prof.dr. M Onderco'],,Inhoud

Europe in the World is a Master course for students in the International Public Management and Policy program. This course aims at developing students’ understanding of the activities of the European Union in the world. By the end of the course, the students will be able to understand and theoretically explain the EU’s external action. They will appreciate the difficulties of EU’s foreign action, and will be able to critically appraise the EU’s foreign policy. Students will have improved soft and transferrable skills.

Students in this course will be expected to have covered the basics of international relations theory. This can be done by having passed the course Global Governance in the IMP program, or an alternative program elsewhere (recognized at the discretion of the instructor).
<body>By the end of the class, the students will be able to
• Illustrate and explain areas of EU’s activity in the world
• Compare different means of EU’s foreign affairs activity
• Contrast EU’s approaches in different areas of foreign policy
• Critically evaluate EU’s efficiency in global governance and foreign affairs

Please note that this course a part of Master International Public Management and Public Policy. Elective students from Master Public Administration tend to experience it as challenging. Furthermore, papers can be submitted only in English in all courses of this Master.

<body><span style=""color:black"">The end of WWII engendered the world’s most far-reaching experiment in international cooperation between sovereign nation states.&nbsp
column2: European countries embarked on a process of integration which has brought them peace, stability and prosperity. Yet, on the European Union’s 60th anniversary, celebrations were noticeably muted with citizens’ support for European integration flagging. How come?

column1: <span style=""color:black"">This course explores the historical, legal, political, and economic background to European integration.&nbsp
column2: It will elucidate the EU’s unique origins, institutions and competences, and debate its place in the world and its relationship to member states. The course sets out to provide the theoretical foundations to critically discuss questions on EU governance, key policy areas, crises and reforms, and to contemplate the EU’s future.

column1: <body>After completing the course, you should be able to:
<li>Understand the origins and evolution of European integration
<li>Assess the political and economic motives of member states to join the European Union

• Explain the necessary conditions for the transition from constitutional right to international right, as stated by Immanuel Kant in Toward Perpetual Peace (1795), and use this to evaluate the feasibility of the idea of a politically integrated Europe
<li>Analyze and reproduce the arguments of Hegel against Kant's idea of global/European perpetual peace
<li>Understand the institutional structure and the legal system of the EU, as well as its competences and the limitations thereof
<li>Understand the economics behind monetary integration and assess the recent crisis in the Eurozone and potential solutions
<li>Apply concepts of sovereignty to the EU in keeping with the latter's political form
<li>Examine the European Union’s relations with the outside world
• Articulate an informed view about current debates on the EU.

<div>The course offers and introduction to the European Union Law. It provides insights into: a) the evolution of the European Union and the sources of EU law
column3: c) the decision making process of the EU
column4: d) the relationship between EU law and the legal systems of the EU Member States
column5: e) the internal market All subjects within the course are approached from a point of view which enables the students to grasp the evolution of European integration. The course intends to embed law related questions into the wider political, social and economic EU-context, without leaving out the developments and discussions as to the future of the European Union.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/101053,2021,European Union Law,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. M Glavina', 'I Dervic, LLM', 'mr. MK Shahid', 'mr. R Notenboom', 'prof.dr. R Repasi', 'R de Geus, LL.M']",,"Inhoud

In recent decades, there has been a rapidly increasing influence of European Union law on more and more areas of national law. Because of this development, people often speak of the progressive 'Europeanization' of different parts of the national legal systems of the Member States of the EU. Virtually all jurisdictions are affected by EU law, which means that the developments in EU law have a major impact not only on the functioning of the national legal jurisdiction and judicial organization, but also on the daily lives of ordinary citizens.

Building on the students’ existing knowledge about the basic principles of EU law and the institutional framework of the EU, the second-year course ‘European Union Law’ goes beyond the basics of the EU’s construct. In particular, the course focuses on the substantive law of the EU. Students will gain an understanding of the internal market and the four fundamental freedoms, the system of legal protection in the EU, EU competition law, as well as Brexit.

Upon completion of this course, students will not only be able to understand the foundations and background of EU law, but will also be able to find, understand, analyze, interpret, critique, and apply the (primary and secondary) rules on legal protection, the four freedoms of the internal market, and EU competition law in the EU to case studies. In addition, student will also be able to find, analyze and apply the relevant case law of the ECJ to a case study.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/98550,2021,European Union Policy-Making,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['prof.dr. M Haverland'],,"Inhoud

<body>This course analyses the European Union as a political system. Rather than just describing the various political actors and formal and informal decision-making procedures, the course aims at a higher level of understanding by applying theories based on institutional rational choice to the various facets of the EU. The basic idea is that political outcomes are the result of actor preferences and institutions (as rules of the game). Equipped with this approach we will analyse among other things, executive politics, legislative politics, judicial politics, interest group politics, and policy making in a variety of areas.</body>
<body>After completion of this course, students are able to:
<li>describe the composition, internal structure and formal decision-making role of EU actors such as the European Commission and the European Parliament
<li>describe the main problems and dynamics of EU policy-making concerning regulatory policies, expenditure policies, and interior policies

<li>define central concepts of rational choice-informed political science theories, such as principal agent theories and coalition-formation theory and to describe the assumptions and hypotheses of these theories

<li>apply rational-choice informed political science theories to executive politics, legislative politics, judicial politics, interest groups politics, regulatory policies, expenditure policies and interior policies
<li>synthesize information about changes in the actor's environment, its effects of actor preferences and changing institutions to predict policy change
• effectively communicate orally about case study findings.

<body>Please note that this course a part of Master International Public Management and Public Policy. Elective students from Master Public Administration tend to experience it as challenging. Furthermore, papers can be submitted only in English in all courses of this Master.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/99098,2021,Europees belastingrecht,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. RP van den Dool', 'prof.dr. P Kavelaars']",,"Inhoud

Een van de redenen voor de Europese toenadering en de totstandkoming van het Verdrag betreffende (de werking van) de Europese Unie is het streven van de lidstaten om te komen tot een interne, markt zonder fiscale belemmeringen, beperkingen of distorsies. Hierdoor moeten onder andere ondernemingen in staat worden gesteld om zich beter aan te passen aan de interne markt, hun productiviteit te vergroten en hun concurrentiepositie op de internationale markt te versterken. Tijdens dit vak wordt geanalyseerd hoe lidstaten deze economische voorspoed kunnen bereiken zonder oneerlijke fiscale concurrentie. Naast de positieve Europese integratie - de regelgeving - wordt ruimschoots aandacht besteed aan de negatieve integratie, de arresten die door het Hof van Justitie worden gewezen.
Het vak bevat o.a. de volgende onderwerpen:
• Bespreking van de verkeersvrijheden in het VwEU
• Wisselwerking tussen EU-recht en nationaal fiscaal recht
• Inzicht verwerven in de algemene beginselen van het EU belastingrecht en in het bijzonder de jurisprudentie van het Hof van Justitie en de regelgeving van de EU.
• De vaardigheid ontwikkelen om aan de hand van het EU belastingrecht nationaalrechtelijke belastingregels te toetsen op hun aanvaardbaarheid.
• Het kritische vermogen ontwikkelen om op zelfstandige wijze naar nationaalrechtelijke belastingregels te kijken.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/101215,2021,Europees en internationaal arbeidsrecht,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['EJA Franssen', 'mr. A Zwanenburg', 'mr.drs. JR Vos', 'N van Toor, LLM', 'prof.mr.dr. JH Even']",,"Inhoud

<body>De doorwerking van het internationale recht op het Nederlandse arbeidsrechtelijke rechtssysteem zal worden besproken. Daarnaast maakt met name het Europees recht het relatief eenvoudig dat een werknemer vanuit Nederland elders in de EU te werk wordt gesteld en vice versa. De regels die hierbij gelden en de problemen die hierdoor kunnen ontstaan worden besproken. Vraagstukken die worden behandeld zijn onder meer: welke fundamentele vrijheden staan de werkgever en de werknemer ter beschikking, hoe verhouden deze vrijheden zich met arbeidsrechtelijke beginselen en rechten, welk recht is van toepassing op de internationale arbeidsovereenkomst en welke rechter is bevoegd bij een geschil. Daarnaast zullen enkele aanpalende actuele onderwerpen worden besproken.</body>
• De student kan de invloed en doorwerking van Europees en internationaal (sociaal verzekerings)recht in het Nederlandse arbeidsrecht toepassen op een concrete casus.
• De student kan beoordelen welke rechter in een internationaal arbeidsgeschil bevoegd is en welk recht van toepassing is.
• De student kan beoordelen wanneer sprake is van internationale detachering, wat de gevolgen daarvan zijn en welke beperkingen wel en niet kunnen worden opgelegd aan internationale dienstverleners.

• De student kan de wijze waarop Europese vrijheden doorwerken in een concrete casus beoordelen en identificeren hoe en waar zich spanningen voordoen tussen deze vrijheden en het (nationale) arbeidsrecht.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/101474,2021,Evaluation of Development Policy, Programmes and Projects",Engels,International Institute of Social Studies (ISS),,"['dr. BA Demena', 'dr. GM Gomez', 'dr. M Faling', 'dr. S Gyamfi Afrifa']",,

Evolution is such a crucial discipline of modern biology that, in 1973, evolutionary biologist Theodosius Dobzhansky wrote: ""nothing in biology makes sense except in the light of evolution"". In this course, a comprehensive introduction to the fascination field of evolutionary biology will be presented. Topics that will be covered include: the origin of abiotic and cellular life, the theory of evolution by natural selection (descent with modification), concepts of fitness and adaptation, the genetic and developmental basis of evolutionary change, micro- and macroevolution, speciation and extinction, elementary population genetics, palaeontology, and human evolution.
After completing this course, you will have a basic knowledge of:
the theory of evolution by natural selection (descent with modification)
the concepts of fitness and adaptation
the genetic and developmental basis of evolutionary change
the origin of abiotic and cellular life

In an infinite population setting, we will learn to use static equilibrium concepts (such as the evolutionary stable strategy), dynamic concepts (such as the replicator dynamics), and we will learn what the relation is between these. In a finite population setting, we will learn what the Moran process is, and get accustomed to evolutionary graph theory.

In order to explain the evolution of prosocial behaviour, we will then apply these evolutionary dynamics and stability concepts to settings with population structure (which then leads to kin selection and/or group selection), repetition (which can lead to the evolution of reciprocity), and partner choice/sexual selection (and its relation to signaling in economic theory). We will also look at subgame perfect equilibria in games where commitment to ""rationally irrational"" behaviour (such as altruism or vengefulness) can have an evolutionary advantage.
We will consider how these predictions can be tested, in and outside the lab, and discuss parts of the empirical literature with each other.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/99446,2021,Experimental Economics,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,"['dr. JTR Stoop', 'F Capozza']",,"Inhoud

Experiments are an increasingly important tool in economics. They are, for instance, used to understand why financial investors spend too little on stocks, why consumers are reluctant to change brands, and in the analysis of labor market decisions. This course deals with the following questions:
• Why are experiments such a powerful tool to discover the causal effect of a treatment?
• Why should incentives be given in economic experiments work? Do they always work?
• How can utility be measured with experiments?
• What kind of statistical analyses are needed for experimental data?
• What is the optimal sample size to discover the causal effect of interest?
• Are results found in the laboratory predictive of behavior in the real world?
• How can we test lab-field generalizability by means of field experiments?
• Understand why randomization is crucial to gather causal inferences of behaviour.
• Understand why economists use incentives in experiments.
• Understand why non-parametric tests are needed to analyze data gathered in experiments.
• Understand why it is sometimes important, and sometimes not important that results from laboratory experiments generalize to other 'real world' settings.
• Know how many indepedent observations one can get out of an experiment.
• Be able to apply some power calculations.
• Be able to come up with an experimental design and derive hypotheses.

The difference with last year, is that this year the classes will be offered on campus. Students should prepare by watching the course lecture video. Then, in class we will go over the material by using case studies.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100735,2021,Experimental Methods in Business Research,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. DR Schley'],,"Inhoud

<body>The course is built on three pillars: Testing research ideas with clean and rigorous experimental designs, applying the appropriate statistical techniques necessary to analyse these designs, and properly interpreting the implications of the observed results in light of the study design and research question. Topics include: causal inference, experimental designs (factorial designs, within- vs. between-subject designs, mixed designs), validity of designs (internal, external, criterion-related, and construct validities), experimental caveats (demand characteristics, confounds, experimenter expectancy, checks, measurement order, control variables), applying statistics to experimental designs (e.g., simple effects, simple slopes, contrasts, outliers, statistical power, simple mediation, moderated mediation, mediated moderation), data visualization, and scientific integrity (researcher degrees of freedom, questionable research practices, transparency, p-hacking)&nbsp

We will examine these topics from the perspective of an applied behavioural researcher (with examples from fields such as marketing, organizational behaviour, economics, and psychology). Our focus is thus very practical—to help you overcome any issues that might arise in designing and conducting your experiment, analysing your data, writing up your results, and getting your paper published. An intermediate proficiency in a programming language (preferably R) is strongly encouraged for this class.
As in previous years, we may be able to collect data in the Erasmus Behavioural Lab.
<body>The goal of this course is to learn how to design, analyse, and interpret field and laboratory experiments.</body>

<li>Introduction to Causal Inference—Overview of the course, motivating questions about causes and effects, and the challenges of measuring effects from data&nbsp
<li>Potential Outcomes Model—A framework for measuring causal effects from observational data or experiments that begins with what you want to measure and works backward from that&nbsp

<li>Graphical Models—Another framework for measuring causal effects from observational data or experiments that begins with what you are willing to assume about the world (and what you can measure) and works forward from that&nbsp

<li>Randomized Experiments and Hypothesis Tests—Sampling from a population and random assignment to different treatments are powerful tools for measuring causal effects. Hypothesis tests provide a way to quantify how likely our results are due to these sources of randomness.&nbsp

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/98940,2021,Exploring Africa,Engels, Nederlands","Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. TA Alade', 'prof.dr. RJM van Tulder', 'R Reshef, MA']",,"Inhoud
This course takes an in-depth look at the African continent from Agenda 2063 and SDG-related perspectives and interweaves sustainable approaches from multiple disciplines.

A flipped classroom guided self study (1 ECs) in the first week introduces and increases an understanding of Agenda 2063 and the SDGs. In the following six weeks, three modules will be presented by the participating faculties and institutions through interactive seminars and presentations that stimulate collaboration and knowledge sharing.
Module I: Economies - EUR (3 ECs) explores African socio-economic realities and partnering opportunities in context of SDGs 8 – 10, 12 &

column2: Infrastructure - TUD (3 ECs) explores available resources and infrastructure in Africa in context of SDGs 6-7, 11, &amp

column1: Module III: Social Dynamics - LU (3 ECs) explores African socio-developmental realities in context of SDGs 1 -5 &
The course concludes with an integration discussion and a one-day conference during which students present their group reports on regional challenges &
Upon successful completion of Exploring Africa, students will have:
The relevance of Agenda 2063 and the SDGs
Socio-economic state of affairs and novel paradigms in African context
The engagements between human and material agents in African settings
Current socio-developmental challenges and opportunities in Africa
Shared responsibility and the interlinkages between disciplines.
Integrate approaches that address the SDGs in a multidisciplinary way
Distinguish innovative business approaches to address ‘wicked’ challenges
Consider the role artefacts play in the relationship between humans and their world
Identify social dynamics that promote and complexities that hamper sustainable development
Academically discuss cross-cutting issues that impact African realities.

The FAECTOR Consultancy Project is a 10-week project organised by FAECTOR for econometrics and BSc2 students. The purpose of this project is to give students practical experience and challenge their knowledge and skills. It does so by offering a practical application of their econometric knowledge in the consultancy field. An additional aim of the project is to offer affordable data consultancy to non-profits and (semi-)governmental institutions, who normally cannot afford professional consultancy. This way, the project has an impact on the
real world while still providing valuable education to students.</body>
In this course you gain experience in applying techniques from Econometrics and Operations Research in a consultancy environment.
<body>The program is extra-curriculair and the students will receive a notification on their diploma and a separate certificate.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/99245,2021,FAECTOR's Excellence Programme,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['JDW Schurink', 'LJ Kragtwijk', 'prof.dr. C Zhou', 'RD van Regteren', 'V Soloveva']",,"Inhoud

The Excellence Programme is a programme designed for the highly motivated Econometrie/Econometrics/BSc2 students. The goal of the programme is to give Bachelor (second year or higher) and Pre-Master students the opportunity to see different sides of an econometric theme. This programme is organised by FAECTOR in cooperation with the Erasmus School of Economics and upon successful completion participants receive 4 Extracurricular ECTS and a certificate signed by the Dean of ESE. Last year's theme was Cyber Security. This year's theme will be announced in November/December. During this programme students attend weekly lectures and practical workshops given by field experts and companies. Moreover, the programme includes several company visits. Programme lasts from January until June.
Participants obtain insight in the role that econometrics plays in a topical issue from different perspectives.
<body>The program is extra-curriculair and the students will receive a notification on their diploma and a separate certificate.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100678,2021,Facility Logistics Management,Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof.dr.ir. MBM de Koster'],,"Inhoud

The Netherlands is well known for its expertise in distribution operations. Many American and Asian multinational companies have established their European logistics centre in the Netherlands, and it is the home base of many logistics service providers and operations. The logistics sector has a big impact on the Dutch economy. Warehousing and distribution are core businesses for many large and smaller firms. While most other courses in the SCM master focus primarily on external logistics and strategic issues, this course focuses on intra logistics (or facility logistics): process design and execution
column2: operations, particularly those within facilities. External and intralogistics are strongly related and interdependent. We will address such questions as: what is the impact of a company’s physical distribution structure on the intra logistics system, and vice versa? What storage systems should be used under which circumstances, what handling systems, what is the best layout, which information systems are appropriate, and what is the resulting performance? Besides matters of system choice, operational storage and order picking strategies are also discussed.

column1: During the course, a number of case-based assignments will be carried out. You may have to present your solutions in class.

The course addresses several skills. These include presentations, consultancy (you have to defend solutions to your peers), data-mining with a database tool, design, and analysis of company-internal operations.
The aim of the course is to:
Develop insight and elementary design skills in material handling and facility (particularly warehouse and transhipment) operations management.
Develop analytical skills in regards to logistics operations. Tools will be provided to enable you to structure, analyse and master the issues at hand.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/101254,2021,Familie(vermogens)recht,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['mr. JJM Grapperhaus', 'prof.mr. AJM Nuytinck']",,"Inhoud

Het familie(vermogens)recht begeleidt de mens als het ware in juridisch opzicht van de wieg tot het graf (en eigenlijk ook, gelet op art. 1:2 BW, in de periode vóór de geboorte en, gelet op de betekenis van het erfrecht, over het graf heen, dus in de periode na het overlijden). Werkelijk iedereen krijgt gedurende zijn leven met dit zo belangrijke rechtsgebied te maken. Het spreekt iedereen aan. Tot het vakgebied behoren het familierecht in enge zin (personen- en familierecht) en het familievermogensrecht (relatievermogensrecht en erfrecht). Vandaar de overkoepelende naam voor dit vak, waarin de drie deelgebieden tot uitdrukking komen: familie(vermogens)recht.

column2: Het eerste deel van het vak, het familierecht in enge zin of personen- en familierecht, vindt men in Boek 1 van het Burgerlijk Wetboek en in belangrijke verdragen, zoals het EVRM en de daarbij behorende Protocollen (‘family life’/‘vie familiale’), het IVBPR en het IVRK. Het rechtsgebied omvat regelingen met betrekking tot de juridische aspecten van het persoonlijk leven, zoals bloed- en aanverwantschap, naam, woonplaats, burgerlijke stand, huwelijk, geregistreerd partnerschap, (echt)scheiding, afstamming (familierechtelijke betrekking), adoptie, gezag over en omgang met minderjarigen, curatele, meerderjarigenbewind, mentorschap, afwezigheid en vermissing.

Het tweede deel van het vak, het relatievermogensrecht als onderdeel van het familievermogensrecht, is in Boek 1 van het Burgerlijk Wetboek opgenomen. Het huwelijksvermogensrecht regelt de vermogensrechtelijke gevolgen van het huwelijk, waaronder begrepen rechten en verplichtingen van echtgenoten, de wettelijke gemeenschap van goederen en huwelijkse voorwaarden. Ook wordt aandacht besteed aan de vermogensrechtelijke gevolgen van de echtscheiding, waaronder begrepen pensioenverevening, alimentatie en de verdeling van de ontbonden huwelijksgemeenschap of de afwikkeling van verrekenbedingen in huwelijkse voorwaarden. In dit verband moet onder ‘huwelijk’ tevens ‘geregistreerd partnerschap’ worden begrepen en onder ‘echtscheiding’ tevens ‘beëindiging van het geregistreerd partnerschap met wederzijds goedvinden of door middel van gerechtelijke ontbinding’. Bovendien komt de rechtspositie van samenwoners zonder huwelijk of geregistreerd partnerschap (informele relatie) aan de orde, zowel tijdens de periode van samenwoning als na verbreking van de samenleving (feitelijke scheiding). Daarom spreekt men ook over ‘relatievermogensrecht’ als overkoepelende term voor huwelijksvermogensrecht, partnerschapsvermogensrecht en samenlevingsvermogensrecht.

Het derde deel van het vak ten slotte, het erfrecht als onderdeel van het familievermogensrecht, vindt men in Boek 4 van het Burgerlijk Wetboek. Het erfrecht regelt de vermogensrechtelijke gevolgen van de overgang van het vermogen van de erflater op diens erfgenamen. Centraal staan het versterferfrecht of ab intestaat erfrecht, d.w.z. het erfrecht dat geldt als er geen uiterste wilsbeschikkingen zijn gemaakt, het testamentair erfrecht, in het bijzonder de legitieme portie, de zogenaamde andere wettelijke rechten en de verdeling van de nalatenschap.

Uitgangspunt bij de behandeling van de stof tijdens de hoorcolleges zal zijn dat de kennis, opgedaan in het eerste studiejaar (inleiding privaatrecht) en in het tweede studiejaar (verbintenissenrecht, alsmede goederen- en insolventierecht), dus globaal gezegd: de kennis van het algemene vermogensrecht, nog paraat aanwezig is. Is uw kennis wat weggezakt, fris een en ander dan vóór de aanvang van de hoorcolleges weer even op. Zie ook de hierboven vermelde toelatingseisen.</body>

column1: <body>Met dit vak wordt beoogd de student vertrouwd te maken met het huidige positieve familie(vermogens)recht en de rechtspraktijk in familie(vermogens)rechtelijke zaken, alsmede met de actuele ontwikkelingen op het gebied van wetgeving en rechtspraak. De bedoeling van dit vak is het verschaffen van kennis van en inzicht in het recht met betrekking tot de hieronder onder ‘Inhoud’ genoemde drie deelgebieden en de verschillende onderdelen daarvan. Wie met goed gevolg het vak afsluit, is in staat om casusposities die zijn gerelateerd aan het personen- en familierecht, het relatievermogensrecht en het erfrecht, te analyseren, te interpreteren en op te lossen, waarbij de drie verschillende deelgebieden van het vak geïntegreerd aan de orde komen.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/98405,2021,Families and Inequalities,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. BE French', 'dr. RM Verweij', 'prof.dr. PA Dykstra']",,"Inhoud

Families are a key link between macro-level processes (political, cultural, and economic shifts) and individual outcomes such as socioeconomic and health status in later life. Many of the decisions that people might perceive as fundamentally personal and individual (the kind of job taken or whether to work at all, whether to become a parent or not, which country to live in) are shaped by the interaction between our families and broader social, cultural, and institutional conditions.

In this course, students will learn about the links between families and social inequalities. We will not only look at social class as dimension of social inequality, but also focus on differences by ethnicity, race, sexuality and gender. Students will gain insights into key theoretical and methodological approaches to the study of families and social inequalities. Attention will be paid to interactions between micro- and macro-levels of analysis
column2: e.g. how markets (e.g. the precariousness of jobs), states (e.g. social policies and national laws) and political, cultural and economic shifts structure family members’ life courses and well-being outcomes, thereby reducing, maintaining or strengthening social inequalities at large.

column1: The course is theory-based and empirical, and thus questions whether claims based on theory are supported by empirical evidence. It also seeks explanations for empirical phenomena. Moreover, tutorials will use empirical evidence in debates.
<body>After successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
<li>Understand the key theoretical and methodological approaches to the study of families and social inequalities
<li>Illustrate how social inequalities arise within and between families
<li>Indicate how changes at the macro level context (e.g. policies, cultural climate, economic circumstances) influence family relations and in turn social inequalities
After successful completion of this course, students will also have developed the following skills:
<li>Understand and evaluate research and link this to trends and associations observed in data sources
<li>Build arguments and assess evidence in a clear and effective manner in oral presentations and written text
• Comment in a constructive way on other students’ work.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100188,2021,Fashion Brand Activism and Social Media,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. AC Uribe Sandoval', 'dr. V Chaudhri']",,"Inhoud

<body>During the first sessions, we will get familiar with the concepts and theories regarding brand activism and then how they are effectively applied in media campaigns in the specific field of fashion. Through seminars, lectures and engaging with case studies, we will further delve into the consequences that being openly and commercially linked to a social stance has affected (or not) the identity and performance of brands in a new media environment.</body>

Aims: This seminar will explore how fashion industry organizations use brand activism and media campaigns for market benefit. The seminar will look into the academic discussions on brand activism connecting it with the experiences of fashion brands in the market. We will focus on recent case studies but also consider the historical way in which fashion has evolved in the market as a luxury product.
• Explore the history and current events around brand activism
• Analyze how brand activism is executed by fashion brands in digital media
• Discuss the different models of brand activism implemented by fashion brands through (social) media campaigns
• Reflect critically on the potential and opportunities of using social media and activism for market gain
• Work in campaign development following the concepts defined in class
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100235,2021,Fashion Media,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. AC Uribe Sandoval'],,"Inhoud

This course aims to provide to an in-depth understanding of past and recent developments in the fashion media. Students will explore the shift from printed media to today’s online media platforms and globalized communication networks, as well as changes affecting advertisement and marketing and the use of various fashion communication technologies and outlets. Special attention will be paid to the impact of globalization on the media coverage (formats, content, discourses) given to fashion and the ways in which various media outlets influence processes of reputation building, consecration and valorisation in the fashion world.

Define and understand the importance of media in the development of Fashion through the 20th and 21st Centuries. Be able to explain how different media have represented changes in the Fashion market and how the market itself is configured differently in an international, online media environment. Reflect on the contents of fashion media, its influence to the market and makers, and its’ possible futures.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/101458,2021,Feminist Perspectives on Gender and Development,Engels,International Institute of Social Studies (ISS),,['dr. NYT Shehada', 'dr. S Heumann', 'dr. S Mullassery Sathiamma']",,
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100403,2021,"Feminist Philosophy: Bodies, Binaries & Beyond",Engels,Erasmus University College,,[],,"Inhoud

This course introduces students to the field of feminist philosophy through key texts by some of the most prominent figures in the field, such as Simone de Beauvoir, Judith Butler, Audre Lorde, Donna Haraway and Luce Irigaray. Through the analysis of these texts, we will engage with a genealogy of feminist philosophy and explore one of its most contested sites of debate: the body.

<span style=""color:black"">We will start by critically assessing mainstream canonical philosophy, which has relied on a hierarchically charged binary opposition between mind and body that also correlates with the opposition between masculinity and femininity.&nbsp
column2: The course will examine how such binary thinking relates to structural (gender) inequalities, and how this has elevated the theorizing of the body in critical feminist thought. By unpacking different feminist positions regarding the themes of embodiment and binaries, students will develop an understanding of key traditions within the field of feminist philosophy, including sexual difference theory, gender performativity, feminist phenomenology and feminist new materialisms.

column1: • Have a basic understanding of key texts within the field of feminist philosophy of the body.
• Have a basic understanding of key re-conceptualisations of the body within feminist philosophy.
<li>Have a basic understanding of key thinkers in feminist philosophy such as Lloyd, de Beauvoir, Irigaray, Haraway, Butler, Young and hooks.&nbsp
• Be able to describe and explain the problematic relation between feminism, philosophy and the body.
• Be able to describe and explain how the rational subject has typically been constructed against the natural realm and what this entails.
• Be able to describe and explain what is at stake politically, ethically and epistemologically in rethinking the body in feminist theory.
• Have a basic understanding of feminist stakes in addressing, and sometimes going beyond, binary thinking.

After the course students are able to:

In het eerste jaar van de bachelor krijg je een introductie op academisch onderwijs. De focus ligt hier op studievaardigheden. Al tijdens de eerste bijeenkomst zal worden gezocht naar een goede balans tussen jouw verwachtingen en de eisen die de studie stelt. Ook zal aandacht worden besteed aan motivatie, attitude en het structureren van zelfstudie (voorbereiding op colleges en tentamens). Er zijn bijeenkomsten voorzien over ‘de ethiek van het lezen’, waarin verschillende genres teksten worden besproken en de daarbij passende houding van de lezer. Maar er worden ook bijeenkomsten gewijd aan het volgen van hoorcolleges, het gebruik van de UB, citeren, verwijzen en frauderen, en het schrijven van een samenvatting.

Aanvullend hierop wordt als onderdeel van deze introductie één college gegeven met als thema loopbaanoriëntatie. Het doel van dit college is om je kennis te laten maken met de loopbaanperspectieven en om (voor jezelf) expliciet te formuleren wat je uiteindelijk verwacht van de opleiding.

Ook wordt tijdens dit college verteld over de mogelijkheden om jezelf naast de opleiding te ontwikkelen. Hierbij gaat het om informatie over het Honoursprogramma, exchange, medezeggenschap, commissie of bestuur bij ERA en het lopen van stage.
1. Heb je een duidelijk beeld van wat er van je wordt verwacht tijdens de voltijd bachelor Filosofie als het gaat om de omgangsvormen en het studiereglement.
2. Kan je zelfstandig een filosofische tekst lezen, analyseren en samenvatten.
3. Ken je de regels wat betreft het schrijven van een academisch filosofische tekst.
4. Weet je welke hulpmiddelen en faciliteiten de universiteit biedt ter ondersteuning van je studie.
5. Weet je welke mogelijkheden er zijn om je in en naast je studie persoonlijk te ontwikkelen.
6. Heb je een onderbouwde visie op de loopbaankansen na de studie filosofie.

In jaar 2 neem je deel aan vijf Filosofen aan het Werk (FAW) sessies waarin alumni vertellen over hun loopbaan en ervaringen. Daarnaast volg je een training van een loopbaanadviseur waar de focus zal liggen op het vergroten van zelfkennis en het maken van loopbaankeuzes.
Aanvullend maak je verschillende opdrachten. Denk bijvoorbeeld aan het maken van een eerste opzet voor de invulling van de minor/stage- en masterperiode.

3. Heb je inzicht in verschillende loopbaanperspectieven na de studie Filosofie.
4. Heb je een eerste idee over het onderwerp van je thesis.</body>

Tot slot neem je deel aan de Week van het Werk waarin verschillende workshops worden verzorgd, waaronder trainingen op het gebied van sollicitatievaardigheden.

Als filosofie student ben je dagelijks bezig met complexe problemen en de factoren die zulke problematiek veroorzaken. Dit is altijd een spanningsveld van onenigheid over waarden en doelen en van onzekerheid over kennis. Je beschikt over filosofische kennis en vaardigheden waarmee grote maatschappelijk vraagstukken kunnen worden gedefinieerd, geanalyseerd en geherstructureerd. Die eigenschappen komen goed van pas in de maatschappelijke context, waar problemen vrijwel altijd complex van aard zijn.

Om jouw kennis en vaardigheden in te kunnen zetten voor een maatschappelijke impact moet je leren samenwerken met de buitenwereld. Hiervoor zijn het ontwikkelen van professionele en praktische vaardigheden van belang. Tijdens deze stage word je uitgedaagd om je verder als professional te ontwikkelen. Enerzijds zet je jouw filosofische kennis en vaardigheden bij organisaties in en anderzijds ontwikkel je nieuwe, hands-on vaardigheden in een werkveld naar jouw keuze.

De stage loopt van september tot aan midden november, 10 weken in totaal. Gedurende de stage werk je aan je professionele ontwikkeling en aan een impactproject. Zowel voor de professionele ontwikkeling als voor het impactproject bieden we inhoudelijke workshops en sessies aan, zoals intervisie en feedbackmomenten. Tijdens die momenten kom je met medestudenten die ook stagelopen samen en help je elkaar verder.</body>
Aan het eind van het stagetraject is de student in staat om...
…filosofische kennis in te zetten ten einde een vraagstuk uit de praktijk te identificeren en analyseren.
…een (filosofische) onderbouwde aanpak te formuleren ten einde een vraagstuk uit te praktijk te doorgronden.
…een vraagstuk kritisch te analyseren ten einde een passende interventie te komen die van waarde is voor de stakeholder.
…probleemverkennende en -oplossende strategieën toe te passen in de praktijk (creativiteit, planvorming, besluitvaardigheid
…een eigen leeromgeving vormgeven ten einde de eigen professionele identiteit verder te ontwikkelen.
…de nodige persoonlijke, professionele en filosofische vaardigheden in te zetten ten einde de stakeholder te voorzien van waardevol advies.</body>

In dit vak staan drie vraagstukken centraal: het investerings-, het prijsvormings- en het beleggings- vraagstuk.

Het investeringsvraagstuk betreft de vraag hoe bedrijven het beste kunnen bepalen in welke projecten zij zouden moeten investeren indien waarde creatie centraal staat. Wij bespreken verschillende inves- teringsselectiemethoden die in de praktijk worden gebruikt waarbij de netto contante waarde methode centraal staat. Deze methode wordt namelijk beschouwd als het meest geschikte investeringsselectie- criterium indien maximalisatie van waarde wordt nagestreefd.

Het prijsvormingsvraagstuk betreft de verklaring van marktprijzen van vermogenstitels zoals aandelen en obligaties. Wij gaan in op de waardebepaling door de vermogensmarkt van aandelen maar ook op die van obligaties uitgegeven door ondernemingen en overheden. Vragen die gesteld worden zijn: Wat is de invloed van de te verwachte dividendbetalingen en het marktrisico op de prijs van het aandeel? Wat is de invloed van de termijnstructuur van de rentevoeten op de prijs van een obligatie? Hoe beïn- vloeden de couponbetalingen de prijs van een obligatie? Is het mogelijk om waarde te creëren door het dividend te verlagen en meer te investeren in groei? Wie heeft er voordeel bij een overname?

Het beleggingsvraagstuk wordt benaderd aan de hand van de portefeuilletheorie van Markowitz. Je maakt tevens kennis met het zogenaamde Capital Asset Pricing Model (CAPM). In de praktijk wordt het CAPM gebruikt bij het bepalen van disconteringsvoeten die nodig zijn bij toepassing van investe- ringsselectiemethoden.
Na het volgen van dit vak is de student in staat tot:
<li>Het analyseren en gebruik maken van financiële overzichten in relatie tot waarderingen en investeringsselectiemethoden
<li>Het toepassen en evalueren van verschillende investeringsselectiemethoden
<li>Het bepalen van de waarde van vermogenstitels zoals aandelen en obligaties
<li>Het uitleggen van de portefeuilletheorie en het toepassen van deze theorie ten einde porte- feuilles samen te stellen van vermogenstitels
<li>Het uitleggen van het CAPM en het toepassen van het model ten einde een vermogenskos- tenvoet vast te stellen
• Het uitleggen van de Efficiënte Markt Hypothese en het analyseren van de implicaties ervan.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/102998,2021,Finance,Nederlands,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['CP Koning, MSc', 'dr. A Mulder', 'dr. MBJ Schauten', 'M Hagens, MSc']",,"Inhoud

The performance of a corporation depends on how well managers succeed in creating value. This course will demonstrate how several financial theories can be applied in order to create value. In this course, we discuss three main issues in finance: capital budgeting, asset pricing and financial invest- ments.

The capital budgeting decision involves how firms select projects that create value. We emphasize the net present value method, which is considered as the most frequently used optimal decision method. In addition, we also discuss several other selection criteria and explain how these criteria are related to the net present value method.

The asset pricing part concerns the way financial assets are priced by the market. The focus is on the pricing of stocks issued by firms and bonds issued by firms and governments. Questions raised are: What is the influence of the expected stream of dividends and the level of market risk of firm’s projects on the price of stocks? How are the term structure of interest rates and promised coupon payments related to bond prices? Is it possible to create value by lowering the pay-out ratio and investing in growth? Who benefits from the value that is added when a takeover occurs?

The financial investment decision is approached from a portfolio perspective and ends with a discussion of the Capital Asset Pricing Model (CAPM). In practice, this model is often used to set a discount rate for capital budgeting purposes.
After following this course, the student is able to:
<li>Analyse and make use of financial statements in relation to valuation and capital budgeting
<li>Determine the value of financial assets such as stocks and bonds
<li>Explain Portfolio Theory and apply this theory to form portfolios of financial assets
<li>Explain the CAPM and apply this model to determine the cost of capital
• Explain the Efficient Markets Hypothesis and analyse its implications.

Dit vak behandelt de kennis die nodig is om een onderneming te kunnen waarderen. De waarde van de onderneming beinvloedt de beurskoers van een aandeel van die onderneming en bepaalt de prijs die betaalt wordt voor de aandelen van de onderneming bij een fusie of overname. Vanuit de perspectieven van een financieel manager en de financiers van de onderneming behandelt Finance 1: valuation hoe investerings- en financieringsbeslissingen de waarde van de onderneming beïnvloeden. We gaan niet alleen uit van de klassieke rationele winst-maximalisatie denkwijze, maar besteden ook aandacht aan recente ontwikkelingen op het gebied van behavioural finance en het financieren van duurzaamheid.

Finance 1: valuation omvat hoorcolleges, tutorial sessions, webcasts en on-line oefeningen. Tijdens de wekelijks colleges behandelen verschillende docenten de stof. Tijdens de tutor sessions worden actuele case studies besproken, waardoor studenten zien hoe de stof wordt toegepast bij echte investeringsbeslissingen, beursintroducties en overnames. In webcasts worden oefeningen besproken en geven docenten extra toelichting.
Na het volgende van Finance 1: valuation mag een student verwachten dat hij / zijweet wat cash-flows zijn en de waarde van toekomstige cash-flows kan vertalen naar de waarde van vandaag
<li>de financiele informatie van een onderneming kan interpreteren en een inschatting kan maken van de waarde van een onderneming
<li>de basis-principes van ondernemingsfinanciering en beleggen begrijpt
<li>voorbeelden heeft gezien van werkelijke beursintroducties, fusies en overnames en bedrijfswaarderingen
• een beter perspectief heeft over de waarde van de onderneming en duurzaamheid.

After the third week, we'll organise a mid-term exam that accounts for 20% of the grade for Finance 1. The grade for the mid-term exam is only valid for the school year 2020-2021 and will not be valid after that. The mid term exam focuses on financial calculus and on the materials of the first three weeks. We'll announce later how we'll organise this exam.

The written final exam accounts for 80% in the final grade. This exam covers the whole course, including the first three weeks. The final exam will not be a multiple choice exam as was usual in previous years. Instead it will be a case study and with open questions.</body>

During this course we'll study the knowledge necessary to value a firm. The value of the firm influences the prices of its shares en determines the price paid for shares in case of mergers and acquisitions. From the perspective of the financial manager and the financers of the firm Finance 1: valuation will show how investment and financing decisions influence the value of the firm. Besides thinking in terms of classical rational profit maximization thinking, we'll address important developments in behavioural finance and sustainability as well.

Finance 1: valuation encompasses classes, tutorial sessions, webcasts and on-line exercises. During the weekly classes, teacher present knowledge. The tutorial sessions will be focused around real-life case studies, such that students understand how the knowledge is applied for real investment decisions, IPO's and take overs. The webcasts are short films wherein exercises will be discuss and teacher give additional information.
After following Finance 1: valuation a student may expect that he / sheknows what cash flows are and can translate future cash flows to values today
<li>can interprete financial information from a firm and assess the value of that firm
<li>understands the basic principles of corporate finance and investments
<li>has seen many examples of IPO's, mergers, acquisitions and firm valuation
• has a perspective on the value of the firm and sustainability.

Achieving the Sustainable Development Goals is the grand challenge of our time. This course gives insight in ‘how the financial system can contribute to sustainable development’.

The finance transition is about transforming the financial system from operating on financial value only to working with the concept of integrated value, which combines financial, social and environmental value. The concept of integrated value is approached from an academic and practical angle (e.g. incorporating social and environmental value flows alongside the financial cash flows in the net present value (NPV) calculation).
Students apply the integrated value concept in exercises and a group assignment.
<body>After following this course, the student is able to:
• understand the allocational role of finance in society
• measure and apply integrated value in investment decisions
• evaluate companies based on the integrated value concept
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/98943,2021,Finance for non-Financials,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. G Xu'],,"Inhoud

<body>This course provides an introduction to finance for students with a non-business background. The themes we deal with in this course are particularly relevant for business decision-making in areas such as how to evaluate the financial health of companies, whether or not to invest in a project, and how to deal with risks. We ultimately aim to build intuition in finance and as such, we will also analogize to other domains, such as personal finance. The course is both theoretical and applied, and builds on online learning, Zoom discussions, and case studies.</body>
<body>After following this course, the student is able to:
• Understand and extract financial information from financial statements
• Perform financial statement analysis to evaluate the financial health of a company
• Understand the concept of time value of money
• Understand investment decision rules and evaluate whether one should carry out a project
• Understand the basic features of financial securities, such as returns and risks of stocks, and how to select an investment opportunity

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/102570,2021,Financial Accounting,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. M Koning', 'dr. MI Sandu', 'prof.dr. EM Roelofsen']",,"Inhoud

Accounting information is vital for the functioning of our economies: investors use accounting information to value shares, loan officers use accounting information when deciding on whether or not to lend money to a business and managers use accounting information to communicate to outside parties the extent to which they were successful in running the business. Financial statements are the principal means of communicating accounting information about a business to outsiders. The objective of this course is to help you become critical users of financial statements. The achievement of this goal requires an understanding of the concepts and techniques that underlie financial statements and an appreciation for the amount of judgment required in applying accounting concepts. Topics include: the fundamental concepts and techniques underlying financial statements, the accounting treatment of various financial statement items (e.g., inventory, PPE, intangible assets, investments, liabilities, and shareholders’ equity) and the analysis and forecast of financial statements.
<body>After completion of the course, the student should be able to:
• Understand the fundamental principles, concepts and techniques that underlie financial statements
• Understand, use and analyze the main items on a company’s financial statements
• Understand and use the relationships between financial statements

• Understand accounting treatments described by accounting rules and apply these accounting treatments to financial statement items (e.g., inventory, PPE, intangible assets, investments, liabilities, and shareholders’ equity)
• Evaluate the impact of different accounting treatments on financial statements
• Forecast financial statements and evaluate the assumptions behind forecasted financial statements.

It is a data-driven world with an extreme competition for analytical talent, according to research by McKinsey Global Institute and McKinsey Analytics in 2017. In this course, I will discuss two main techniques to deal with structured data and unstructured data at entry level: 1) textual analysis and 2) machine learning. It aims to introduce a set of analytical tools for understanding and examining real-time data examples in R. Students need to complete empirical assignments in R to enhance the knowledge and skills learned in the course.
After having followed this course, students should:
<li>Apply textual analysis to work with R on unstructured data
<li>Apply machine learning techniques to work with R on structured data
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/99091,2021,Financial Derivatives,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. M Grith'],,Inhoud

This course provides the mathematical foundations for the analysis of financial derivatives, in particular, futures, forwards and options. It explains pricing and hedging under the no-arbitrage assumption. Basic discrete and continuous probabilistic models are used to illustrate the binomial tree approach to option valuation and the Black-Scholes formulas for option pricing using Brownian motion and Ito calculus. Further topics include European option Greeks and hedging strategies, American and Exotic options, implied volatility, order books and market makers.
Throughout the course, numerical examples and applications of empirical financial data are used to illustrate the analytical and Monte Carlo approaches.
By its very nature, the course involves a considerable amount of mathematics and statistics. Of all subjects in finance, the area of derivatives has used these tools most intensively.
• To become proficient at maneuvering through the fundamental derivative pricing concepts and modeling approaches.
• To open the black box of the underlying modeling assumptions and understand the pros and cons of the most widely used models in practice.
• Learn the main characteristics of the financial derivatives available to perform such hedge
• Study different ways to price derivatives, with a focus on binomial and the Black-Scholes model
• Understand the implementation and benefits of hedging financial risks
• Advanced quantitative analyses of all above points

<span style=""font-size:9pt"">Financial distress risks have received a wide media attention with the corona pandemic, several large accounting frauds, the Brexit, and monetary policy decisions of the European Central Bank. Next to this media coverage, financial distress risks are a central factor in empirical and theoretical research across all fields of finance, including asset pricing and corporate finance. Students with a deeper understanding of financial distress risks can apply this knowledge at numerous employment opportunities, including finance departments of corporations, banks, public and private investment firms, accounting firms, and government agencies.&nbsp

column3: provides participants with a theoretical and practical skill set to understand financial distress risks from the perspective of a corporation. The course covers the legal framework for bankruptcies, bargaining theory, the impact of financial distress on security pricing, prediction models for default, and empirical evidence regarding the negative consequences of financial distress. The course is highly interactive and features lectures that cover theoretical concepts besides many applications, including in-class examples using real-life data, a bargaining simulation game, two case studies, and a guest lecture. The video&nbsp
column4: Welcome to Financial Distress and Corporate Restructuring
column5: provides an overview of the course.&nbsp

This course integrates advanced managerial accounting topics with recent techniques of financial management and strategic analysis. It focuses on preparing, evaluating and interpreting financial information for managerial decision making in different types of organization (manufacturing and service companies
column2: for-profit and not-for-profit). Topics covered include advanced cost allocation techniques (like Time-Driven Activity-Based Costing), evaluation of financial information to support project appraisal and capital budgeting, pricing strategies, as well as the latest techniques for customer profitability analysis and other short- and long-term investment decisions.

column1: The course involves the extensive use of the case method to analyse and discuss how financial information integrated with non-financial information is used to effectively support managerial decision making. Students are expected to apply appropriate analytical frameworks to diagnose and solve complex problems by emphasizing the connection between financial information and data analysis techniques that fit with management’s specific needs. The course provides a highly interactive environment that combines theory and practice sessions with group assignments, presentations and discussions.
On completion of this course, students should be able to:
<li>Analyse financial information that is useful in making and communicating managerial decisions
<li>Perform and evaluate advanced cost accounting techniques, such as Activity-Based Costing, Time-Driven Activity-Based Costing, and Life Cycle Costing
<li>Apply relevant cost analysis to various types of short-term decisions, including make-or-buy, discontinuation and further processing decisions
<li>Apply customer profitability analysis and explain its appropriateness in different business sectors, including both contractual and non-contractual settings

<li>Discuss pricing strategies (like market skimming, product bundling, etc.) and their consequences for different market segments vis-à-vis the inherent conflict between ‘marginal cost’ principles and the need to recover full costs
<li>Compute and evaluate variances to identify the true cause of less than optimal performance for both direct/indirect costs, production and marketing mix strategies
<li>Analyze information and discuss the financial consequences of dealing with long-run projects, in particular the importance of discounted cash flow and risk analysis in capital investment
• Apply the appropriate problem solving, computational and communication skills essential to the preparation and analysis of managerial reports that aid in managerial decision making.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/99066,2021,Financial Innovations and Institutions,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. T Eisert', 'prof.dr. S Gryglewicz']",,"Inhoud

The financial sector constantly creates new products, services, and institutions. Some examples of paramount importance include financial derivatives, securitization, and cryptocurrencies. This course looks at financial innovation through the prism of risk. First, we study how financial institutions, such as banks, manage risk by creating financial innovations. Second, we explore how regulators set requirements on financial institutions to contain risk-taking. We cover the following topics in detail:
• Sources of risk for financial institutions
• Risk measures used in the financial sector
• Students have knowledge of and insight into the theory of financial risk management.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into recent developments in financial innovation.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into the regulation of financial institutions.
• Students are able to apply standard measures to evaluate market and credit risks.
• Students are able to critically assess tradeoffs involved in regulating financial institutions.

Graduates of the HCM master programme will work in complex institutional contexts with high levels of professional autonomy, conflicting interests and financial pressure. Such a working environment involves lots of challenges without clear-cut solutions. In the course Financial Management, students will work on a realistic case study and are asked to draft and defend an advice related to the problem at hand. After this course students will be able to analyze the financial health of an organization and derive substantiated and defendable improvement suggestions. These learning objectives will be assessed in two ways: (i) by working in a group on an organizational case and writing a report about the analyses and recommendations, and (ii) by individual examination. Both components contribute equally to the course grade.

The group project will allow students to learn from each other while developing the knowledge and skills for mastering the learning objectives. The individual examination will be about critically assessing the outcomes report of another group. Students will be instructed to critically reflect on the analyses and recommendations. Students will write the critical assessment report under supervision.

This course runs over 6 six weeks and follows a 4 + 2 design. In the first 4 weeks, students will build up the skills and knowledge related to the learning objectives by means of a case study. Students will practice with financial health assessment, evaluate the financial and non-financial consequences of improvement suggestions, and critically assess each other’s work.

In the last 2 weeks, students will work on their group project demonstrating that the learning objectives are achieved. The case related to the group project will be announced at the beginning of the course.

Important: Depending on students’ prior education, students might be more or less familiar with economic concepts and financial management. For those who lack familiarity, the following books might be a valuable background read:

column2: Brouwers, R. (2018). The Basics of Financial Management. Fourth Edition. Noordhoff Uitgevers.

column1: Walsh, C. (2008). Key management ratios: The clearest guide to the critical numbers that drive your business. Fourth revised edition. Pearson Education.
Language: Only the workgroups are in Dutch</body>

Using earlier acquired knowledge and skills, students will be made familiar with several important methods and techniques used in Financial Econometrics. The emphasis is on understanding the techniques, and why the methods are relevant and appropriate for specific financial applications. In addition to the lecture there are weekly Stata assignments and one hand-in group assignment.
• Reproduce and interpret concepts in Finance and econometrics, particularly concerning methods of empirical research in Finance.
• Develop knowledge and understanding of regression analysis by means of OLS (Ordinary Least Squares) as well as the assumptions underlying OLS.
• Be able to diagnose and correct violations of these assumptions.
• Develop knowledge on time-series econometrics, including ARMA and GARCH models, as well as non-stationarity.

• Select relevant methodologies for problems in Finance (identifying the main bottlenecks in the methodology for writing a thesis), execute the analysis in Stata, interpret the results from that statistical program, judge the robustness of their conclusions.
• Assignments (not graded, but compulsory) will be conducted through the Canvas site. A group assignment accounts for 20% of the grade.

Financial reporting is vital for the functioning of our economies: investors use accounting information to value shares, loan officers use this information when deciding on whether or not to lend money to a business, and managers use financial performance information to communicate to outside parties the extent to which they were successful in running the business. Financial statements are the principal means of communicating such information about a business to outsiders. The objective of this course is to help you become critical users of financial reports. The achievement of this goal requires an understanding of the concepts and techniques that underlie financial statements and an appreciation for the amount of judgment required in applying accounting concepts. Topics include: the fundamental concepts and techniques underlying financial statements, the accounting treatment of various financial statement items (e.g., investments, liabilities, and shareholders’ equity), the analysis and forecasting of financial statements, and estimating company value and creditworthiness using financial statements.

In sum, students will gain a solid understanding of financial reporting and analysis, enabling them to understand the intricacies of financial reporting and to extract the implications of financial performance reports for businesses, investors and other stakeholders.
After following this course, the student is able to:
<li>Explain the purpose of the different components of financial statements and fundamentals of book-keeping&nbsp
<li>Apply and evaluate how the main items in financial statements are reported&nbsp
<li>Analyze financial statements and use the results of the analysis for decision-making&nbsp
<li>Critically evaluate the limits of financial statements and their analyses&nbsp
• Understand reporting discretion and how it affects financial statements and its analyses
