https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/98637,2021,Global & European Governance,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. AT Zhelyazkova', 'prof.dr. M Onderco']",,"Inhoud

The course Global and European Governance provides an introduction governance beyond nation-states. The first part of the course introduces students into the study of international politics, with special attention to the role of international institutions and regionalism. The tutorials will focus on applying the lessons from the lectures to the particular policy questions at hand.

In the second part, students will concentrate on the European Union. The European Union is the most advanced instance of international cooperation in the history of humankind. The course will focus on the main institutional aspects of the European Union, economic integration as well on political integration, and the role of the EU in the world. We will also discuss the rise of Euroscepticism. The tutorials focus on analyzing EU policies, discuss Euroscepticism, and model EU bargaining.
<body>After completing this course, the students will be able to:
• Identify different conceptual approaches to international and European politics
• Distinguish various actors in international and European politics
• Illustrate and explain the most relevant themes of the current global politics
• Explain the various decision-making procedures and their impact on international institutions
• Analyze the role of public in creating the European policies
• Independently collect, and present relevant information about international organizations and related actors
• Understand different conceptual approaches to global politics based on information from English language articles and book chapters
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100136,2021,Global Advertising,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. YCML Vermeer'],,"Inhoud

Technological advances and global market expansion require marketers, advertisers and communicators to develop an understanding of the developments and factors influencing their field. An increasing number of Western companies are looking to compete in non-western markets as the saturated markets in their own country offer only limited opportunity for growth. In this course, students will explore how a variety of companies target customers in different cultures and how they attempt to make educated decisions with respect to research, strategy, media, implementation and evaluation in today's globalized marketplace. Students will analyze and reflect upon different approaches that companies are using to communicate with diverse audiences across the globe.

Drawing on various communication models, students will analyze and interpret current advertising messages and issues arising from the creation and distribution of such messages in other countries in&nbsp
Students have gained knowledge and understanding of:
<li>Current theoretical perspectives and research methods in the field of global advertising
<li>The environmental factors affecting global advertising, including the impact of culture, regulation, and competition
• The variety of advertising strategies and tactics used in the international arena.
<li>Critically review current research on global advertising and its uses in the advertising world
• Collaborate with peers in order to analyze, reflect and present real-life cases in global advertising.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100643,2021,Global Business Strategies,Engels, Nederlands","Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. PR van der Straaten', 'prof.dr. RJM van Tulder']",,"Inhoud

This Master course is primarily aimed at understanding the global strategic and corporate perspective of sustainability issues. The course focuses on the global issues that affect, and are affected, by business. While the first core course provided deeper insight in particular on worldwide (ecological) issues, this second core course considers the international business and international management side more directly – so in particular social and economic sustainability issues will also be taken into account. Global issues are portrayed as the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). They will take a more prominent role in this course. Moving abroad and managing across borders can be a very profitable exercise for firms. It, however, is also surrounded by considerable risks. This course focuses on the logic behind the strategies of multinational corporations (MNCs) in order to assess the strengths and weaknesses of particular strategies, and the management of international operations. &nbsp
column2: How do, or can, MNCs manage across borders, and what determines their performance? What motives are relevant and how can intentions become realities? Beyond a focus on profitability, we consider broader performance implications in how MNCs either contain negative reputation effects that stem from their operations, or develop a positive image due to the way they handle the manifold issues appearing in front of them, from handling corrupt regimes and dealing with currency instability, to developing solutions for major issues like poverty, neglected diseases, catastrophes or hunger.</body>

column1: • Describing and discussing the various interfaces/topics multinational corporations Identifying the societal issues that impact on corporate international operations and the risks and responsibilities of these issues for the international operations of a multinational corporation
• Making a Quick Scan of a wicked problem (SDG) and consider at theoretical level what this could imply for corporate strategies (SDG book)
• Getting fundamental insights into three levels of motivation (and transition): personal, organizational and international
• Being able to map motives in a quick manner on the basis of publicly available information and through filling out a scan (better business scan) that maps the transition phase companies are in.
• Understanding basic behavioral barriers to transition (and implementation) processes
• Applying principles of peer review and interrater reliability in a constructive setting of parallel groups that aim at accumulating knowledge by interacting with each other on a joint case.
• Analyzing how regulatory differences across the world impact on corporate international operations, i.e. the impact of managing distance
• Considering the trade-offs multinational corporations face with managing an adequate portfolio of risks and responsibilities
• Assessing the (coping) strategies of multinational corporation to manage the societal issues that impact their corporate operations in terms of effectiveness and impact
• Providing strategic advice on the global business strategy of a specific multinational corporation that addresses the management of risks and responsibilities

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/99926,2021,Global Challenges in Health & Behaviour,Engels,Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,['dr. IEJ Bonfrer', 'dr. SA Lipman', 'dr. VT Reckers - Droog', 'J Issa', 'MM Duvekot']",,"Inhoud

<body><span style=""color:#002328"">This course will introduce students to worldwide challenges in health and unhealthy behaviours, with a focus on low- and middle-income countries (LMICs). This will be combined with coaching to further improve students’ presentation skills. First we will set the scene by introducing students to the global burden of disease across LMICs. We will identify the relative importance of communicable and non-communicable diseases and the “double burden of disease” these countries are increasingly facing. Then we will explore the limited demand for health care in these countries and interventions to increase this demand including conditional cash transfers. This is followed by interventions to strengthen the supply side of health care systems including performance based financing. We will assess the progress of different countries towards the goal of “Universal Health Coverage”. Throughout the course, students will learn to interpret results of quantitative studies that relate to these different global health topics and will improve their presentation skills working&nbsp
This course is available for maximum 30 students.
• Understand worldwide challenges related to health, health care systems and health behaviors as well as policy interventions to reduce these, especially in low- and middle-income countries.
• Evaluate and critically reflect on a quantitative research method as applied in a scientific study on health, unhealthy behaviour and/or a related policy intervention.
• Present and provide feedback about a scientific study related to health, health care systems and/or behavior to peers.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/98445,2021,Global Development Issues,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. CM Egger', 'prof.dr. AG Dijkstra']",,"Inhoud

International development is a heavily contested field. Some argue that corruption in the developing world is the main reason for countries staying poor, while others point to continuing colonial relationships in the form of exploitation of the environment and labour in poor countries, tax agreements with these countries that benefit multinational companies, and/or illicit capital flows. Similarly, there is debate on what the most effective development strategies are and on what external actors can do to alleviate poverty. This course aims to provide students with the knowledge and tools to meaningfully participate in these debates. Students get insights in the history of development as well as a thorough knowledge of the theories and debates on causes of economic growth, development and structural transformation, and on the role of human development, institutions, and culture in development. Next to these classical themes, there will be attention for the management of the global challenge of poverty and inequality. This means that issues like sustainable development, the Sustainable Development Goals, the role of foreign aid and of local policies will also be dealt with. The course has a strong empirical emphasis, providing insights in different indicators for development, poverty and inequality and working with available databases.
After successfully completing this course, you are able to:

<li><span style=""background-color:white""><span style=""color:#212529"">Assess the multiple causes for the growth and stagnation of countries: economic, (international) politics- and policy-related, institutional, and cultural
• Evaluate the main theories on effective and inclusive development strategies and the main historical experiences with development strategies

<li><span style=""background-color:white""><span style=""color:#212529"">Evaluate the opportunities and limitations of international and national responses to global poverty and (gender) inequality, in particular the Sustainable Development Goals, foreign aid, and national social policies in developing countries
• Evaluate indicators for assessing development, poverty and (gender) inequality
• Estimate a possible cause for development applying cross-country Ordinary Least Squares (OLS) multiple regression analysis.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100056,2021,Global Environmental Politics,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. S Bertrand'],,"Inhoud

Global environmental dangers are seen by many as the greatest threat to the survival of humanity. How has this link between the environment and human society been constructed over time? What are the proposed solutions to this problem, and how have they been framed, debated, and contested? Giving historical perspective to the environmental issues we face today, this course will cover topics such as energy politics, global environmental governance, and advocacy politics. Focusing on contemporary history, we will discuss questions such as: What were the political implications of moving from coal to oil as energy sources and what consequences might a move to renewable energies entail? How has the relationship between the human and non-human world evolved and should non-humans have political representation? What role did advocacy politics play in the development of our current environmental governance structures and can green consumerism be an effective solution to climate change on a global scale? In doing so, the course will provide you with an understanding of the following three core themes: 1) how ideational and material factors have interacted to shape our understanding of the environment
column2: 2) how individual actions and social structures inform environmental policy at the local and global levels, 3) how historical legacies of colonialism, race, gender, and economic inequality intersect to inform our current perspectives on global environmental politics.

column1: By the end of this module, you will be able to:
• Explain and evaluate the main debates in the field of global environmental history
• Critically assess the relation between human society and nature, particularly as it intersects with legacies of colonialism, race, gender, and economic inequality
• Reflect on the limits and possibilities for political action
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/98541,2021,Global Governance,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['prof.dr. M Onderco'],,Inhoud

Global governance is a Master course for students in the International Public Management and Policy program. The main purpose of this course is two-fold: to introduce students into state-of-the-art theorizing on the functioning of the global governance and to offer an overview of the most pertinent issues in global governance. The course applies the theories of international politics to the concept of global governance and relevant international relations
column3: the rise of governance beyond the nation-state

column1: familiarizing students with the main theoretical outlooks in the field
presenting students with the most topical themes of the current global governance
enabling students to apply learnt theory in practical analytical work
teaching students to frame their arguments coherently and substantively
further honing students’ writing and speaking skills.

<body>Please note that this course a part of Master International Public Management and Public Policy. Elective students from Master Public Administration tend to experience it as challenging. Furthermore, papers can be submitted only in English in all courses of this Master.</body>

The assertion that global politics is undergoing dramatic change has become a truism. The objective of this course is to understand and contexualise that change. We will critically analyse whether institutions and practices developed during an era in which states were the dominant actors in world politics are able to cope with today’s myriad challenges. How does global politics work in an increasingly interdependent world? Are the institutions of diplomacy and multilateralism equipped to cope with 21st century challenges that are set to change the world profoundly?

The course engages with what is being described as the 'post-Western moment' in global politics. The Western-dominated global political order is increasingly being challenged by 'new' actors, as well as new issues that are making their presence felt on the global stage: corporations, cities, individuals and other non-state entities.

Key questions that structure this course are centred on global governance: the structure problems that require a global political approach and the practices and structures that address them, the reality of which is rapidly and profoundly changing. Topics range from new forms and innovations in diplomacy as it relates to issues such as multilateralism, geo-economics, security, global cities and climate change, but also the nature of the evolving global order.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/101963,2021,Global Health Economics,Engels,Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,['CS Brindley', 'dr. CM Dieteren', 'dr. IEJ Bonfrer', 'JAM Bom', 'prof.dr. EKA Van Doorslaer', ""prof.dr. OA O'Donnell""]",,"Inhoud

In the developing world, millions of people have no, or limited access to urgently needed health care. Universal access to essential health care is an important but elusive goal. Many poor households are exposed to great financial risks related to ill health, or are forced to forego essential treatments altogether. The World Health Organization has once again put universal health coverage (UHC) high on the policy agenda and the United Nations have embraced the UHC as one of the targets of the Sustainable Development Goals.

Generally, to make progress on the path towards UHC, policy makers in low and middle income countries (LMICs) are required to raise more money for health, to move away from direct payments at the point of use and to use resources for health more efficiently and equitably. This course aims to provide students with a better understanding of each of these three topics and furthermore to evaluate specific health care reforms on this path towards UHC.

The lectures mostly consist of case studies, presenting evidence on health coverage extensions across the developing world. While the course is not focused on teaching new quantitative methods, the sessions do emphasize how the effectiveness of UHC reforms can be evaluated quantitatively.</body>
By the end of this course, students should be able to

• appraise key challenges that affect health systems in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) with regard to service delivery, the health workforce, governance, financing, medical products and technology, and information systems.
• discuss and contrast the burden of disease, social determinants and health inequalities within and between countries at different levels of economic development.
• distinguish the mandate, influence and interests of different actors in global health.
• assess and understand the rising burden of non-communicable diseases LMICs and evaluate its potential consequences on public health and access to healthcare.
<li style=""text-align:justify"">analyze the complexities of extending coverage of health care in LMICs. More specifically,
• analyze the limitations of tax financed health care.
• analyze difficulties in extending health coverage through voluntary health insurance.
<li style=""text-align:justify"">discuss innovative financing schemes of health care in LMICs. More specifically,
• outline the relations between provider payment mechanisms and universal health coverage.
• identify the scope for demand side interventions (vouchers, insurance, CCTs) in a specific context.
• critically assess the effectiveness of health care financing reforms in LMICs aimed at improving universal health coverage.
• evaluate the strength of the evidence base on the effectiveness of a health care financing reform.
• relate the characteristics of a particular health care financing scheme to the topics discussed in the lecture and critically assess.
• describe the economics of disease control and the global health challenges of antimicrobial resistance, pandemics and climate change
• evaluate national and international responses to the COVID19 pandemic including its health, socioeconomic and equity impacts

• clearly present and critically discuss health care financing reforms and their evaluation to an audience of fellow students in the course. analyze existing data related to health care financing in LMICs using the statistical software program STATA and interpret the output generated by this program.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100029,2021,Global History,Engels, Nederlands","Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['BC Fici, MA', 'dr. S Bertrand', 'JA Seijbel, MSC MA', 'prof.dr. G Oonk']",,"Inhoud

Global history is the story of interaction. Mankind has engaged in migration and trade since time immemorial. Over the centuries, the different continents, religions and nations have interacted with one another through the exchange of money, goods, information and world views. On the one hand, these contacts may lead to the fusion and mutual influencing of cultures
column2: on the other, they also lead to clashes. Indeed, war, colonisation and decolonisation mark the boundaries of interaction and exchange. In these situations, people have a heightened awareness of what makes their own group ‘unique’. This is yet another age-old phenomenon.

column1: In this series of lectures and tutorials students learn how to structure and periodize Global History into a number of major periods. Discussing these periods, the students become familiar with concepts such as mercantilism, European expansion, colonisation, decolonisation, the postcolonial world and globalisation. Throughout the course, we reflect on the major themes and key developments of human history. Using a variety of case studies and primary sources, the course establishes connections between global developments and their outcomes at the local level.

<body>Students are introduced to the history of the world from 1500 to the present. At the end of the course the students are able to reflect on periodization in global history. They use concepts such as Eurocentrism, colonization, capitalism, resistance, decolonization, post-colonial world and globalisation. Students learn searching and finding primary and secondary sources in the library and use them in a meaningful way in independently written essays.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100804,2021,Global Leadership,Engels, Nederlands","Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. M Shemla', 'prof.dr. HGH van Dierendonck']",,"Inhoud

The contact between individuals and organizations from different countries, cultures, and social groups has never been greater than in our time. In recent decades organizations have continuously globalized their operations, resulting in increasing frequency with which employees interact with colleagues and customers from different cultural backgrounds and ethnicities. At the same time, as a result of legal, social and economic shifts, workforce participation rates of women, minorities, and disabled people have dramatically grown, thus turning diversity into a strategic issue in organizations. Further, as executives operate around broader regions, global teams are formed to address the need to become globally competitive, and customers and suppliers operate across borders, the demands on global executives are ever growing.&nbsp

This course is designed to help participants develop a deeper understanding of the issues that confront global managers today, and to prepare them for leadership roles in international organizations. Through business cases, experiential exercises, and real-life examples, the course strives to explore knowledge in leading diverse people as well as in leading global organizations. Emphasis will be placed on gaining awareness for the role of culture in organizations and on developing skills to manage diversity.

Each session is a module addressing a particular leadership challenge facing executives in the global arena (e.g., leading a diverse team, managing change, etc.). The teaching approach will vary, with a mix of lecture input, group discussion, case analysis, experiential exercises, and guest lectures.
The students will have the opportunity to learn from the experiences and insights of the following guest lecturers:
A. Mr. Jacques Kemp, Former CEO of ING Asia/Pacific, will talk about strategic issues in leading international organizations
B. Mrs. Josefine van Zanten, Senior Vice President Culture Change at Royal DSM
The course grade will be computed as a weighted average of five elements
e. Cultural immersion experience/Service learning project 30%&nbsp
f. Optional task - Personal inquiry (Bonus of up to 0.5 points)
Assignments c, d, and g will be completed in teams. All other assignments are individual tasks.
Upon completion of this topic participants should:
• Acquire knowledge on managing people and teams in global contexts
• Experience first-hand accounts of the challenges facing leading diverse others
• Gain awareness of their own culture and how it influences the way they see the world

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100417,2021,Global Regimes: Trade, Health & Power",Engels,Erasmus University College,,[],,"Inhoud

International, transnational and domestic actors shape and contest the global regulations and practices we live by. For example, the World Health Organization (WHO), which remains the primary organization involved in global health, provided guidance during the outbreak of Coronavirus. Moreover, the interaction between the WHO, development aid donors and pharmaceutical companies affects access of millions of people to affordable medicine by regulating production and sales of so-called ‘generic drugs’. Such interactions of states, international organisations, NGOs, private actors, legal norms and informal rules create international regimes – sets of written and unwritten rules that guide (but do not predetermine) behaviour in particular policy sectors. These regimes are not just legal rules but practical “ways to do things” on the global arena. Ultimately, international regulatory regimes are an attempt to bring order to anarchy, make sense out of complexity and establish rules and predictability in at least some global policy areas. However, the practice of implementing these global rules is often confusing and contradictory. For instance, anti-money-laundering legislation initiated by the G7 has found higher compliance rates in ‘developing countries’ than in OECD countries. In cases of high-level corruption, it is often NGOs and activist groups which elicit compliance, not the governments who signed anti-corruption legislation. These observations make one ask how we can achieve accountable and effective governance on global and local scales. Do the current rules governing global trade and related activities, including international cooperation in the health sector, provide for a common level playing field?

This course analyses the interaction -both formal and informal - between the different stakeholders (governments, business corporations, civil society representatives etc.) in the development and functioning of international regulations regimes that govern trade and health cooperation, affecting power relations across the globe. Amongst a variety of issues, students will address issues related to the production of generic medicine (TRIPS), fighting money-laundering and tax-evasion as well as bringing transparency to arms trade. By adopting this layout the course reflects on the systemic rules that govern global trade (food, medicine and health, military equipment) and shape our lives, connecting these rules with broader issues like inequality, human rights and political coercion.

Doing so, we challenge the simplistic assumption that global regulatory regimes always transfer most effective and best applicable practices that serve the 'common good'. By going beyond legal aspects, international economics and a focus on international organisations or state actors, this course provides an expansion to the POLIR and EUC curriculum. Students will explore practical issues of global politics in commerce and health to understand how implementation and compliance challenges power asymmetries and international arrangements on a daily basis.

<body>The purpose of this doctoral seminar is to provide you with a broad understanding of the conceptual underpinnings, theoretical perspectives, and relevant contexts related to global strategy.&nbsp
column2: We will discuss key topics in global strategy, including the historical roots, current issues, and flavors of the future.&nbsp
column3: Many “best-in-show” articles in global strategy will be discussed to give you the tools to do excellent research in this area.&nbsp
column4: The course requirements may demand much time, but this investment should pay off as you work toward crafting your own academic contributions.

column1: This year, we would like to give you the opportunity to join a large-scale survey-based research project.&nbsp
column3: This will allow you to consider international corporate strategy implementation-related factors, including finer grained characteristics of the implementation process, which generally are difficult to get to through other means. We intend to survey deals that were completed between January 2017 and December 2019, and collect information on (a) background features – such as motives, organizational fit, cultural fit, strategic fit, relative size, integration completion, (b) process features, such as communication richness, degree of autonomy, level of integration, knowledge transfer, procedural justice, and (c) current acquisition performance. In addition, we’ll complement survey data with archival information on other key features, such as relative size, relatedness, geographic distance, cultural distance, cash/stock, etc.&nbsp
column4: The combination of survey data and archival data allows for studying a wide range of topics. Please know that you are not required to join this project – if you like to pursue a topic using different methods, we of course are happy to coach you as well.

How can firms gain and sustain their competitive advantage in increasingly competitive environment? Firms have realized that a focal source of competitive advantage lies in internationalization. At the same time, they have realized that increasing internationalization also bears challenges by exposing firms to competition from domestic as well as foreign firms. Furthermore, there are three factors that complicate the management beyond a firm’s domestic market: First, the potentially fundamental differences of markets, second, the scale and complexity of cross-border business, and third, the uncertainty revolving around the economic and political conditions between countries. In this elective, we will address these factors and their implications for firms’ competitive advantages in international markets and their considerations to move into foreign markets on the one hand, as well as for firms’ decisions regarding how they intend to operate across borders on the other hand. This will help us understand global strategy, why some firms thrive, while similar ones may struggle in the global marketplace.</body>

The objective of this course is to develop students’ understanding of how international operations differ from domestic ones. It provides students with the necessary knowledge for a career or further study in international business. We will focus on four learning outcomes. At the end of this course students should be able to:
• Distinguish the three leading international strategy perspectives and be able to identify the strengths and weakness of each.
• Integrate and apply both theory and practice to international strategy cases.
• Defend a choice relevant to international strategy of MNEs (e.g., entry mode, governance structure, etc.) using theoretical frameworks.
• Develop an international strategy for an existing business to show their understanding of core international strategy concepts.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/98951,2021,Global Virtual Teams,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. TIN Davidson'],,"Inhoud

<body>Teamwork has long been a vital skill in the workplace. Today’s teams however are more dynamic and “virtual” than ever and are required to operate across disciplinary, temporal, cultural, linguistic, and geographical boundaries. Organizations increasingly rely on such global virtual teams (GVT’s) to participate in the global marketplace, to leverage talent globally, or to tackle global strategic challenges.&nbsp

Unfortunately, getting global virtual teams to realize this potential is anything but trivial. Communication breakdowns, animosity and conflict across geographical sites, motivational issues, and missed targets are common. Have you mastered the skill of global virtual teamwork? Do you know how to help your team get the best out of its cross-boundary work?

This course aims to sensitize students to the opportunities and challenges of contemporary teamwork, with a focus on global and virtual teamwork. The course consists of two components. First, you will take part in a global consulting challenge where you and your global virtual team will tackle an ongoing, real-life international business challenge presented by a corporate partner. Second, and partially concurrently, a series of interactive lectures, including case studies, exercises, and group discussions, will equip you with the theoretical knowledge and practical tools to gain insight into your real-life team challenges and deal with such challenges more effectively in the future. Topics focus on the role of geographical distance, language differences, cultural diversity, and virtuality in teamwork effectiveness.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100805,2021,Global supply chain management,Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. M Pourakbar'],,"Inhoud

<span style=""font-size:9pt"">Supply chain management (SCM) has emerged as one of the major areas for companies to gain a competitive edge. Managing supply chains is a complex and challenging task, due&nbsp
column3: current business trends of expanding product variety, short product life cycles, increasing outsourcing, globalization of business, and continuous advances in information technology.&nbsp
column4: Supply chain management, as a natural successor to operations management, is a fundamental driver not only for further improving operations but also for strengthening the competitive position&nbsp
column5: of firms. When a company faces the pressure of excessive inventories, degraded customer service, escalating costs and declining profits, or a poor return on assets, its supply chain is out of control. On the other hand, when a company moves into new markets or new technologies, it must have its supply chain prepared for new business challenges and opportunities. The course will introduce students to concepts and techniques related to the design, management and improvement of supply chains and supply chain operations.&nbsp

column1: The course focuses on a variety of challenging supply chain business situations.
column2: For example, how different types of supply contracts can be used to design win-win solutions between buyer and supplier, how the benefits of information sharing can be estimated in the context of supply chain, and what supply chain strategies match with proliferating product variety. Other topics include, but are not limited to, inventory management, supply chain transportation and distribution network design, operational hedging and global supply chain risk management.&nbsp

column1: <span style=""font-size:9pt"">By the end of this course, you will:&nbsp
<li><span style=""font-size:9pt"">be able to evaluate opportunities and challenges related to the operations and supply chain strategy of companies
<li><span style=""font-size:9pt"">be able to evaluate opportunities and challenges related to the&nbsp
column2: management of supply chains in (inter)national contexts

column1: <li><span style=""font-size:9pt"">be able to analyze performance-related business problems and design and propose solutions
<li><span style=""font-size:9pt"">be able to find relevant literature and apply this to a business case
<li><span style=""font-size:9pt"">be able to create feasible plans of action and develop sensible decisions on how to deal with a particular supply chain challenge
<li><span style=""font-size:9pt"">have knowledge of, and skills for, collaborating, managing and coordinating operations in diverse teams and in complex demand-supply networks

column2: defend problem formulations and solutions based on sound arguments

column3: critically think about problem definitions and to reflect on solutions proposed by yourself and others.&nbsp

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/98427,2021,Globalisation & Society I,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. P Tuytens', 'prof.dr. DA McCauley']",,"Inhoud

column2: Society’ intends to introduce the phenomenon of globalization, and how it affects modern societies. This course will give you an opportunity to explore how various facets of globalization impact the world we live in today.

column1: This course starts with recognizing how globalization affects the world around us. We then continue with looking at how globalization influences social identities. What defines our identity, who are we? We will then turn to the social media, and the ways how they transform the world around us. Then, we continue by looking at migration as an essentially globalizing phenomenon. In addition to immaterial culture, globalization very fundamentally affects also material culture – and we will analyze this process. We close by looking at how globalization influences the men and women in the world.

By the end of the course, you will understand that all culture is deeply affected by globalization – beyond what you would expect when you first enter the classroom. But is it all rosy? Never too far from real world, the contents of this course will touch on most of the topics that animate the debates in 2020.</body>
<body>This course offers an introduction to globalization, and how it affects modern societies. At the end of the course, you should be able to:
• Identify and illustrate how globalization influences everyday life
• Compare various theoretical aspects of understanding globalization
• Contrast and evaluate various empirical ways to evaluate globalization’s impact on culture and society
<body>English serves as the language of instruction for all tutorials.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/98429,2021,Globalisation & Society II,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. P Tuytens', 'prof.dr. DA McCauley']",,"Inhoud

column2: Politics’ will give you an opportunity to explore how globalization impacts on local conditions, as well as how governments cope with the globalizations’ impact.

column1: The course starts where the course ‘Globalization: Culture &amp
column2: Society’ left off. We begin with a discussion of economic globalization. Why do businesses move to countries with lower production costs, and with what consequences for all involved? We then continue with the discussion of poverty and inequality, drawing on both local cases and evidence from across the world. Does globalization make inequality increase, or does it help societies to cope with it?

column1: Governments frequently try to manage the challenges through international cooperation. What have been the patterns and why is it so? What are the consequences for states, as well as for the international institutions? How do such institutions work?

By the end of the course, you will understand how the pressures on corporate boards in New York influence real livelihoods in Africa. You will be also able to explain why some international organizations adopt decisions in very clumsy way.
<li>This course offers an introduction to globalization, and how it affects economic life in modern societies. At the end of the course, you should be able to:
• Evaluate the consequences of economic globalization the globalization backlash
• Explain the emergence and patterns of supranational governance
<body>English serves as the language of instruction for all tutorials</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100079,2021,Globalisation and the Making of Europe, 1850-present",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. JJ Euwe', 'dr. N da Silva Perez']",,"Inhoud

<body>After an introduction on trade before the industrial revolution, the relation between increased specialisation, industrialisation and the growth of economic contacts will be discussed. In the second half of the 19th century, monetary stability and free trade created a truly global economy, but not without suppressing a substantial part of the&nbsp
column2: world. From 1914 on, two world wars and the Cold War prevented a complete recovery of economic relations. Political interests caused that national economies were created with relatively limited international contacts. In post-1945 Europe this was a problem. Not only had the 1930s shown that economic nationalism was fatal for growth and development, but Germany also was a problem. For these reasons European economic integration seemed a solution. Until the collapse of the Soviet Union, this proved very successful. In the 1990s liberalisation of international markets, but also, just as in the late 19th century, an enormous decline of transport costs, caused a second period of globalisation. Now multinational companies cut apart their production chains, &nbsp
column3: and each step was done wherever in the world is cheapest. Europe was no longer the centre and its process of integration, that after the Cold War got a boost, is now even crumbling.</body>

column1: • Students can describe the history of international economic relations since the 19th century
• Students can critically discuss the development of theory regarding international economic relations since the 19th century
• Students can apply theories of international (economic) relations to historical cases
• Students can explain how developments in Europe’s political economy since the 19th century are related to globalization
<li><span style=""color:black"">Students are able to assess Europe’s changing political-economical position in the world&nbsp

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100959,2021,Globalisation, Digitalisation and Crime",Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,"['AI Marzouk', 'dr. W van der Wagen, MSc', 'drs. EG Brein, MSc', 'prof.dr. R van Swaaningen']",,"Inhoud
<body>The course starts with two general lectures on the question why we should be engaged with international and comparative research in criminology
column2: how with the process of globalisation a so-called ‘global criminology’ has emerged
column3: and point at some socio-historical and cultural factors that have determined why criminology developed differently in Europe, North America, Latin America and Africa. The key-question in this respect is whether concrete criminological questions can actually be addressed with theoretical models that pretend to have a global validity, but mostly have Western biases. Next we will follow the structure of Katja Franko her book, of which the central line is that globalisation and digitalization offers opportunities for certain people and indeed confronts others with new limitations and forms of social exclusion.&nbsp
column4: Globalisation and digitalisation also come along with types of deviance, crime and crime control that take place across physical and digital borders. In this context, we deal with human trafficking, cybercrime, eco-crime and crimes against humanity. Additional readings offer a more concrete analysis of each of these issues, whereas guest-lecturers and practitioners will bridge the academic and the practical dimensions of the issues discussed.

column1: <body>This course aims to give insight in the cultural embeddedness of criminological perspectives and research traditions
column2: the different ways we do international and cross-cultural research in criminology in the global and digital age
column3: the different themes in global criminology
column4: and indeed the different positions that are taken in these fields.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/99965,2021,Globalisation, culture and place",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. TA Calkins III'],,"Inhoud

<body>In this course, we will discuss theories and empirical cases related to the contemporary functioning of art worlds and the dynamics of cultural globalisation and aesthetic appropriation which shape them. Arguably, cultural production and consumption have become more transnationally-oriented. We look at the changing relationship between cultural production and consumption and place
column2: the networked nature of artistic production and consumption, and the social conventions that govern them. Students get acquainted with the major contemporary trends and developments in the visual arts, music and the media, drawing on case studies from Western and non-Western context.&nbsp
column3: This course will be conducted as seminar which foregrounds student discussion and analysis of the readings.

column1: <body>This course aims to take a fresh look at the notion of art worlds and the socialized nature of artistic and cultural production and consumption à la Becker, in light of theories of and empirical research on cultural globalisation. Drawing on examples from contemporary art movements, the media and music industries from around the world, we look at how art worlds operate across spatial scales
column2: and how trends and social conventions spread across the world
column3: and how they become embedded in different places and social contexts.</body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100205,2021,Globalization and Media Industries,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. AM Diallo', 'dr. CS Ritter', 'dr. HJCJ Hitters']",,"Inhoud

<body>Central to the seminar is cultural globalization: the global dispersion of (popular) cultural products. Cultural exchange transcending regions and nation-states is not a new phenomenon, but the past three decades witnessed an accelerated intensification of international cultural flows, thanks to much improved dissemination means (e.g. streaming and other digital technologies) and &nbsp
column2: transnationalisation in media and cultural-industry businesses.

column1: Media are pivotal in this process of cultural globalization: all around the world, people are familiar with TV series such as The Big Bang Theory, the Marvel Cinematic Universe and popular music artists like Beyoncé. Globalization however, is not the same as Americanization: Indian movies, South Korean popular culture (K-wave) and formats such as The Voice are sold and consumed all over the world. In this course the meanings of developments in the media industries for production, content and consumption of media products is scrutinized. Due to their global presence entertainment genres form the focal point of this course. To critically examine cultural globalization in relation to media industries and the symbolic meanings produced the ‘critical political economy’ approach is adopted.
• Key developments in the global spread of culture and the role of media therein.
• Different perspectives in the scholarly and public debate on the nature and impact of cultural globalization.
• Apply relevant theoretical insights and methods in the analysis of globalization processes and their social consequences.
• Critically reflect on academic texts, both verbal and in written form.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100242,2021,"Globalization, Digitalization and Culture",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. SJ Opree', 'MC Sarria Sanz', 'prof.dr. MNM Verboord', 'prof.dr. P Arora', 'V Balan, MSc']",,"Inhoud

The so-called Islamic State recruits members from around the world for their cause through Twitter. Netflix recently declared that after analysing their browsing statistics, they realized that the old constructs of cultural taste in association with the usual suspects of gender, class and age are irrelevant in their algorithmic design. Solidarity marches are happening more frequently around the world –the Occupy movement, Women’s march, and March for Science. What these diverse phenomena are pointing out today is that we live in an increasingly global world where through social media, we are able to create new forms of communities, cultures and contexts that go beyond national borders.

Hence, it is worth asking: Is the notion of the nation state redundant? Does culture matter today in the age of the internet? As social networking sites and their impact spans across borders, are we living in a post-cultural age? To talk of global and representative practice, we need to expand our frames of reference, revisit sacred discourses and Western-biased rubrics of digital design and practice. A paradigm shift is needed in approaching cultural phenomena on the internet with a more global-oriented, open- ended and pluralistic perspective. This seminar investigates popular events, claims and trends by going into the history of dominant theories of influence over these decades including (post) structuralism, (post) modernism, (post) Marxism, feminism and (post)colonial discourse .This opens up critical discussions on key topics such as privacy/surveillance, labour/leisure, activism, democracy, and media consumption/production. &nbsp
column2: This is essential for students to be able to position their research and target audience within a more globally architected digital and cultural landscape.

column1: • normative constructs in new media studies and dominant perspectives on digital cultures
• the development of key concepts on the globalization of the internet and persistent discourses on
• the intellectual history and theoretical shifts in the framing of culture, community and technology
• apply relevant theoretical insights and methods to their topic of choice
• critically reflect on academic texts, both verbal and in written form
<li><span style=""color:black""><span style=""color:black"">design and write an essay
column2: make an intellectually compelling argument on globalization of the
column3: internet and its relationship to culture

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/101271,2021,Goederen- en Insolventierecht,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['BB Balla, LLM', 'mr. A Schoneveld', 'prof.dr. KKECT Swinnen', 'RSM Bosch']",,"Inhoud

<body>Het goederenrecht vormt samen met het verbintenissenrecht een van de twee pijlers van het vermogensrecht. Iedereen heeft te maken met goederenrecht, of het nu de vraag betreft wie eigendom van een gestolen fiets heeft of de vraag aan welke eisen een bank moet voldoen wil zij bewerkstelligen dat zij een geldig pandrecht krijgt op de handelsvorderingen van haar debiteur. Het goederenrecht is daarnaast onlosmakelijk verbonden met het insolventierecht. Denk aan vragen als, moet de curator van de dief van bovengenoemde gestolen fiets deze fiets ook in faillissement teruggeven, of moet de fiets juist ten behoeve van de gezamenlijke schuldeisers worden verkocht? En mag de bank, die een geldig pandrecht op de handelsvorderingen van haar debiteur heeft verkregen, haar vordering in faillissement verrekenen? Dat en meer komt aan bod tijdens het vak goederen- en insolventierecht.</body>

<body>In dit vak komt zowel het goederenrecht als het insolventierecht aan de orde. Bij het B1-vak Inleiding privaatrecht is de basis van het goederenrecht in hoofdlijnen behandeld. In dit vak wordt dieper op het goederenrecht ingegaan en staan verhaal, zekerheid en insolventie centraal. Het vak heeft daarbij tot doel de studenten de hoofdregels van het goederen- en insolventierecht bij te brengen, zodat zij in de (commerciële) praktijk zelfstandig een goederen- of insolventierechtelijke casus kunnen oplossen. Vanwege het grote belang van dit leerstuk in de praktijk wordt extra diep ingegaan op het leerstuk van de verpanding van vorderingen.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/98952,2021,Going Viral: Ideas that Spread Around the World,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. A Krefeld-Schwalb'],,"Inhoud

Think about the last time you shared a link with your friends and family. It could have been an informative article, a silly meme, or a song you like. Now think again, why did you share it with your family? Most likely, you weren't the only one who shared it, but part of a viral spread of information. The Going Viral: Ideas that Spread Around the World course will help you answer that question. We will explore why some things go viral while others never gain traction. In doing so, we'll examine the very specific conditions that social networks set. The course will cover not only the positive potential of viral information spread, but also the dangers that exponential spread of misinformation poses to society.

The cornerstones of the course are set by three influential books on word-of-mouth. In addition to sections from these seminal books, influential scholarly articles on the topic are discussed. These articles cover the broad spectrum of academic research in marketing, from basic psychology to memory and attention effects in consumer research to quantitative modeling of social networks and information diffusion. So not only will this course help you understand and design successful ideas and products, it will also provide a broad introduction to the rich field of marketing research by covering one of its core topics: Word-of-mouth.</body>
<body>After taking the course, students know the conditions for viral information spread:
They understand the potential for companies by changing consumers preferences through viral information, but also know some of the risks of viral information spread.
Students can distill the theoretical knowledge from scientific articles and apply it to real-life phenomena.
They can do the basics of state-of-the-art data analyses of social media content.
After taking the course, students have developed a critical opinion about the potentials and risks of viral information spread, for the society and the economy.</body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/101934,2021,Governance and Strategy,Engels, Nederlands",Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,"['dr. RAJ Borst, MSc', 'dr. SPF van Haperen', 'HS Stalenhoef, MSc', 'M Kalisvaart', 'MJC Aspria, MSc', 'OS van der Woerd, MSc', 'T Seddiqi']",,"Inhoud

<body>Healthcare managers increasingly are confronted with changes in the policy environment affecting the ways they organize and manage daily care processes. For example, legal requirements for patient participation force healthcare managers to install patient representatives in their advisory boards, and safety regulations ask for structured ways of organizing and accounting for the quality of care within healthcare organizations. Policy measures also influence the strategic choices of managers
column2: if patient safety is displayed as an important problem in healthcare, rendering patient safety a top priority of the healthcare institution can be a valuable way of presenting the institution to third-party payers and patients.

column1: Yet, incorporating national policy aims and measures in the organization’s policies also transforms the role of the healthcare organization. A healthcare organization is not a neutral adaptor of national policy requirements, but actively gives shape to these policies. For instance, what patient participation means and how the actual role of patients in the healthcare organization’s decision making process is fleshed out in practice, gets shape in the day-to-day interactions between health care managers, healthcare practitioners and quality staff.
This course aims to provide HCM students with theoretical lenses as well as practical knowledge to the understanding and dealing with governance and strategy issues in healthcare organizations.
Language: Only the workgroups are in Dutch
• Students are able to explain theories on governance and strategy.
• Students are able to analyse governance issues in healthcare from different theoretical perspectives on governance.
• Students are able to analyse strategic issues in healthcare from different theoretical perspectives on strategy.
• Students are able to evaluate contemporary challenges and changes in healthcare governance and strategy
• Students are able to deal with, and reflect on, complex healthcare issues in a serious game.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/101240,2021,Governance in de zorg,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['mr.dr. AGH Klaassen', 'prof.mr.dr. MAJM Buijsen']",,"Inhoud

Het vak Governance in de zorg focust zich op de drie partijen in de zorg, de zorgaanbieder, de zorgverzekeraar en de patiënten(vereniging). Vanuit het rechtspersonenrecht wordt deze drie partijen nader belicht. Daarnaast maakt de student in het vak Governance in de zorg kennis met de zeer uiteenlopende relaties waarmee mensen aan deze zorgorganisaties verbonden (kunnen) zijn, variërend van hoogopgeleide, vrijgevestigde medisch specialisten tot uitzendkrachten werkzaam in de schoonmaak, van bestuurders, interne toezichtzichthouders tot leden van cliëntenraden en ondernemingsraden. Aandacht wordt besteed aan onder meer vraagstukken van governance, medezeggenschap en arbeidsrecht.
1. De taken en bevoegdheden van de verschillende organen van zorgverzekeraars, zorginstellingen en patiëntenverenigingen (her)kennen, toepassen en analyseren/evalueren in een casuspositie.
2. De eisen van bestuurders en interne toezichthouders van zorgverzekeraars, zorginstellingen en patiëntenverenigingen en hun aansprakelijkheidsposities analyseren en waarderen.
3. De positie van de cliëntenraden en ondernemingsraden (her)kennen en analyseren/evalueren wanneer en op welke wijze cliëntenraden en ondernemingsraden hun rechten kunnen aanwenden.
4. De regels voor beloning, jaarverslaggeving en groepsstructuren toepassen en analyseren/evalueren in een casuspositie.
5. De verschillen tussen het huidige en toekomstig recht (her)kennen, toepassen en analyseren/evalueren in een casuspositie.
6. De positie van de maat en de bevoegdheden (her)kennen en toepassen op een casuspositie en de aansprakelijkheidspositie analyseren en waarderen.
7. De positie van een medisch specialist (her)kennen en de specifieke regels toepassen en analyseren/evalueren in een casuspositie.
8. De rol van het Scheidsgerecht (her)kennen en zijn uitspraken toepassen en analyseren/evalueren in een casuspositie.
9. De regels voor mediation en de verschillende arbeidsrelaties in de zorg toepassen en analyseren/evalueren in op een casuspositie.
10. Een onderzoeksvraag formuleren en daarover een paper schrijven en de (voorlopige) onderzoeksresultaten daarvan presenteren.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100742,2021,Governance of Information Systems, Enterprises, and Supply Chains",Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof.dr. GWJ Hendrikse'],,"Inhoud

Governance of information systems, enterprises, and supply chains studies the design of incentives (contracts, ownership structures, …) and coordination mechanisms to channel business activities in value-creating ways.

The lectures present the core ideas as simple as possible. This is done in a two-tier approach. First, the main topics are introduced at a master-level. Second, some of the classic articles in the field will be studied in more detail, depending on the level of the students participating in the course.
The goal of this course is to learn the topics at the frontier of the field, and desirably to develop contributions to your PhD-thesis.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/98588,2021,Governance of Migration and Diversity,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. A Pisarevskaya', 'dr. AS Leerkes', 'dr. JD Handmaker', 'dr. SWS Winters', 'dr. Z Kasli']",,"Inhoud

This course is coordinated by the Erasmus University Rotterdam and given jointly with University of Leiden, and Institute of Social Science, and is part of the Governance of Migration and Diversity Master programme.
This course offers a multidisciplinary outlook on governance of migration and diversity from the perspectives of public administration, history, sociology and development studies.&nbsp
column2: The course aims to stimulate a dialogue between the practice of migration and diversity governance and a variety of theoretical perspectives on governance. During the seminars and site-visits the students are given the opportunity to engage in discussions with both scholars and practitioners of governance.

column1: The course consists of seminars and field trips (or webinars). It includes two introductory lectures about the structure of the course and about the foundations of&nbsp
column2: governance theory. The following eight sessions will be conducted by governance scholars working within disciplinary traditions of Public Administration, Sociology, History and Development Studies, each seminar introducing the topic and new aspects of governance theory will be followed up by a site visit&nbsp
column3: to the organizations, where students are expected to engage in conversation with practitioners of governance.

column1: NB. Due to COVID-19 situation in the country, the visits to the sites may be replaced by webinars with practitioners from the organizations.</body>

Based on the 6 lectures, obligatory and optional readings of the course, lecture slides and 4 theory-meets-practice webinars (or site-visits if possible) students at the end of this course will be able to:
• Interpret various issues of governance of migration and diversity from different disciplinary perspectives (public administration, sociology, history and development studies)
• Apply these theories and perspectives to real-life cases of governance of migration and diversity
• Formulate recommendations to governance actors to improve their governance practice (grounded in real-life cases, based on scientific evidence and theoretical perspectives)

Cities are increasingly seen as important places to ‘govern’ health. In the Netherlands, cities have gained more responsibilities since the decentralizations of care and support to local municipalities. On the local level, solutions need to be found for pressing problems, such as rising health inequalities between neighbourhoods, fragmented public service provision, and unsuitable housing for aging populations. To address these problems in innovative ways, experiments are being conducted in urban labs and inter-sectoral networks are set-up to enhance collaboration between different stakeholders in the city.

In this course we explore the ways in which urban health has come to be governed in modern societies. Governance, in the literature as well as in practices, stands for policy without central policy actors. That is: policymaking and implementation have come to rest on a myriad of actors and perspectives that are interwoven in networks. The course therefore serves as a guide to how urban governance for health is being done. This will be discussed both on a theoretical level (using concepts) and on practical level (using urban action research).

During the course students will work together with a field partner in Rotterdam on a specific urban issue. This ‘action-research’ will allow students to delve deeper into an urban problem and propose policy recommendations for solving it. Grading is based on a group paper, where theoretical concepts and recommendations for practice come together, and on an individual open-questions exam.</body>

<body>The main objective of this course is for students to get acquainted with healthcare governance as a concept and the different shapes and forms of governance in practice. More specifically, the following learning goals apply to this course:
• Students have an understanding of the shift from government to governance
• Students have an understanding of different coordination modes in governance (market, state, networks and communities)
• Students can explain the connection between place and healthcare governance.
• Students can apply theoretical concepts from the literature to analyze empirical cases of healthcare governance (see the 2 cases in Feijenoord, Rotterdam)
• Students will be able to develop useful policy recommendations for Feijenoord on the basis of the key concepts and themes of this course
• Students are able to explain and critically reflect on how people can be ‘responsibilized’ and be ‘made governable’
• Students are able to effectively discuss literature and issues on governance during meetings
• Students are able to provide peer-support to each other during workgroups by reading and discussing each other’s draft version of the report
• Students are able to write a coherent essay on the basis of a clear research question.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/98406,2021,Governing Social Inequalities,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. AM Kanas', 'dr. BE French']",,"Inhoud

When it comes to social inequalities, policies and institutional arrangements are part of the equation. They help shaping the incidence and consequences of our endowments and of the events we experience during our life – and often do so unequally. Policies and institutions may in fact mitigate social disparities, build some anew, magnify others, or even do all of the above at once. The result is often composite, a patchwork of trade-offs and unintended consequences cutting across the social fabric.

In this course we will examine a number of policies and institutional arrangements implicated in the (re)production of social inequalities. We will explore theory- and evidence- based accounts of these policies and institutions, of their features and effects as examined across the social sciences. Emphasis will be given to current debates, both academic and public, and to the organisation of informed debates within the class. Particular attention will be devoted, but by all means will not be limited, to the realms of welfare provision and labour markets. Most of all, the course will focus on four axes of social inequality, namely gender, generation and cohort, race and ethnicity, and class.
<body>After successful completion of this course, students will be able to:

<li>Review and analyse theory- and evidence-based accounts of the features and consequences of different policies and institutions, with a particular emphasis on the (re)production of social inequalities
<li>Reflect on how policies and institutions respond to socio-economic, demographic, and political developments

<li>Identify trade-offs and unintended consequences of policies and institutional arrangements, i.e. how policies and institutions might mitigate some social inequalities while simultaneously producing or intensifying others
• Apply a theoretical “toolbox”, built on the insights of sociology and (equally) of other social sciences, to analyse policies/institutions and their consequences.
After successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
<li>Make informed policy recommendations, especially in the realm of social policies or other institutions implicated in social inequalities
• Report and summarise findings in a clear and effective manner (in writing).

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/98571,2021,Governing Urban Economic Growth and Innovation,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. J Fransen', 'prof.dr. FG van Oort']",,"Inhoud

Cities are dynamic engines of economies growth and innovation, but they also create negative externalities such as inequality, poverty and pollution. Urban economies are primarily coordinated by market transactions, many of which take place at an (inter)national level. The ability of urban governments to influence markets is limited and widely discussed. The course adopts a network governance perspective, debating if and how varying combinations of markets, state and non-state actors steer and facilitate local economic development. The question is if and how urban network governance can stimulate economic growth and innovation, while overcoming negative externalities.

The course first discusses multi-disciplinary factors driving economic growth, creativity, innovation and entrepreneurship in a global economy. Subsequently the section zooms in on transitions towards sustainable and resilient urban economies, responding to recent challenges such as climate change, financial crises, growing inequality and the Brexit.
<body>By the end of the course, students are able to:
• Distinguish and apply different perspectives to urban economic governance
• Analyze the complex nature of urban economic governance across and within sectors and cities
• Formulate conditions for sustainable and inclusive urban economic growth and inclusive innovation
• Determinate strategies to overcome negative externalities (like poverty, inequality and pollution)

<body>Handelingen en gedragingen als misdaad kwalificeren en bestraffen, is geen theorieloze en eeuwig onveranderlijke praktijk. Aan dit gebeuren liggen talrijke filosofische en politieke vooronderstellingen ten grondslag die evolueren in de tijd. Over deze theoretische vooronderstellingen en achterliggende historische denkkaders, wordt in het vak grondslagen van de criminologie gereflecteerd.&nbsp
• Inzicht verschaffen in de maatschappelijke verhoudingen en filosofische opvattingen die een rol hebben gespeeld bij de historische ontwikkeling van de ideeën over misdaad en straf.
• Inzicht verschaffen in de vraag waarom in bepaalde historische periodes gewetensdelicten zoals ketterij strafwaardig geacht werden en hoe men reageerde op een verdenking van hekserij.
• Inzicht verschaffen in de rol die de godsdienst speelde in de vervolging van gewetensdelicten en hekserij.

• Studenten kritisch laten nadenken over de vraag waarom een staat het recht heeft om diegenen die afwijken van bepaalde normen te straffen en inzicht verschaffen in de wijze waarop dit filosofisch gerechtvaardigd wordt?
• Studenten kritisch leren reflecteren over de reikwijdte van overheidsmacht en over de filosofische oorsprong en de grondslag van individuele rechten tegenover de staat.
• Inzicht verschaffen in de rol en de betekenis van de Verlichtingsfilosofie in dit proces.
• Studenten kennis laten maken met het debat tussen utilisten en retributivisten in de strafrechtsfilosofie.
• Studenten kritisch laten nadenken over de vraag of (en zo ja hoe) foltering en de doodstraf kunnen gerechtvaardigd worden (en indien niet, waarom?)
• Inzicht verschaffen in de verschillende ethische theorieën die een antwoord formuleren op de vraag wanneer de overheid iets strafrechtelijk mag verbieden?
• Studenten kritisch doen nadenken over de vraag of alleen individuen misdaden kunnen plegen dan wel of ook staten en (internationale) organisaties dat doen?
• Studenten doen reflecteren over de vraag of het object van de criminologie ruimer is dan louter datgene wat door de strafwetgever strafbaar is gesteld.
• Studenten kennis laten maken met de manier waarop de criminologie als wetenschap is ontstaan en hoe zij zich verhoudt tot de (totalitaire) politiek.
• Studenten kennis laten maken met het debat over vrije wil en determinisme in de strafrechtstheorie.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/98873,2021,Groups at Work,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. H van Mierlo'],,Inhoud

It is no coincidence that our psychology curriculum in Rotterdam begins with a course about people in groups (social psychology). Groups were central to the human past, are central to our present, and will continue to be central to the human future. To understand human behavior, we need to understand groups, because people live in groups, play in groups, and.... work and perform in groups.

As a Work and Organizational Psychologist, you will be faced with groups at work all the time: departments, project teams, discussion groups, boards, work teams, et cetera. Often, your involvement with groups will be about improving them, about suggesting or implementing changes to make groups or teams more effective. In your future job you may, for example, train groups, build groups (or teams), advise groups, design groups, disband groups, address groups, motivate groups, study groups, or simply participate in groups.

By presenting state-of-the-art knowledge about various aspects of groups at work, this course will give you the opportunity to prepare for these and other intriguing encounters with the practice of group work.

<body>‘Groups at Work’ is a specialized Master course that will introduce you to different aspects of groups at work. The tutorial group meetings and lectures enable you to become familiar with the state of affairs in group research and encourage you to further develop an academic attitude: a constructive, critical attitude towards the things you see, hear, and read. At the end of this course:
• You have knowledge and understanding of the basics of groups at work, diversity in groups, group processes and emergent states, and group leadership.
• You have developed a critical view of the literature about these topics
<body>De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding.</body>

The Grow module offers you a unique opportunity to build your knowledge, skills and experience in establishing and growing a business. The course deals with new business entry, expansion and scaling up, potentially, the exit of the founder-owner(s) of the business. Therefore, important topics are establishing the structure and governance of the nascent and growing firm, looking for its first sales and customers, finding critical resources (money, employees), and expanding the business. Eventually, some businesses may fail, some are wildly successful. Both scenarios might mean that the founders have plan for their exit and harvesting.

This BSc course is relevant for students who plan to become (or are already) involved in new venture formation, building fast-growing firms and making existing businesses more entrepreneurial. Students that want to know more about the ins and outs of start-ups, scale-ups and high-impact entrepreneurship as a future consultant to young and fast-growing companies, as an investor funding them, or as an entrepreneurship support manager (e.g. as a growth hacker) may find this course interesting and relevant too.
After following this course, the student is able to understand and analyze:
• when to found (should I start a company now or work elsewhere first)
• how the dynamics and challenges of growing a business from a strategic perspective works
• should investors be approached to boost the growth of the company (and if so, which investors) or not
• whom to hire and how should the roles and relationships be created and managed
<li>how to design the structure and create the culture of a growth-oriented venture. &nbsp

Human Resources have increasingly been recognised as a source of competitive advantage and as such good people management is vital for organisations. The course is designed to develop a thorough knowledge and understanding of the effective management of people. After exploring the theoretical origins of HRM, the emergence of HR strategy and the relationship between business strategy and HRM strategy, the course will focus on discussing and analysing important HRM activities such as HR planning, recruitment and selection, training and development, absence and retention management, reward and performance and exit management. A deepened understanding of the strategic character of these practical HRM activities provides students with the knowledge and skills required for the integration of HR policies into a coherent HRM strategy, the implementation of which will contribute to a high-performance organisation.

This course offers students the opportunity to conduct an internship on a topic of their own interest. An internship can help students to apply their theoretical knowledge as well as develop their professional attitude including skills such as organizing, planning, analyzing data and professionals collaboration with coworkers.&nbsp
This course offers internships via two possible tracks
column2: a practice-based and a research-based track. Students are themselves responsible for finding a practice-based internship, while we can place students interested in a research-based internship on an ongoing project of faculty. This can include a project that is offered by staff working on issues in human resources management, organizational change, organization theory and/or organizational behavior.

column1: The duration of the internship is at least equivalent to 5-6 weeks full-time work, but can also be spread over a longer period of time or be conducted on a part-time basis. At the end of this course the student should be able to:

<li>Prove a professional attitude by reflecting on their built work relationships and skills.&nbsp
