Macro principles of good writing and publishing (Day 1)

column4: What makes a paper a good paper
column5: why do some paper get published and others not

column4: Writing as a contribution to scholarly discourse: Finding your conversation, finding a story to tell
Structuring a paper: Different options and when they are appropriate.
Knowing the key ingredients for each section of a paper: what has go into an introduction, a literature review, etc., and where exactly should it be located.
Good sections, good paragraphing (pyramid principle, topic sentences etc.)
Rules for building strong sentences, cohesion among sentences (e.g., relating to action characters, strong verbs, 2-3-1, paragraphing, creating overlap, from known to unknown, concision)
Choice of tense and mode to fit section of the paper and the content, choice of words that send the right “signals”, etc.
Conducting your writing project: Strategies for productive writing and editing
Writing to get published in leading academic journals
Measuring and managing your impact as a scholar

column1: Prerequisites: Please note that attendance is expected on all three days. Participants will be admitted on a first come, first served basis. The maximum number of participants is 20.

This course aims at improving participants’ academic writing skills, and help them to publish papers at leading journals. The course is an intensive one-week course, where participants are expected to focus exclusively on this course. Participants are expected to submit a piece of writing before the start of the seminar. This can be a draft of a conference paper or a draft of a regular paper. During the course, you will be invited to revise the written piece after each day. At the end of the course, the initially submitted piece of writing should be revised substantially and should be re-submitted to the professor. Participants should also actively take part in the discussions
• At the end of this course, participants know how to craft high quality papers.
• Participants know the principles of good academic writing, and recognize these principles.
• Participants improve their own writing and editing.
• Participants understand the publishing process, including research ethics issues that can arise in its course.
• Participants understand how scholarly impact is created and measured, and can apply this knowledge to increase their own impact.
• Participants get an understanding why many papers get rejected.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/101055,2021,Handelsrecht,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. FL Stevens', 'drs. EC Smit - Bennemeer', 'mr.dr. JLE Vannerom', 'prof.mr. FGM Smeele']",,"Inhoud

<body>De economie draait op het kopen en verkopen van de meest diverse goederen en diensten. Allereerst wordt daarom aandacht besteed aan het (internationale) kooprecht. Wat zijn de rechten en verplichtingen van koper en verkoper? In handelstransacties zijn koper en verkoper meestal niet op dezelfde plaats gevestigd. De verkochte goederen zullen dus vervoerd moeten worden. Wat indien de goederen tijdens dit transport beschadigd worden? Het vervoerrecht regelt de rechten en verplichtingen van de partijen die bij het vervoer betrokken zijn. De gekochte goederen moeten uiteraard ook betaald worden. Wanneer koper en verkoper zich niet op dezelfde plaats bevinden wordt het uitvoeren van een betaling minder evident, zeker wanneer koper en verkoper elkaar niet per se vertrouwen. De handelspraktijk heeft hiervoor verschillende oplossingen uitgewerkt, die in belangrijke mate berusten op het concept van waardepapieren. In het onderdeel betalingstechnieken en waardepapieren wordt hieraan aandacht besteed. Wanneer in een transactie iets mis loopt, is het zeer wel denkbaar dat de schadelijder een aansprakelijksvordering heeft op een andere partij. Het instellen van een vorderingen kosten echter tijd en geld, en draagt steeds een procesrisico in zich. Vaak zullen de partijen bij een handelstransactie risico's dan ook verzekeren, zodat zij zich bij een schadegeval tot hun verzekeraar kunnen wenden i.p.v. de uitkomst van een procedure te moeten afwachten. Het verzekeringsrecht regelt de rechten en plichten van partijen in het kader van een verzekeringsovereenkomst. Tenslotte wordt aandacht besteed aan twee rechtsdomeinen die niet noodzakelijk, maar wel vaak een rol spelen bij handelstransacties. Vooreerst het recht inzake handelstussenpersonen. Producenten willen hun producten vaak ook wel in het buitenland aanbieden, maar vinden het moeilijk om dit vanop afstand te doen, en maken daarom gebruik van plaatselijke tussenpersonen (distributeurs, handelsagenten, enz.). De opdrachtgever en de tussenpersoon hebben soms echter uiteenlopende of zelfs tegenstrijdige belangen, wat in de praktijk regelmatig tot problemen aanleiding geeft. Het handelstussenpersonenrecht regelt deze materie. Tenslotte wordt aandacht besteed aan het intellectuele eigendomsrecht. Producenten investeren tijd en geld in de ontwikkeling van producten, en worden door het intellectuele eigendomsrecht beschermd tegen ongeoorloofd kopiëren en namaak.</body>

<body>Het doel van dit vak is om de student een basiskennis te verschaffen van de diverse onderdelen van het handelsrecht, met name het (internationale) kooprecht, het vervoerrecht, het (internationale) betalings- en waardepapierenrecht, het verzekeringsrecht, het handelstussenpersonenrecht, en het intellectuele eigendomsrecht.</body>

“The best way to predict the future is to invent it.”
Ed Catmull, President of Walt Disney Animation Studios
Creativity is a vital skill. It makes you better at work, better at home, and generally more fun to be around. In a knowledge-based and innovation-driven world, creativity is an essential &nbsp
column4: capability to gain a sustainable competitive advantage. All &nbsp
column12: innovations begin with creative ideas and creativity is also needed during the entire innovation process. More than that, all employees in any job and at any level of the organization can make use of creativity to enhance work performance and “invent” the future as Catmull put it.

column1: Unfortunately, creativity is known to diminish with age. Education and working life refrain from asking for creativity because it is hard to measure and impossible to predict and catch in numbers. As a consequence, creativity as a skill is neglected. This course aims to do something about that!

The course consists of three components. In the first part you will learn more about creativity in general and the social psychology of creativity. We will investigate different factors that influence creativity and provide tools to help you analyze and understand your creative performance (Weeks 1 and 2). During the second part we tackle your creative thinking skills. Specifically, we will look at how to overcome biases and make yourself and (groups of) other people more
column12: creative. We look at techniques for enhancing individual creativity as well as creative thinking tools that can be applied more broadly across organizational contexts such as brainstorming and design thinking. We will also examine how to create in the face of constraints (Weeks 3, 4, 5, 6). During the third part we will look at what happens with creative ideas. Generating ideas for the sake of generating ideas is not enough: How can you make sure that you and others around you can recognize the value of creative ideas? These and other topics will be addressed in the final part of this course (Weeks 7, 8).

column1: Put simply, we will address various aspects of the creative process, allowing you to understand not only how to generate creative ideas, but also how to evaluate, select and move ideas towards implementation.</body>
After following this course, the student is able to:
• Understand the dimensions of creativity and creative ideas
• Identify and analyze different factors that influence creativity
• Understand and utilize techniques to stimulate individual idea generation
• Understand and utilize techniques to stimulate idea generation in groups
• Develop systems to evaluate and select ideas

<span style=""font-size:9pt"">The Syrian civil war, the Ebola epidemic, Covid-19, hurricane Katrina, the Rohingya crisis, the earthquakes in Nepal and Haiti, the Japanese tsunami, the Indian Ocean tsunami, the HIV/AIDS epidemic,… the world has experienced many large humanitarian crises in past decades. Climate change, population growth, and rapid urbanization will likely only increase their frequency and impact in the future. At the same time, the world is still facing several substantial development challenges. For example, nearly 2 billion people still lack access to basic&nbsp
column3: and more than half the world population still lacks access to essential health services.&nbsp

column2: h<em><strong>ealth and humanitarian crises come with&nbsp
column3: extreme demands for logistics, technology, and operations management. Extreme in terms of operating conditions. Extreme due to the scarcity of resources. And extreme in terms of consequences for health and well-being. For example, managing disaster response is like organizing the next Olympic Games without knowing where it will take place, when it will take place, and how many people will come. Though this seems
column4: pretty impossible, the way response is being prepared and managed is a matter of life and death for many. Similarly, increasing access to medicines and health services in&nbsp
column6: countries is about addressing a disproportionally heavy burden of disease with very limited resources (doctors, clinics, outreach/vaccination teams, transportation, infrastructures, money…). Maximizing the effectiveness of&nbsp
column8: is hence key, which is exactly what logistics, technology, and operations management is about.&nbsp

column4: Humanitarian Logistics and corresponding UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Though it covers some theory, the&nbsp
column6: will be on learning by doing. Through case studies, a simulation game, guest lectures from people who work in the humanitarian sector,&nbsp
column8: you will work on real and complex challenges related to disaster relief, medicine supply chains, and health service delivery in low and middle income countries. Examples include: Where should one locate warehouses to pre-position relief goods? What/how much to stock there? What logistics network should one set up to handle incoming relief goods after a disaster? How to optimize the dispatching of these goods? What technology is useful to support relief activities? Should governments adopt a push or a pull system for medicine supplies to health facilities? Are vendor-managed inventories a solution for weak inventory management skills in pharmacies and clinics? Should drones be used to perform medicine deliveries? In what contexts should one use mobile (i.e., travelling) healthcare providers instead of traditional health facilities? How to screen for epidemic outbreaks?

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/99212,2021,Health Economics,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['prof.dr. FT Schut', 'prof.dr. WBF Brouwer', 'R van Gestel, MA']",,"Inhoud

This course will introduce students to economic analysis of health and health care. The health care sector is a more and more important sector of the economy, with health care expenditures having reached 10% of GDP in most OECD countries. The performance of health care systems still has a lot to benefit from sound economic analysis. We will start by addressing the question of what makes health care a different economic good. The special features of health care mean that the standard economic tools are not sufficient to study its demand and supply. We will learn the main economic models that have been developed to analyse these issues. This course will also provide an introduction to economic evaluation of health care. This area of health economics provides information on which products - health care interventions - should be provided for consumption by patients, by weighing the costs and benefits of various alternatives. In many instances, such information is now required for new technologies to get access to the health care market. Questions that will be addressed include:
• Do doctors induce unnecessary demand for their services?
• Can poor people pay for their own health insurance?
• Should health insurance premia depend on how (un)healthy people are?
• Do poor people in developed and developing countries have access to the health care services they need?
• How to determine the value/utility that people attach to health?
• What health care services should be included in the basic insurance package?
• To become acquainted with the discipline of Health Economics.
• Understand the major theories in this field.
• Understand the main empirical work in this field.
• Know main methods used to help decision makers choose the most efficient treatments.
• To be able to apply basics of methods for economic evaluation of health care.
• To be able to understand and critically assess published studies in health economics.

• The assignments count for 30% and consist of group presentations of articles during which students are asked to critically assess the article and answer a number of questions, received in advance (20%). The remaining 10% is based on class participation.
• The mark of the exam should be at least 5.5.
• If a small number of students fail the examination, the re-examination will be oral, instead of written.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/102086,2021,Health Economics,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,[""prof.dr. OA O'Donnell""]",,"Inhoud
Instructors: Prof. O.A. O’Donnell (EUR) and Prof. M. Lindeboom (VU)

Health is an important dimension of wellbeing. Its value is evident from our willingness in high-income countries to spend around 9 percent of GDP on healthcare. And in the US, almost twice this fraction of income is spent on healthcare. Health economics examines whether the level of health spending is efficient and its distribution is fair. It is also concerned with how to finance this spending to strike the right balance between efficiency and equity. Less obviously perhaps, economics can be used to explain variation in health itself by viewing health behaviour as resulting from constrained optimisation of either a fully rational agent or one that is prone to psychological biases. In addition to explaining health behaviour, economics examines the influence of health on economic behaviour and outcomes. Current circumstances make it all too evident that economic activity is highly contingent on population health.

This course covers some of these health-related applications of economics. The first session examines health inequality. We evaluate the success of economic theory and empirical methods in explaining differences in health by education, wealth and income. The second session considers effects of health on economic behaviour and outcomes. While the research discussed in the first two sessions seeks to explain phenomena, the third session turns to research with a prescriptive purpose: the design of policies to control communicable diseases and prevent non-communicable ones. The fourth session switches attention from health to the financing of healthcare
column2: specifically, the efficiency of health insurance, and its potential contribution to the much higher spending on healthcare in the US.

column1: The fifth session examines the hypothesis that health and economic outcomes in adult life and old age are the result of long run mechanisms that originate very early in life. The penultimate session examines socioeconomic determinants of a major cause of ill-health – smoking – while the last session considers the impact of work and retirement on health.
By the end of the course, students will have the ability to:
1. comprehend models and empirical methods used in health economics research,
2. apply economic analysis to understand health behaviour and effects of health on economic behaviour and outcomes,
3. appraise the validity of evidence on causal relationships between health and socioeconomic factors,
4. use economics to evaluate the efficiency and equity of health policies, including the financing of healthcare,
5. make a cogent critique of health economics research,
6. present a concise, clear written argument related to a health phenomenon or policy founded on economic analysis with reference to relevant evidence from health economics research.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/98487,2021,Health Psychology and Behavior Change,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['A Mamede Soares Braga, MSc', 'dr. I Merkelbach', 'dr. PL Kocken', 'prof.dr. S Denktas', 'S Shagiwal, MSc']",,"Inhoud

In this course students will learn how they can use psychological theories to design and evaluate effective interventions. Together with our experts, they will take on the challenge to analyse, investigate and solve complex behavioral problems. They will start with exploring how psychological processes are linked to behaviors, and how they can use these insights to design interventions that change targeted behaviors and promote healthier choices.

The course will explore how psychological, behavioral and sociocultural factors influence health. The course will investigate how some of the most relevant societal challenges and health problems (e.g. behaviors related to infectious diseases, obesity, cancer) can be tackled through behavior change interventions. The course will give students the opportunity to apply the Behavior Change Wheel (BCW) for developing effective behavioral change interventions. This implies that, besides learning about behavior change theories, students will get hands-on experience with the steps involved in developing behavior change interventions to tackle current health problems.

• Students will learn about theories on health psychology and behavior change and their applications in daily practice in weekly lectures. A series of show-cases from practice will be presented on a variety of topics, such as promoting healthy eating in school canteens, physical activity at work, prevention of sexual harassment and management of addictive behaviors.

• During the workshops, students will practice techniques of designing interventions. The steps of the BCW will be central. Experts will present examples of interventions and the ins and outs of design and implementation. The examples will focus on healthy eating in the first half of the workshops and on physical activity in the second half.
• The workshops will be rich on assignments taken from practice on which student work together using interactive learning activities.

Upon completion of the course students should have provided evidence of being able to demonstrate a sophisticated, in-depth, and critical understanding of theory, assessment and intervention regarding psychological approaches to health. They are also able to critically and creatively evaluate current issues, research and advanced scholarship in the area of psychological approaches to health.</body>
At the end of this course you will be able to...
• Outline the magnitude of a public health problem with available evidence from recognized resources.
• Identify from the available evidence what health risk factors, behavioral determinants, and sociocultural factors influence public health problems.
• Distinguish theories and models of health behavior
• Estimate behavior change theories and techniques in public health by addressing their strengths and limitations.
• Argue the challenges of behavior change interventions and policies to intervene in the public health problems in today's society.
• Apply the Behavior Change Wheel framework for developing effective behavior change interventions (BCIs) to tackle current health problems.
• Systematically design a behavior change intervention based on theory and empirical evidence, and professionally and convincingly present the intervention proposal, both oral and in writing.
• Critically judge scientific publications in the field of behavior change and its effect studies, accounting for methodological rigor, theoretical soundness, and relevance.
• Distinguish stakeholders in the field of public health and analyze their aims and counterarguments concerning behavior change interventions.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100416,2021,Health Psychology: Intervention Design for Health Behaviour Change,Engels,Erasmus University College,,[],,Inhoud

Why do people smoke, refuse vaccination, have unsafe sex, eat unhealthily and are physically inactive despite the health risks? How can we help individuals, communities and societies to live healthier and maintain these behaviours to prevent illness? In this course, we will explain how health psychology can be used to address behaviours that can affect our health. We will do this by (1) explaining how biological, psychological, and sociocultural factors contribute to physical, mental, and social wellbeing, and by (2) exploring health promotion intervention design in a hands-on manner, using the intervention mapping approach. This course is about theory, evidence, practical applications and a glimpse into the real-world.
<body>Upon completion of this course, you should be able to:
<li>Understand the reasons underlying the emergence of health psychology
<li>Have a basic understanding of the public health consequences of hypertension, diabetes, and sexually transmitted diseases
<li>Understand the determinants of health behaviour and identify effective methods of promoting behaviour change and healthier lifestyles
<li>Understand the main health risks and positive health behaviours that are relevant to the population at large
<li>Understand the role of health behaviours for determining health outcomes
<li>Become familiar with behaviour change theories in public health
<li>Identify trends in research about the evidence based clinical behaviour of health care professionals
<li>Discuss the role of theories and techniques of behaviour change
<li>Learn from the experiences of a GP working in the South of Rotterdam
<li>Understand sociocultural differences of health and illness
<li>Become familiar with a theoretical framework to understand cultural differences and similarities
<li>Apply behaviour change theories to design a pilot intervention focused on hypertension/diabetes/sexual and reproductive health
• Appreciate the challenges and opportunities associated with running an intervention in the field.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/101928,2021,Health Service Operations Management,Engels, Nederlands",Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,"['dr. S Sülz', 'dr.ir. SG Elkhuizen', 'prof.dr.ir. CTB Ahaus', 'prof.dr.ir. JMH Vissers']",,"Inhoud

Health Service Operations Management (HSOM) can be defined as the analysis, design, planning and control of all steps necessary to deliver services to clients in healthcare. We use methods and techniques that originate from manufacturing but have been adapted to service industries and health services.

The aim of the course is to make the students familiar with the basic concepts, methods and techniques of health service operations management and to enable them to apply these concepts to services in healthcare. We will focus on the development of health service operations management as a field of research, its relevance to develop and improve health services and on the basic concepts of health service operations management. We will use Operations Management theory and concepts for the operations management of individual units within health service provider organizations (e.g. a ward) and for the operations management of care pathways (e.g. mamma cancer diagnosis and treatment) and care chains (e.g. stroke services).

Furthermore we will discuss the concepts underlying Focused Factory, Lean Management, Six Sigma, Business Process Redesign and Theory of Constraints as these are popular approaches in operations management used in continuous improvement of processes in health services. All topics will be introduced in lectures and put into practice in workgroups. Quantitative analyses (with Excel) will be part of both the working group assignments and the individual assignment. To prepare, test and update your Excel knowledge, a formative test in excel is available on the website (Excel skills).
Language: The workgroups for ZoMa are in Dutch, lectures and working groups for HCM are in English. Exams are in English, but ZoMa students are allowed to answer questions in Dutch.
• The student can apply definitions, concepts and methods of Health Service Operations Management.
• The student can perform quantitative analyses with Excel.
• The student can analyse the performance of health service delivery systems.
• The student can apply concepts of HSOM to evaluate and improve services for healthcare delivery.
• The student can provide support for solutions suggested, based on the theory of health service operations management.
• The student can work together in groups to analyse and evaluate and create solutions for health service operations management problems and present the results.

<div>The course focuses on the question: How can organizations develop and evaluate innovative services in health care. The course provides an introduction to innovation science. Innovation science is interdisciplinary
column2: it combines knowledge from the field of economics, sociology, change management and organizational sciences. Specific questions we will address in this course are: How to develop an innovation? What is the value of specific innovations? What impact do technologies have on clinical practice? Why do certain innovations emerge while others do not? How can you evaluate an innovation (is it better compared to what, who, whom)?

column1: In this course students are asked to participate in an innovation contest (comparable to the Dutch Health Care innovation Award) and develop their own innovation based on a real problem of a healthcare organization. The examination of the course represents all elements of innovation and implementation processes. Students are asked to write a proposal for an innovation, to present this proposal to both health care professionals, managers and board members and to review an innovation proposal

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/101949,2021,Health Technology Assessment,Engels,Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,['dr. A van Dongen - Leunis', 'dr. HM Blommestein', 'dr. MA Koopmanschap', 'dr. P Wetzelaer', 'dr. WF Thielen', 'H Mokri', 'prof.dr. MPMH Rutten - van Molken', 'SS Bour', 'YH Chen, MSc']",,"Inhoud

Although patients demand access to all health care programmes available, the scarcity of resources necessitates that choices have to be made. Given that health is such an important matter and that choices usually have far reaching consequences for individuals, the choices require careful consideration, preferably based on transparent and unbiased data. Health Technology Assessment is a multidisciplinary research area closely related to health economics. HTA research attempts to examine the short- and long-term consequences (e.g. health effects and costs) of new and existing health care programs. This is done in a systematic and consistent way in order to provide evidence for the relative cost-effectiveness of health care programs. Policy makers in health care are increasingly using the results of these studies in making choices on priorities in health care.
In this course you will learn how to perform and critically review a HTA.
By the end of the course students can:
- describe the structure and the objectives of HTA/economic evaluation studies.
- perform the 6 steps of an economic evaluation study.
- describe and discuss the inclusion, measurement and valuation of future costs, productivity costs, informal care and outcomes beyond the QALY in economic evaluations
- explain advantages and disadvantages of various quality of life instruments and can discuss when and how individual instruments should be used.
- explain the relationship between several economic theories and the differences in operationalization of key concepts in economic evaluation studies.
- perform and interpret cost- and cost-effectiveness calculations including analysis of uncertainty with a decision tree and a Markov disease model and reflect upon the design and quality of studies.
- critically discuss the inclusion of economic evaluations&nbsp
column2: among other policy ingredients in policy reimbursement decisions of new health care interventions.

column1: - explain the difficulties of transferring outcomes of economic evaluations across jurisdictions.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/101942,2021,Healthcare Ethics,Engels, Nederlands",Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,"['dr. CM Dieteren', 'dr. KJ Grit', 'dr. MA Koopmanschap', 'prof.mr.dr. MAJM Buijsen']",,"Inhoud

Conflicts and dilemmas in healthcare are rarely merely technical problems. They tend to have profound moral dimensions which are often overlooked. Policy-advisors as well as managers need to be sensitive to the moral aspects of conflicts and dilemmas occurring in healthcare. Sensibility for the moral side of problems (in healthcare as well as anywhere else) is not self-evident. It is something which must be acquired. In addition, moral problems are also problems which can be solved. Moral reasoning is something that can be learned.

The course introduces students to moral philosophy. What is morality? What constitutes a moral dilemma? Why be moral? Is there truth in morality? What qualifies an act morally? What constitutes moral character? Following these meta-ethical questions, the course surveys major normative ethical theories (including utilitarianism, rights theory and virtue theory), describes methods of moral justification in healthcare ethics, addresses the problem of moral status and agency (what rights people are due, and when) and examines the moral characteristics of the basic relationships (e.g. professionals-patients and clients) inherent to healthcare.

Drawing from contemporary research, case studies and real-life examples, students will learn how the fundamental moral principles of autonomy, benevolence and justice can be expanded to apply to various conflicts and dilemmas in healthcare, from whether or not to withhold or withdraw life-sustaining treatments, to such diverse issues as the legislation of organ donation (opt-in or opt-out?), euthanasia and fulfilled lives, life style choices, access to collectively financed healthcare and solidarity, and expensive drugs and the worth of human life.

At the end of the course, students will have learned that the reasoning typical of the disciplines constituting health sciences, such as (health) economics and (health) law, are but different ways to approach normative problems in healthcare, that there is a common (ethical) language, and that there is a way to include them all when faced with such problems.

In interactive lectures students will be made familiar with the basics of philosophical ethics, healthcare ethics and moral reasoning. In the seminars the theory will be put to practice. During the course students will apply the same method of moral reasoning to a variety of moral problems in healthcare in ever smaller groups. Finally, the individual student is expected to write an essay, providing a moral question of his or her choice, but approved by the staff, by the best possible answer, in the way taught in the seminars.
• The student acquires knowledge and an understanding of the basics of moral philosophy
• The student acquires knowledge and an understanding of the basics of health care ethics
• The student acquires basic moral reasoning skills
• The student is able to apply basic moral reasoning skills to real-life moral dilemmas in healthcare
• The student engages actively in moral discussions
• The student is able to hold a moral position convincingly, expressed in a well-written essay, based on well-researched arguments and sound logic

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/101943,2021,Healthcare Ethics,Engels,Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,['dr. J Weenink', 'dr. KJ Grit', 'dr. MA Koopmanschap', 'dr. VT Reckers - Droog', 'prof.mr.dr. MAJM Buijsen']",,"Inhoud

Conflicts and dilemmas in healthcare are rarely merely technical problems. They tend to have profound moral dimensions which are often overlooked. Policy-advisors as well as managers need to be sensitive to the moral aspects of conflicts and dilemmas occurring in healthcare. Sensibility for the moral side of problems (in healthcare as well as anywhere else) is not self-evident. It is something which must be acquired. In addition, moral problems are also problems which can be solved. Moral reasoning is something that can be learned.

The course introduces students to moral philosophy. What is morality? What constitutes a moral dilemma? Why be moral? Is there truth in morality? What qualifies an act morally? What constitutes moral character? At the end of the course, students will have learned that the reasoning typical of the disciplines constituting health sciences, such as (health) economics and (health) law, are but different ways to approach normative problems in healthcare, that there is a common (ethical) language, and that there is a way to include them all when faced with such problems.

In interactive lectures students will be made familiar with the basics of philosophical ethics, healthcare ethics and moral reasoning. In the seminars the theory will be put to practice. During the course students will apply the same method of moral reasoning to a variety of moral problems in healthcare in ever smaller groups. Finally, the individual student is expected to write an essay, providing a moral question of his or her choice, but approved by the staff, by the best possible answer, in the way taught in the seminars.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100686,2021,Healthcare Procurement & Value Chain Management,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof.dr.ir. EM van Raaij'],,"Inhoud

<span style=""font-size:9pt"">In this course we will focus on the procurement process and on value chain management in the healthcare sector. In many countries, healthcare represents one of the largest sectors of the economy
column2: healthcare spend often amounts to 10% of a country’s GDP.&nbsp
column3: This course builds on the key concepts as taught in the core course Purchasing &amp
column4: Supply Management (BM05SCM). This course expands into areas that are not only relevant in healthcare, but also in other sectors, such as services triads, performance-based contracting, best value procurement, European tendering, cooperative purchasing, and negotiation skills.&nbsp

column1: In healthcare value chains two types of purchasing can be distinguished: purchasing of healthcare and purchasing for healthcare. In purchasing of healthcare, which is done by for instance healthcare insurers, ‘healthcare’ is the service that is purchased. In purchasing for healthcare a diverse set of goods and services is purchased (e.g. catering, temporary
A significant amount of money is spent in the healthcare industry on a yearly basis, which makes that there is a large potential for the purchasing profession to decrease spend, improve quality
column2: and increase innovation as well as efficiency. In this course we connect management theory about purchasing with specific characteristics of the healthcare industry.&nbsp

column1: Students will get to understand the role that purchasing plays within and between healthcare&nbsp
column3: and the different ways in which purchasing can contribute to the overall performance of a healthcare&nbsp
column5: and/or a healthcare system. Upon completing this course, students:&nbsp

column1: <li>Can explain the importance of professional purchasing and supply management to create value in healthcare systems and justify why high purchasing maturity is important
<li>Understand the role that incentives play in buyer-supplier relationships and evaluate which incentives are appropriate to create value in such relationships
<li>Understand the importance of supplier relationship management and compare the advantages and disadvantages of different types of supplier relationships
<li>Understand the importance of business and board alignment and justify how to achieve such alignment
<li>Can describe the forms and advantages of horizontal purchasing collaboration and evaluate when purchasing collaboration can help to create value
<li>Understand the principles of the EU regulations on public procurement and evaluate how such regulations impact purchasing for care and purchasing of care
<li>Can articulate a question for a guest lecturer based on their knowledge of purchasing of care and purchasing for care

<li>Can apply their knowledge of purchasing of care and purchasing for care to cases of real healthcare organizations, diseases/conditions, and/or patient groups, and create an argumentation how purchasing and supply management can deliver value in that case.&nbsp

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/101936,2021,Healthcare Procurement & Value Chain Management,Engels, Nederlands",Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,['prof.dr.ir. EM van Raaij'],,"Inhoud

Health care providers are dependent on suppliers for the production and delivery of the services they provide to their customers. In the same vein, health care financers (such as health insurers) are dependent on the health care providers to supply health care services to their clients. In both cases, the purchasing function has the responsibility to secure external inputs (goods, services, knowledge, people) from the suppliers against the best possible conditions.

In the health care supply chain, we distinguish between purchasing of health care and purchasing for health care. When we speak of purchasing of health care, the health care is the product that is purchased (e.g., care or cure purchased by health insurers). When we speak of purchasing for health care, we are looking at a broad spectrum of goods and services needed by health care providers, such as medical devices, temporary labor, catering, and much more. Health care represents a considerable portion of public (and private) spending, and therefore, various entities (such as the WHO, as well as the Dutch NZa and RVS) are pointing towards professional purchasing management as a possible contributor to cost containment, quality improvement, innovation, and productivity enhancement in the health care sector.
In this course, we connect management theory in the area of purchasing and supply management to the specific characteristics of the health care sector.
<li style=""text-align:justify"">Can explain the importance of professional purchasing and supply management to create value in healthcare systems
<li style=""text-align:justify"">Understand the role that incentives play in buyer-supplier relationships
<li style=""text-align:justify"">Understand the importance of supplier relationship management and know the advantages and disadvantages of different types of supplier relationships
<li style=""text-align:justify"">Understand the importance of alignment between purchasing and medical professionals and how to achieve such alignment
<li style=""text-align:justify"">Can describe the forms and advantages of horizontal purchasing collaboration
<li style=""text-align:justify"">Understand the principles of the EU regulations on public procurement and how such regulations impact purchasing for care and purchasing of care
<li style=""text-align:justify"">Can articulate a question for a guest lecturer based on their knowledge of purchasing of care and purchasing for care

• Can apply their knowledge of purchasing of care and purchasing for care to cases of real healthcare organizations, diseases/conditions, and/or patient groups, and create an argumentation how purchasing and supply management can create value in that case.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/101063,2021,Heffingen lokale overheden,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['mr. A Schoneveld', 'mr. FJHL Makkinga', 'prof.mr.dr. AW Schep']",,"Inhoud
Het vak Heffingen lokale overheden behandelt de gemeentelijke belastingen en retributies en plaatst dit specialistische vakgebied in perspectief ten opzichte van het gehele fiscale stelsel.

Daarbij is, naast kennis van de lokale belastingen, die veelal een geheel eigen karakter hebben, ook inzicht in de structuur van dit nog steeds groeiende belastinggebied van belang. De verbondenheid van de belastingverordeningen dient kritisch te kunnen worden beoordeeld. Gegeven de veelvuldige wijzigingen (ook in dit deel van het belastingrecht) dient inzicht te worden verkregen in de materiële gevolgen van implementatie van nieuwe regelgeving, waaronder het steeds bredere gebruik van de WOZ-waarde, bijvoorbeeld in de inkomstenbelasting en in de vennootschapsbelasting (de beperking van de afschrijving op gebouwen ingevolge de Wet Werken aan Winst).
Heffingen lokale overheden richt zich op&nbsp
column2: een uitwerking van diverse belastingen en rechten die gemeenten, provincies en waterschappen heffen, alsmede op de Wet waardering onroerende zaken, haar uitvoeringsregels en de taxatiemethoden.

column1: Daarnaast komt de toepassing van rechtsbeginselen in ruime mate aan bod, zoals de werking van het gelijkheidsbeginsel en het evenredigheidsbeginsel.</body>

column2: kennis en inzicht in de grondslagen en beginselen van het lokale belastingrecht alsmede de verhouding van dit belastingrecht tot andere rechtsgebieden
grondige kennis en inzicht in de essentialia van de lokale belastingen en retributies, alsmede in de werking van de Wet WOZ
het gelijkheids- en het evenredigheidsbeginsel toepassen op de lokale belastingen en retributies, alsmede andere rechts- en fiscale beginselen toepassen
kennis en inzicht in de totstandkoming en inhoud van verordeningen en lokale belastingen, alsmede in de heffing en invordering van deze heffingen

column2: juridische teksten, waaronder wetgeving (mede hieronder begrepen verdragen), jurisprudentie en wetenschappelijke literatuur begrijpen, analyseren en kritisch beoordelen

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100081,2021,Heritage and Fashion,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['J Quak', 'prof.dr. B Wubs']",,"Inhoud

The fashion industry is a paradigmatic sector of post-industrial economies, whose products increasingly rely on symbolic and aesthetic considerations as well as on local heritage and specificities. The fashion industry revolves around a myriad of key locations around the world, yet this has been the case for an extended period of time. A polycentric geography of fashion emerged, integrating traditional
column3: digital technologies. Some luxury brands, such as Louis Vuitton, are even engaging with blockchain to prove the authenticity of their products. Topics covered in the course, among others: place, space and heritage in the fashion industry, storytelling, craftsmanship, temporary fashion clusters, and policies for fashion. In particular, storytelling appears to be an important tool for the fashion industry due to the necessity to differentiate the various products or brands and to add emotional value to them. Heritage and tradition are at the core of storytelling. Even new fashion products and brands are imbued with a historical flavor and sense of legendary quality, with the help of storytelling and revived craftsmanship. Given the rise of sustainability concerns, storytelling and craftsmanship, and in general heritage, are gaining momentum for the fashion industry and other creative industries too.

column10: Students have a thorough knowledge and understanding of how the fashion industry and heritage are intertwined.
Students can analyze the place, space, and heritage of the fashion industry from business history and cultural economics perspectives.
Students are able to present and discuss the results of their analysis with peers and with fashion stakeholders.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/101886,2021,Het (moderne en postmoderne) subject: tussen autonomie en determinisme,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['prof.dr. RBJM Welten'],,Inhoud

Het moderne subject als autonoom en rationeel individu werd geboren in de gedachten van Descartes en Kant, zo wordt beweerd. Maar tijdens de 20e eeuw tot heden trekken veel filosofen de vrijheid, rationaliteit en coherentie van het subject in twijfel. Is het subject wel zo autonoom en vrij als het meent te zijn? Is het wel wat het denkt dat het is? In welke mate zijn we bepaald door de maatschappelijke, culturele, economische en politieke aard?

In deze cursus zullen we nagaan hoe het huidige beeld van de mens als een autonoom, rationeel individu zich heeft ontwikkeld en op welke grenzen het stuit. We bespreken klassieke teksten uit de subjectfilosofie en analyseren de kritiek aan deze posities van denkers uit de 20e en 21e eeuw waaronder Freud, Kierkegaard, Camus, Sartre, De Beauvoir, Barthes, Lacan en Žižek. Daarbij zal duidelijk worden dat niet enkel het concept van het subject, maar ook het filosofische denken zelf altijd ingebed ligt in omstandigheden van maatschappelijke, culturele en politieke aard en dat die elkaar over en weer beïnvloeden.</body>
De werkcolleges zijn verplicht voor voltijdstudenten Filosofie.

Aan het einde van de cursus heeft de student/e inzicht in de verschillende concepten van het subject via de wordingsgeschiedenis daarvan en de kritische uiteenzettingen daarmee in de moderne tijd. Ze/hij is in staat om de argumenten in de behandelde teksten te identificeren en samen te vatten. Zij/hij geeft een onderbouwde redenering over de deugdelijkheid van de genoemde kritiekpunten (die gericht zijn tegen het concept van een autonoom een rationeel subject).

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/102486,2021,Het Hybride Nieuwslandschap,Nederlands,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. BCM Kester', 'dr. RA Harder']",,"Inhoud

Meer dan ooit zijn media met elkaar verweven. Het medialandschap van vandaag kan worden gekarakteriseerd als hybride, een situatie waarbij 'oude' en 'nieuwe' medialogica's naast elkaar bestaan en met elkaar in botsing komen. Deze botsingen tussen verschillende vormen van media leiden tot zowel versmelting als differentiatie. De podcast is bijvoorbeeld een relatief nieuw platform dat alleen kan bestaan dankzij het internet, maar het draagt tegelijkertijd eigenschappen van ‘oude’ media als boeken en radio in zich. Het heeft dus een hybride vorm. Ook in de nieuwsvoorziening zijn deze mengvormen gemeengoed, met de liveblog als meest typische voorbeeld. De opkomst hiervan kan niet los gezien worden het succes van Twitter, maar naast deze sociale-medialogica komen hierbij ook elementen uit bijvoorbeeld de papieren krant, televisie, en radio terug.

In deze research workshop leggen we dit fenomeen onder een vergrootglas. We bespreken hoe we de verwevenheid tussen verschillende media theoretisch kunnen duiden, en bekijken via empirisch onderzoek hoe dit tot uiting komt in de inhoud en/of publiekservaring.</body>
• De rol van mediaplatformen in de nieuwsvoorziening van vandaag
• Onderzoeksmethoden die passen bij het onderzoek naar hybriditeit
• De manier waarop wetenschappelijke concepten zich ontwikkelen
• Een theoretisch kader te ontwikkelen en hier een relevante onderzoeksvraag aan te verbinden
• De probleemstelling via een kleinschalig empirisch onderzoek uit te werken en de onderzoeksresultaten helder te rapporteren
• Kritisch te reflecteren op het eigen onderzoek

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/102147,2021,Heuristic Optimization Methods,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,[],,Inhoud

Heuristics form an indispensable tool for everyone working in operations management because problems arising from practice are often too hard to solve exactly and heuristics are relatively simple methods that may provide feasible solutions of good quality. The course is about heuristics to solve general problems but uses logistics optimization problems such as the vehicle routing problem as examples of specific implementations. The field of routing is in fact so rich that virtually all published heuristic ideas have been applied to it. The course is further divided into two parts, each of which first covers general problems and then focuses on routing:
• Classical heuristics to construct a feasible solution and improvement heuristics based on structured local search
• All methods will be illustrated through actual implementations in high level language.

column2: margin-right:0px"">By the end of the course, students will be able to:

column3: >Identify problems which will require heuristics for their solution
column4: identify the most appropriate heuristic for the solution of a problem.

column3: >Discuss the characteristics of the main heuristici techniques by considering their efficiency and effectiveness
column4: develop implementations of heuristics for optimization and vehicle routing problems.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100658,2021,High Performance Leadership,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. TIN Davidson'],,"Inhoud

Leaders are key players in organizational functioning because they critically affect the people they work with—both inside and outside of their organization. Leaders are in a unique position to mobilise employees to excel and contribute to the organisation’s mission and vision. At the same time, however, they may also be a primary source of conflict and demotivation. Understanding what makes for high performance leadership as well as where leadership can go wrong, therefore, is of critical importance to any aspiring leader
column2: and in particular for HR professionals who may come to take the lead of the HR organization, as well as facilitate the process of leadership in their organization.&nbsp

column1: In this course, we address one key question: “what makes an effective leader?” from a range of different theoretical perspectives (e.g., social identity, visionary leadership) and cast in the context of contemporary workplace trends (e.g., demographic change, digitization). Through a sequence of readings, lectures, cases, and experiential exercises, students learn to understand and apply state-of-the-art leadership theories, analyse and evaluate the determinants of leadership successes and failures, as well as apply these learnings to make recommendations for real-world leadership challenges.&nbsp
Upon completion of the course, you should be able to:
• Understand and apply the state-of-the art theories in leadership (i.e., vision communication, identity-based leadership)
• Analyze and evaluate the determinants of leadership successes and failure
• Communicate theoretically sound and practically relevant recommendations for “better” leadership in a persuasive manner
• Practice and develop your leadership through self-awareness, application, and reflection.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/102655,2021,High-Performance Brain Simulation,Engels,Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC),,"['dr. D. Jaarsma', 'E. Buitenhuis - Linssen', 'L.M.R. Nijs - de Langen']",,

The discipline of sociology was established during (and to make sense of) the process of modernisation. A core characteristic of modernisation is rapid social change, and sociology theorises and studies such changes by comparing traditional societies to modern societies. The perspectives that were developed and the topics addressed by the founders of the discipline are still relevant today, because they regard issues as socioeconomic inequality, social order and deviance, the role of religion and ideology, gender relations, what it means to live in an urbanised world, the relation of individuals with society. In this course we learn about these classic perspectives by looking at contemporary societies. We will learn to apply the ‘sociological imagination’ to everyday life as well as study the classic sociological questions using present-day cases. Assessment consists of a final exam and an essay.

After this course, students will be able to describe and apply the three most important sociological perspectives (functionalism, conflict sociology, symbolic interactionism) to issues such as modernization, inequality, cohesion and individualization.
In addition, students are able to reproduce the meaning of and theory formation around the following key concepts: Scientific paradigms

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100069,2021,Historical Culture in a Globalising World,Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. RJ Adriaansen', 'J Quak']",,"Inhoud

The past is not simply gone. It permeates people's lives through memory and imagination, and offers an orientation in time. Telling stories about what happened in the past plays a key role in the construction of personal and collective identities. Creating a historical narrative through emplotment means establishing a sequence of selected historical events that makes the events meaningful to a contemporary audience in a specific way. Historical narratives fuel calls to action of social and political movements. Tragic stories of historical injustices support calls for reparations or for emancipation. Governments go to great lengths to control historical narration and interpretation to legitimize the political entities they govern, or to legitimize their policies. Also individuals historicize their own lives through narration in order to deal with expected and unexpected challenges and opportunities.

A central concept to understand these and similar processes is historical culture. The concept refers to historical narratives and performances, to the infrastructure of the historical field which makes it possible for people to deal with past, and to different conceptions of history that enable historical imagination.

This course provides theoretical reflection on historical culture and discusses methods of analyzing narrative plotlines. We will study several cases, such as the narrative scripts of historical reconciliation committees, the politics of descent in political speeches, and the destruction of cultural heritage.
• Students can explain the meaning of the concept historical culture
• Students can analyze transformations in cultural and political attitudes towards the past
• Students can defend a theoretically and empirically informed position in contemporary memory debates

The term Creative Industries is a relatively recent concept coined in the late 1990s by new labour in Britain. Ever since this contested concept has evolved into an important policy instrument of national and local governments, the European Union, and United Nations, as well as a lively academic discourse. The workshop aims to historicize the concept and explore the historical roots of the creative industries and aims to analyse different sectors of the industry, including fashion, art markets, film, radio, television, music, design, theatre, tourism and video games. Furthermore, this course looks at innovations within large and small firms and networks across a range of industries. It explores the role of institutions and organizations, in particular governments or similar gatekeeping structures, and the diversity of innovation processes and across different sectors of the economy in the long twentieth century. Finally, it focuses on the effects of innovation and creativity on economic growth, international competitiveness, and employment. Different theoretical approaches emphasising cultural, national, regional, local, and firm-based factors, will be explored and applied to case studies selected by the students.
Further information at the Thesis Market in October
• Students can adequately and efficiently structure and conduct historical research
• Students can critically assess and discuss the research design, data collection and methodology of their master’s thesis
• Students can analyse, report and present their research findings
• Students can present their ideas and work- in-progress
• Students can constructively comment on the research of their peers

This course starts with an overview of the major founders of the social sciences (Adam Smith, Karl Marx, Emile Durkheim and Max Weber). These early social scientists assume that the rise of modernity around 1800 was a milestone in world history. They believe that early modern society was profoundly transformed by industrialisation, secularisation, democratisation and urbanisation. This particular view on historical developments is heavily criticised by historians, because of its Eurocentric, deterministic and teleological approach. However, these theories still offer an interesting starting-point for historical research, because modernisation theories laid the foundation of our modern, western self-awareness and is still frequently used to explain global historical developments. Some of the twentieth-century elaborations of these early social theories are discussed in this course. A critical reflection on current developments is also part of this course.

Students learn to identify and recognise similarities and differences between social sciences and history. They can define some key concepts of the social sciences and place them in their historical context. They can explain and critically analyse modernisation theories. They can connect social theory with empirical research based on historical sources.

This course deals with constructs of culture and of cultural difference in modern history within the context of European, European expansion and colonial order as well of in the context of diaspora and migration. Principal concepts such as “culture” and “identity” “nationality” and “citizenship” will be critically reviewed, tracing its uses in the various contexts. The following twin notions will be dealt with: culture-identity, difference-equality, majority-minority, native-migrant, insiders-outsiders, hyperdiversity-uniformity.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100031,2021,History of Early Modern Societies,Engels, Nederlands","Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['DLA Velthuizen - Velthuizen, MA', 'dr. JC Nierstrasz', 'dr. JW Schaap']",,"Inhoud

<div>In the early modern period, Western societies set their first steps towards modernity. In this process, they ultimately set off on a path diverging from the rest of the world. Most historians will agree on this part of the story, but it is still under debate how, why and when this divergence started. Did it&nbsp
column4: start with the American war of independence, the French Revolution and the Industrial Revolution or had the wheels of change already been set in motion long before? Did Europe feel born again as it set out to discover the unknown after the Plague? Were the religious 'dark-ages' eventually&nbsp
column5: enlightened by the Renaissance and reason? And to what extent did international trade provide the inspiration for and precede industrialisation? During this course, it will be critically assessed whether these changes were indigenous to Europe or should be viewed just as much as a result of Europe’s interaction with the rest of the world. In the lectures and tutorials, we will ask ourselves the question if historians have too easily projected their view of the world today on the past, instead of seeing early modern societies as different and unique in their own right.

column1: Students are introduced to the history of early modern societies between 1300 and 1750. They will acquire new insights into the structural changes that took place in Europe and in the wider world during this period. Students are able to analyse historical argumentative texts and use this skill of the so-called structure analysis in producing papers and an oral presentation.

Lectures/seminars provide a general overview of the history of economics, with more detailed analysis of particular issues and problems, the precise coverage sometimes being varied to reflect the interests of those taking the course each year. Students are expected to read recommended materials beforehand, so that the lectures can focus on a discussion of the readings.
Topics likely to be covered (subject to students’ interests) include: Adam Smith, the market and trade

Readings are selected to introduce students to a range of approaches to the subject. For example, Adam Smith is used to show how reading an economist through the lens of modern economics may be to impose ideas foreign to his or her thought
column2: the lecture on Keynes introduces the idea of approaching the history of economics through an economist’s biography. Subsequent lectures give examples of work that debunks myths and which shows how changing philosophical presuppositions can change the way economic arguments are constructed.</body>

column1: By the end of this course, students should be able to:
1) Explain how economic ideas may be influenced by the context in which they arose and may reflect philosophical values and attitudes different from our own.
2) Provide and comment on examples of different approaches to writing the history of economics.

3) Identify and analyse some of the major themes that historians of economics have identified, such as the “marginal” revolution, the transition from interwar pluralism to postwar neoclassical economics, the Keynesian revolution, or the recent turn to applied economics.
4) Explain, using one or more examples, how the historian’s perspective on episodes in the history of economics may differ from that of a modern economist.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/102089,2021,History of Economic Thought,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['prof.dr. RE Backhouse'],,Inhoud

This course offers a short introduction to the history of some important ideas in microeconomics, macroeconomics and empirical methods. A frequent theme will be that the writings of earlier generations of economists were frequently much less naïve than they are often made out to be and, in some cases, economists held views diametrically opposed to those with which they are often associated. For example, Adam Smith did not advocate the unchecked pursuit of self-interest, Maynard Keynes did not attribute unemployment to sticky wages, and Keynesian economists of the 1950s and 1960s well understood the potential for high demand to create accelerating inflation.

Sessions will involve a mixture of lecturing and discussion, and students will be expected to do a limited amount of reading before classes and to participate in discussions. One reason for this is so that students can turn the discussion to topics that interest them. More extensive reading will then be required for assignments, related to their own interest, which in many cases means students’ students’ research interests
column2: the topics for these are worked out in consultation with the teacher.

column1: The coverage can vary according to student demand, but topics that could be covered as part of the core include: the history of general equilibrium theory, game theory and welfare economics
column3: the history of the Phillips curve and DSGE modeling
column4: the history of econometrics and empirical methods.

<body>From the middle of the eighteenth century, the industrial revolution, the spread of Enlightenment ideas and the rise of Romanticism, and the political revolutions in America and France created a structural transformation of Western Europe. A core notion that emerged, and that will serve as our central theme, is the contested idea of progress: the belief that humans are able to understand the world and improve it on the basis of that understanding. Each week we will focus on a specific theme that illustrates this basic idea and its critics. The first week is devoted to the rise of the new interventionist state from Napoleonic France on, the beginning of what would later be called the welfare state. During the second week we will study class conflicts in the nineteenth century, in connection with the increasing internationalization of the economy. Week three is devoted to the crisis of democracies during the interwar period, with a focus on the rise of fascism. In week four we will study the making of the modern material environment, especially the world-wide impact of modernist architecture, design, and city planning.</body>

<body>This course provides an introduction to the history of western societies since 1750. Structural changes in politics, culture and the economy are discussed. In addition, students are trained to close-read and interpret primary sources from this period and to report their findings in oral and written presentations.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/101832,2021,History of Political Thought,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,"['D Rusu', 'dr. B Leeuwenburgh', 'dr. P Schuurman', 'prof.dr. JA van Ruler', 'prof.dr. L van Bunge']",,"Inhoud

Week 1. In intellectual history, few areas have recently been the subject of such intense scrutiny as the history of political thought. During the first week/part of this course the so-called ‘Cambridge School’ will be discussed. Established by eminent practising historians such as Quentin Skinner, J.G.A. Pocock, and John Dunn, it rose to prominence during the 1960s and 1970s, inspiring intellectual historians far beyond political theory.

Week 2. With his enormously influential political philosophy, Plato (c. 427-347) tried to solve the problem of conflicting interests of different parts of society. We will how his quest for harmony produced a detailed vision of an ideal society in The Republic
column2: and we will discuss whether this vision entailed a totalitarian nightmare. Aristotle’s political philosophy revolves around the notion of man as a political animal who needs the political entity of the polis (city-state) in order to realise a happy and virtuous life
column3: we will study Aristotle’s ideas for the best form of government and we will also critically examine his arguments for the inclusion and exclusion for certain specific groups.

column1: Week 3. Though not very well-known for his political standpoints, Desiderius Erasmus’ Philosophy of Christ would form the basis of a standpoint on the ideal society that shares many aspects with what is understood by the rule of law in ‘free’ societies today. His moral conception of politics contrasts sharply to what we find in his friend Thomas More’s famous book on Utopia. Both positions and their intricate interdependence will be addressed. Without any doubt the best-known and most notorious work of the Italian humanist and philosopher Niccolò Machiavelli (1469-1527) is Il Principe (The Prince), first published in 1513. Notorious, because The Prince can be interpreted as a manual for would-be dictators whose goal is to attain and maintain power at all cost. Less notorious and famous, but certainly not less interesting is Machiavelli’s later more elaborate work, especially his Discourses on Livy (1531), where the classical history of ancient Rome forms the background stage of a discussion on how to form and maintain a republic. By comparing both works the students will learn about the basic principles of Machiavelli’s political philosophy.

Week 4. In the 19th century J.S. Mill (1806-1873) is the forefather of modern liberalism and feminism. According to On Liberty (1859) the greatest threat to personal liberty is no longer the state as in classic liberalism, but ‘public opinion’, which enforces conformity. Karl Marx (1818-1883) is the source of both social-democracy and communism. In the Communist Manifesto (1848) he outlines a ‘materialist’ theory of society, which sees society not as an integrated whole, but as a contingent set of conflicting groups (classes), and he links society to economy.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/99937,2021,History of Western Arts and Culture,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['DM Goossens, MA', 'dr. SR Driessen', 'drs. AG van Ham', 'LJLM De Strooper, MA', 'MF Rodriguez Rodriguez']",,"Inhoud

The course History of Western Arts and Culture provides a historical and chronological overview of Western art and culture from the late Middle Ages until the 21st century. Students get acquainted with the major developments in the visual arts, architecture, music, and literature from this period, against a historical background. It is demonstrated how the highlights from these disciplines originate from, reflect, and shape the socio-cultural context of their time, and how these historical developments continue to have their effects on contemporary culture.

History of Western Arts and Culture is intended for first-year students of the International Bachelor Arts and Culture Studies/Algemene Cultuurwetenschappen. The aim is to provide them with a historical and versatile foundation for their further studies. Students will acquire a historical overview of the main developments and trends in Western art and culture, and gain insight into how the various disciplines (visual arts, literature, architecture and music) are interrelated.
column2: Furthermore, students will gain insight into the way in which art comes from, reflects on, and at the same time shapes the socio-cultural context of its time. Finally, students will acquire knowledge on how the position of the artist in relation to fellow artists, clients and the public has developed historically.</body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/99960,2021,History of the Art Market,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['AC Crotta', 'KF Karatas, MA', 'prof.dr. FRR Vermeylen']",,"Inhoud

This course will provide an introduction to the history of the Dutch and European art markets, and the way the art trade functions as an intermediary between artist and audience. Various aspects dealing with the production, distribution and consumption of art will be discussed. Attention will be given - among other topics - to the innovations that were introduced to expand the market for works of art since early modern times. For instance the development and growing importance of art auctions from the seventeenth century until the present will be examined in detail, as well as other more recent developments such as the impact of new media on the art market.
Note: The maximum number of participants is 55.

<body>The course seeks to familiarize the students with the history and functioning of early modern and modern art markets. They will be exposed to the recent findings concerning the socio-economic, but also the cultural and sociological framework in which works of art were and are produced, traded and consumed. An interdisciplinary approach will be pursued in order to gain insight into these phenomena.</body>

column1: History and memory are analytically distinct, but overlapping concepts. The significance of both concepts is closely related to the emergence of nation states and their colonial empires, and to the professionalization of the pursuit of history. In this course we discuss the relationship between history and memory, and how this relationship has changed over time due to fundamental changes in society, such as the French Revolution, the emergence of mass culture, secularization, two world wars, new media, globalization, and transformations in historical scholarship. We will also study specific applications of these concepts in examples of (popular) historical culture, such as the construction of the nation state, heritage and public history.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100038,2021,Honours Class,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. I Gusc', 'dr. MF van Dijck', 'dr. S Bertrand', 'J Quak', 'prof.dr. B Wubs', 'prof.dr. HAM Klemann']",,"Inhoud

Following the political revolutions of the late eighteenth century, the organising role of the state in a society that was no longer based on a hierarchy of orders and estates was fiercely debated in Europe and the United States. This debate was further intensified by the major effects of industrialisation in the English Midlands and subsequently elsewhere in Europe. The ideologies that still frame and inform debates today – conservatism, socialism, liberalism, nationalism and so on – emerged at that time. While industrialisation, economic growth and imperialism led to technological advances and levels of prosperity the likes of which the world had not seen before, they also caused social and environmental disruption on a global scale. Wars caused destruction on an unprecedented scale, social bonds that had defined the fabric of society for centuries were broken and even the biosphere was affected. In the context of seeking solutions to such problems, reference was repeatedly made to the state and, increasingly, also to the need for cooperation between states. The development of this thinking since the eighteenth century is the subject of this course.

The purpose of this course is to study themes that are covered elsewhere in the bachelor’s degree programme in greater depth. Students will be introduced to historical thinkers and their theories regarding the state and the relationship between state and society. Students will develop the ability to place these thinkers and their works in their respective contexts. Students will read primary texts/sources. Students will learn how to independently initiate and structure a meaningful discussion.

Na het afronden van de Honours Class kan je zelfstandig richting geven aan jouw eigen persoonlijke ontwikkeling en hierop reflecteren.
Om dat te bereiken kun je:&nbsp
<li>Leerdoelen opstellen die in lijn zijn met je kernwaarden
<li>Een planning maken waarin je specificeert en beargumenteert welke stappen je onderneemt om je doelen te bereiken, in welke volgorde je dat doet, en welke hulpbronnen je daarbij nodig hebt
<li>Reflecteren op je eigen vooruitgang, zowel wat betreft het maken van producten als het aanleren van vaardigheden
<li>Medestudenten op correcte wijze feedback geven en constructief omgaan met feedback die je van medestudenten krijgt
<li>Een aantrekkelijke presentatie geven aan medestudenten over een studie-gerelateerd onderwerp
<li>Je zelfstandig verdiepen in de onderzoeks-, beleids- en managementaspecten van een zorggerelateerd onderwerp en hier verslag van doen
• Een inhoudelijke bijeenkomst organiseren over een zorg-gerelateerd onderwerp.
De Honours Class is er voor studenten die gemotiveerd zijn om naast de reguliere vakken een verdiepend studieprogramma te volgen.

Je kiest aan het begin van de Honours Class het zorg-gerelateerde onderwerp waar je tijdens de rest van de Honours Class aan werkt. Vervolgens specificeer je leerdoelen – wat wil je over dit onderwerp leren? – en maak je een plan hoe je die doelen gaat bereiken en hoe je door middel van door jou zelf gespecificeerde producten gaat bewijzen dat je de doelen behaald hebt. Uit je leerdoelen en je plan blijkt dat je aandacht hebt voor kennis én voor vaardigheden. Je producten maak je voor jezelf maar ook voor anderen waar je in je studie mee te maken krijgt: van je producten is er minstens een die interessant is voor een onderzoeker, een voor een beleidsmaker en een voor een manager.

The Honours Class Private Equity is an extra-curricular programme that can be followed in addition to the regular programme and tries to increase impact of education by training the application of theory.

In a challenging and demanding learning environment students come into contact with experts from the field in order to be able to directly test the knowledge gained in practice. The program consist of a series of guest lectures and a private equity game in block 2 and 3.
The ambitious extra-curricular program brings together a 24 selected Financial Economics students with an interest in investment in an inspiring and intensive study track.&nbsp
Students know different types of acquisitions in private equity and how these are structured and financed.
Students know fundamental economic theories in corporate finance and and have insight into how these can be applied.
Students know strengths and weaknesses of the use of different types of valuation models and have insight into the context where these can be applied.
Students are able to form an opinion based on different perspectives acquisitions and private equity investment.

This course is open—by invitation only—to IBCoM’s most talented and highly motivated students. Once they are invited to the course, interested students must submit a special application. A limited number of applicants can be accepted in the program.

CM2100 gives excellent students access to opportunities and challenges beyond the normal scope of an undergraduate program. Honours students are exposed to the most recent developments in communication and media studies. Moreover,&nbsp
column2: various and attractive fieldtrips, as well as close contact with professionals, organizations and experts give students the opportunity to witness and, in many cases, actively engage in real life communicative and media practices within public and private institutions. Students’ own contribution in the HP’s curriculum—through engagement in class discussions, presentation of their own work, building of a portfolio and the organization of the honours symposium —further enables them to actively explore new areas of interest.

column1: The course is organized in two modules, and an honours symposium at the end.
• The state of the art in specific areas of communication and media studies beyond the normal scope of the undergraduate curriculum.
• The perspectives of professionals and experts working in media and communication-related industries and organizations.
• Actively explore new areas of interests and participate in the proposal, organization, and preparation of seminar sessions.
• Further their reading, research, writing, and presentation skills.
• Work independently on a research project and publicly report their results.
