https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/98200,2021,Hoogtepunten uit de psychologie,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['prof.dr. AACM Smeets'],,"Inhoud
In deze minor zul je kennismaken met een aantal belangrijke inzichten uit de Psychologie.

<span style=""color:#002328"">De psychologie is een wetenschappelijke discipline die probeert het gedrag, de gedachten, gevoelens en drijfveren van mensen te begrijpen, te verklaren en te voorspellen. Na deze minor&nbsp
column3: zul je beter begrijpen waarom mensen doen wat ze doen. Meer begrip van menselijk gedrag kan buitengewoon relevant zijn voor alle disciplines waar mensen de hoofdrol spelen. Denk bijvoorbeeld aan de economie, de rechtspraak, de bedrijfskunde, de politicologie, maar ook in de bouwkunde of de ICT. We hopen dat de kennis die je in deze minor op doet van toegevoegde waarde is voor je huidige studie. Maar we hopen vooral dat je door meer kennis van de psychologie ook meer kennis van jezelf krijgt.

column1: De psychologie is een enorm vakgebied. Natuurlijk kunnen we in het tijdsbestek van één minor niet alle belangrijke psychologische inzichten met jullie delen. Daarom hebben we een selectie gemaakt van een aantal van de meest tot de verbeelding sprekende theorieën en ontdekkingen. Deze komen onder andere voort uit de sociale psychologie, de persoonlijkheidsleer, de biologische psychologie en de klinische psychologie.
De minor wordt in het Nederlands aangeboden, maar de literatuur is Engelstalig.
Er wordt gewerkt in kleine teams. Studenten zijn van elkaars input en bijdragen afhankelijk. Daarom is aanwezigheid verplicht.
Gedurende de wekelijkse bijeenkomsten krijgt de student feedback van de tutor. Dit kan betrekking hebben op studievoortgang en werkhouding (professioneel gedrag).
<div>Na afronding van deze minor heeft de student basale kennis van een aantal belangrijke psychologische theorieën uit de volgende subdisciplines:
Verder maakt de student kennis met verschillende vormen van psychologisch (wetenschappelijk) onderzoek.
Door de werkvorm van Probleem Gestuurd Onderwijs (PGO) leert de student:
• In kleine groepen met studenten uit verschillende disciplines psychologische problemen te analyseren
• Uit deze probleemanalyse relevante (persoonlijke) leerdoelen te formuleren
• Nieuwe inzichten en kennis terug te koppelen in een multidisciplinair team

In this course, students will look at financial decision-making from the perspective of households and individuals. With rising levels of debt and strained pension systems, there is a need to understand the financial decisions facing households and the way in which firms and policymakers can address these. The course also aims to provide insight into new areas of finance such as fintech which provide new challenges for regulators and opportunities for consumers.
The course aims to provide a framework that students can use to think about financial decision-making as well as apply this knowledge to socially relevant challenges, such as
column3: among economically vulnerable groups. In addition, the course investigates the importance of access to finance around the world and provides some examples of how companies (such as&nbsp
column4: fintechs) are addressing consumer needs in new ways.&nbsp

column1: <li>Students will be able to develop a framework for thinking about household financial decision-making&nbsp

column2: the role of financial products in improving consumer welfare and the financial instruments available to individuals and households&nbsp

column1: <li>Students will be able to use this framework to debate the merits of extending access to financial services (financial inclusion) as well regulation of financial services&nbsp
<li>Students will be able to propose solutions on using technology to help providers of financial products improve consumer well-being&nbsp
<li>Students will better understand the role of access to finance in improving (and worsening) consumer welfare&nbsp

<body>We humans have an irresistible urge to explain our own and others’ behaviour, to attribute it to some causes and therefore, to make it seems orderly, predictable and controllable. Why do we behave, think, and feel as we do in social situations? How are our thoughts, feelings and behaviours shaped by others? How do we make sense of our social world and how do we become social? How do we see ourselves? These are the type of questions that the course Man &amp
column2: Society seeks to address. Obviously, a huge number of variables play a role in answering these questions and many disciplines employ scientific techniques to answer these questions. However, in this course we will try to answer these questions from a socio-psychological perspective and use quantitative research to investigate how and why certain (socio-psychological) behaviours occurred.

column1: This course deals with an important and relevant area of psychology, the social psychology. Social psychology is the scientific field that seeks to understand the nature and causes of individual behaviour in social situations. Social psychologists are interested in underlying social and cognitive processes as they are in overt behaviour. The central theme of social psychology is how people understand and interact with each other.
Upon completion of this course, students should be able to:
<li>Discuss the history and research methods of social psychology
<li>Distinguish between cultures regarding the processes that underlie our thought, behaviour, and feelings in social situations
<li>Apply theoretical concepts of this course in a more practical manner
<li>Identify the components of the self and self-schemas
<li>Define attitudes and how they develop and change
<li>Explain the theories and dynamics of group formation: social categorization and social identity
<li>Understand the antecedents and consequences of stereotyping, prejudice, racism, discrimination, and genocide
<li>Describe evolutionary approaches to helping others and the bystander effect
<li>Understand the way people attach meaning to other’s and their own behavior
<li>Explain the theories of attraction and romantic relationships
• Write a scientifically sound research paper on a particular subtopic from social psychology.

The study of anatomy (and morphology) is crucial in understanding how multiple tissue types and organ systems are organised in multicellular organisms, and how they interact. Moreover, it is not possible to understand how such organisms ‘work’ (as studied in physiology) without having fundamental anatomical knowledge. Clearly, this knowledge is also vital when studying the nature of a disease (pathology) as well as the biological mechanisms that lead to disease (pathogenesis).

In this course, we will focus on the anatomy of humans. You will learn the exact location, three-dimensional orientation and morphology of all major human body parts, and you will learn the correct anatomical language that is required to describe these parts. Particular attention will be given to the cardiovascular, respiratory, gastrointestinal, nervous, and musculoskeletal systems. The course is designed in tight collaboration with the Erasmus MC, and consists of expert lectures, interactive tutorials, and dissection room practicals, which ensure that you will get a practical, hands-on learning experience.
<li>obtain a general understanding of the use and importance of general anatomical nomenclature (in Latin and/or English)
<li>learn to actively use the terms in the anatomy checklist to describe the basic anatomy of the bony skeleton and its joints
<li>be able to relate the dermal and musculoskeletal system of the extremities to its nervous innervation
<li>be able to explain how musculoskeletal system allows the movement and stability of the human body
<li>be able to identify and describe the basic anatomy and functional properties of the anatomy of the thorax
<li>learn how to describe the main characteristics of the human blood circulation and name the main arteries and veins of the human body
<li>be able to identify and describe all the abdominal and pelvic organs and know where they are located in the abdominal and pelvic cavity, respectively
• learn the basic functional anatomy of the human nervous system and head and neck structures.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/101877,2021,Human Conditions I,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['prof.dr. J de Mul'],,"Inhoud
<body>The first part of the course offers a systematic overview of the main subjects &nbsp
column2: and concepts of Philosophical Anthropology (such as the place of man in the Cosmos, the relationship between body and mind, consciousness, action, freedom of will, (inter)subjectivity, reflexivity and language), and its relationship to other philosophical disciplines, such as ethics and social philosophy, and the empirical sciences and humanities, which deal with human beings, such as biological anthropology, neuroscience, psychology, sociology, history, and cultural anthropology.

column1: Next, we will distinguish the mechanistic, organismic, and hermeneutic conception of man and, inspired by Kant’s and Dilthey’s transcendental philosophy, we will analyze the third-person, second-person, and first person ontological perspectives connected to these conceptions. Against the background of the ‘Historization of the World View’, both in its naturalistic (Darwin) and hermeneutic (Dilthey) form, we will discuss Plessner’s philosophical anthropology as a still topical attempt to connect the two. Finally, against this background, will reflect on the possible futures of the human life form in the light of the so-called converging technologies (such as information technology, neuroscience, and biotechnology).</body>

At the end of this course the student understands and can use the key concepts of philosophical anthropology, is able to distinguish the differences between mechanistic, organismic, and hermeneutic approaches in the study of human nature, and has acquired a basic knowledge of the history and the possible futures of the human life from an evolutionary (Darwin), historical (Dilthey), and philosophical-anthropological (Plessner) perspective.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/101887,2021,Human Conditions II,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. AW Prins'],,Inhoud
<div>In this second part of ‘Human Conditions’ we will focus on Phenomenological &amp
column2: Hermeneutical approaches. Our point of departure will be the fortuitousness of western philosophy and the unsolved, but ever tentalising question, how we may comprehend the phenomenon of human existence while simultaniously being 'subject' and 'object' of this attempt toward comprehension ourselves.

column1: Key figures in this course will be: Kierkegaard (on truth and individual existence), Husserl (on transcendental subjectivity as the ‘wonder of all wonders’), Heidegger (on the 'event' of being human and the framing of existence in the era of Technology), Sartre (the ontology of absolute freedom and radical responsibility), Merleau-Ponty (on the phenomenology of bodily perception), Gadamer (on philosophical hermeneutics) and Levinas (on questioning the primacy of ontology in phenomenology and western philosophy as a whole).
1. Understanding the historical predicaments of the ‘first-person perspective’ in Western Philosophy
2. Acquaintance with the main currents in the Phenomenological Movement and the ‘turn’ from Phenomenology to Hermeneutics
3. The ability to assess the importance, relevance and limitations of the philosophical positions presented and discussed during the course, and taking well-argued positions
4. Acknowledging the importance of, and being able to practice ‘stirring thinking’
5. The ability to thoroughly comprehend philosophical texts (academic skill training).

Human physiology studies how cells, tissues, organs and organ systems function in a healthy human body in response to internal and environmental changes. As a central concept in physiology, this course will highlight homeostatic processes, i.e. the maintenance of the steady state of the body within regulated ranges that are compatible with life. You will learn that homeostasis is regulated at multiple levels, from the cellular all the way to the organismal level. In this course, we will study the components and function of different physiological systems in the human body, including the cardiovascular system, circulatory system, respiratory system, musculoskeletal system, digestive system, urinary system, and the endocrine system. The human physiology will mainly be discussed under normal conditions, although pathologies and exceptional circumstances will be mentioned, such as high-altitude and space physiology. Importantly, this course aims to provide an integrated view of human physiology, acknowledging the complex interactions within and between different physiological systems.

The physiology of systems under scrutiny include the integumentary system, the nervous system, the circulatory system, the respiratory system, the musculoskeletal system, digestive system, renal system, and the endocrine system. The immune system will be studied in detail in Quad 4, 200-level course, 'Micro- and immunobiology', and is therefore not a focus within this course.
Learning objectives regarding the biological systems under study include:
• Be able to recognize different histological tissue samples from one another.
• Be able to describe the structure and identify characteristics of the organs’ tissues and relate them to their functioning.
• Understand how these vital parameters are regulated/ kept constant under normal and extraordinary circumstances (e.g., microgravity, high altitudes, cold temperatures).
• Be able to make and present a scientific poster in a clear and attractive way.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/102572,2021,Human Resource Management,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['DAP Peeters, MSc', 'dr. A Burmeister', 'dr. CISG Lee', 'dr. RL Hewett']",,"Inhoud

In many industries, the personnel – or the Human Resources – of an organization are one of the most vital factors shaping an organization’s success or failure. Decisions that involve the hiring, training, job assignments, or the separation of employees have far-reaching consequences. These consequences do not only involve financial gains or losses and have potential legal implications for the organization but also affect individuals and their motivation and ability to be productive and satisfied.

This course offers you an evidence-based perspective on the main challenges in Human Resource Management. We begin by examining the conceptual foundations of Human Resource Management, including the design of jobs and work processes, and the conditions under which work is satisfying and engaging. We then focus on the hiring process all the way from the human resource planning to sealing the deal with new hires and starting the socialization process. Building on this, a number of sessions deal with how one can achieve great results with the people within an organization by motivating and compensating their efforts, measuring their performance, as well as training and developing them for current and future tasks. Finally, we will consider how to manage employee’s voluntary and involuntary exit from organizations. By the end of the course, you will have a deep understanding of- and basic hands-on experience regarding the most important HR practices considering the empirical evidence that supports or discourages their use.
<div>After following this course, students will be able to:
• Describe and explain fundamental HRM practices and their theoretical underpinnings.
• Integrate theoretical knowledge and practical considerations to critically analyse and suggest solutions for HR-problems and cases.
• Reflect on the role of evidence in guiding the actions of HR managers.
In this course, we will cover the following topics:
• Importance and strategic role of HRM

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/102390,2021,Human Resource Management,Engels, Nederlands","Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. A Burmeister', 'dr. CISG Lee', 'dr. RL Hewett']",,"Inhoud

In many industries, the people – or the Human Resources – are the vital factors shaping success or failure for organizations. Decisions that involve the hiring, training, job assignments, and retention (or dismissal!) of employees have far-reaching consequences. These consequences do not only involve financial gains, losses, or potential legal implications for the organization, but also affect individuals and their motivation and ability to be productive and satisfied.

This course offers you an evidence-based perspective on the main challenges in Human Resource Management (HRM). We begin by examining the conceptual foundations of HRM, including the design of jobs and work processes, and the conditions under which work is satisfying and engaging. We then focus on the hiring process all the way from human resource planning to sealing the deal with new hires and starting the socialisation process. Building on this, we deal with how one can achieve great results with the people within an organization by motivating and rewarding their efforts, measuring their performance, as well as training and developing them for current and future tasks. Finally, we will consider how to manage employees’ voluntary and involuntary exit from organizations.

By the end of the course, you will have a deep understanding of and basic hands-on experience with the most important HR practices in light of empirical evidence that supports or discourages their use.
column2: You will have learned to look beyond short-term financial gains for the organization when making decisions that affect people in organizations, but also have a thorough understanding of evidence-based guidelines on employee well-being, job satisfaction, and fairness. As a result, you are able to use your knowledge and skills about HRM to be a force for positive change for peoples’ working lives.

column1: Given that HRM is a central organizational function, this course has links to many other courses in your curriculum. It particularly builds on your first-year course Organisational Behaviour, which laid the foundation for many of the concepts we will apply to workplace settings in this course and sets the stage for the third year specialism for People Experts.
After following this course, students will be able to:
• Explain fundamental HRM practices and their theoretical underpinnings.
• Design solutions for HR-problems and cases by integrating theoretical knowledge and practical considerations.
• Apply HR-related knowledge and skills to solve real-world organizational challenges in an international context.
• Develop an evidence-based mindset in reflecting on the role of evidence in guiding the actions of people managers.

Human Resource Management (HRM) gaat er vanuit dat de mens een belangrijke bron is voor organisatiesucces en heeft daarom als doel het personeelsmanagement zo goed mogelijk te laten verlopen. Hoewel dit geldt voor HRM in alle organisaties, kent HRM in publieke organisaties een aantal specifieke uitdagingen en toepassingen.

In deze module wordt daarom ingegaan op actuele thema’s binnen HRM in de publieke sector zoals wendbaarheid, inclusiviteit, mobiliteit en werkgeluk. Deze thema’s hebben gemeenschappelijk dat ze hoog op de agenda van wetenschappers en beleidsmakers staan. In de hoorcolleges wordt dan ook gebruik gemaakt van actuele voorbeelden en recente literatuur.

De literatuur voor dit vak bestaat uit wetenschappelijke artikelen die via Canvas te verkrijgen zijn. Er wordt van u verwacht dat u voorafgaand aan het hoorcollege de aangewezen artikelen leest. Het is daarnaast mogelijk om voorafgaand aan ieder hoorcollege een individuele opdracht in te leveren. Door deze individuele opdrachten met een voldoende af te ronden kunt u 20% van het eindcijfer behalen, en hoeft u minder vragen te beantwoorden op het take-home tentamen.

column3: Beschrijven welke overeenkomsten en verschillen er tussen HRM in publieke en private organisaties zijn
Toelichten welke actuele en toekomstige thema’s er op het gebied van HRM in de publieke sector spelen
Beredeneren welke invloed HRM in een publieke organisatie heeft
Uiteenzetten hoe HRM in de publieke sector kan worden toegepast.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/102156,2021,Human Resource and Organizational Behaviour Analytics,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,[],,Inhoud
Instructors: Dr. Marc van de Wardt, Prof. Svetlana Khapova.

Most organizations today collect a wealth of data that could help improve organizational outcomes. Still, only few succeed in using this data successfully. The phenomenon of Human Resource (HR) Analytics and the respective field(s) of research could potentially fill this void. HR Analytics gained traction in recent years as a movement that could let the HR profession evolve. Contrasting with the ""soft” approach that was long associated with the HR, HR Analytics seeks to add value to the organization by leveraging analytical processes, a broad range of statistical techniques, and novel data sources.

In this course, we learn how to use HR data and HR Analytics to improve business outcomes and make better HR decisions. The overarching question of the course is how can organizations use data to better understand organizational processes? Through a sequence of readings, lectures, and experiential exercises, we learn what questions to ask, how to determine which methods to use, we will discuss the strengths and weaknesses of different research designs, we will analyze several (applied) datasets during the lab sessions and we will discuss what organizations could learn from the results of these analyses. We will be studying the following six topics each covered by a specialist: recruitment &amp
column4: organizational outcomes, employability, gender and leadership and careers.

column1: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:

column2: Understand how organizations can use HR data to assess personality, diversity, employability, leadership, employee turnover and the effect of HR practices on organizational outcomes. Understand and critically discuss the strengths and weaknesses of different research designs

column1: • Application of knowledge: Apply different analytic techniques to address questions at the core of HR.
• Making judgement: Understand the implications of these analyses for organizational practices
• Communication: Engage in critical in-class discussions on academic research articles. Provide practical recommendations from HR Analytics to practitioners.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/101264,2021,Human Rights in International Law,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. M Stambulski', 'mr. D Stankovic', 'mr. MK Shahid', 'prof.mr.dr.drs. JD Temperman']",,"Inhoud

This course addresses the various legal instruments and monitoring/enforcement mechanisms for the international protection of human rights, placing emphasis on the United Nations and its various organs, as well as regional organizations (with a main focus on the Council of Europe and its European Convention on Human Rights). After a brief but intensive study of the key underlying doctrinal debates in human rights and its connection to international law, students will comprehensively examine the principal international human rights treaties, enforcement systems, and illustrative case law.

The different instruments and protection mechanisms are explored in relation to contemporary debates regarding the concept, scope, development and – obstacles to the actual – enforcement of human rights.

The course aims at enabling students to identify the relevant actors, instruments and monitoring/enforcement mechanisms for the international protection of human rights. Furthermore, students successfully completing this course will be able to analyse recent trends and developments in the context of that framework and critically assess different points of view in relation to the application and interpretation of human rights. Students will also train their analytical, writing and debating skills by participating in the compulsory Seminars.
Accordingly, students successfully completing this course will be able to:

column4: Independently analyse and assess, in the context of broader public international law, human rights treaty law
Independently analyse and assess, in the context of broader public international law, legal problem statements pertaining to the implementation or enforcement of international human rights law
Develop ways, in cooperation with others, of addressing human rights problem statements with profound societal ramifications

Independently present, in both oral (viz., in the form of moot court pleadings) and written (viz., in the form of written memorials) form, the results of academic research as well as legal advice, both to other lawyers and to a non-legally trained audience.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/102567,2021,Human resource management,Nederlands,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['DAP Peeters, MSc', 'dr. A Burmeister', 'dr. CISG Lee', 'dr. RL Hewett', 'L Iannelli']",,"Inhoud

In de meeste sectoren is het effectief managen van personeel – Human Resource Management (HR/HRM) – een bepalende factor voor het succes of het falen van de organisatie. Beslissingen over werving, training, taakstelling, beloning en ontslag hebben namelijk verstrekkende gevolgen. Ze hebben niet alleen betrekking op het economisch welvaren van de organisatie of het juridisch kader, maar vooral ook op mensen en hun motivatie, welzijn en productiviteit.

Dit vak biedt een evidence-based perspectief op de belangrijkste uitdagingen in Human Resource Management. We beginnen met het onderzoeken van de conceptuele basis van Human Resource Management, inclusief het ontwerp van banen en werkprocessen en de voorwaarden waaronder werk bevredigend en boeiend is. Vervolgens richten we ons op het wervingsproces, van de personeelsplanning tot het aannemen van nieuwe medewerkers en het starten van het socialisatieproces. Hierop voortbouwend hoe we prestaties meten, hoe bedrijven goede resultaten kunnen bereiken door hun personeel te motiveren en te betalen voor hun inspanningen en hoe de opleiding en de ontwikkeling voor huidige en toekomstige taken vorm kan krijgen. Ten slotte gaan we na hoe we het vrijwillig en onvrijwillig verlaten van organisaties door werknemers kunnen beheren.

Het is de bedoeling dat je aan het eind van dit vak theoretisch inzicht hebt verworven in de belangrijkste HRM-praktijken en ze tegelijk ook op hun praktijkwaarde kunt beoordelen. Onze aandacht gaat daarbij in het bijzonder uit naar hoe wetenschappelijke onderzoeksresultaten deze HR-praktijken ondersteunen dan wel ontkrachten.
<body>Na het succesvol afronden van dit vak zul je in staat zijn om:
• Fundamentele bedrijfsvoering van HRM en de theoretische grondslagen daarvan te beschrijven en begrijpen.
• Theoretische kennis en praktische bedrijfskundige overwegingen samen te brengen voor het analyseren en aanreiken van oplossingen voor HR-casuïstiek.
• Op de rol van wetenschappelijk bewijs als basis van HR-management te reflecteren.
In dit vak behandelen we de volgende onderwerpen:
• Belang en strategische rol van HRM

<div>The first two decades of the 21st century have witnessed a considerable reduction of poverty and associated phenomena in countries previously labeled as “under-developed” countries. The rapid and widespread innovations, mostly enabled and&nbsp
column6: Communication Technologies (ICTs), have given rise to “Emerging Markets”, also known as “Emerging Economies”. More and more developing countries are making remarkable inroads into economic growth and some have even become global leaders in specific areas. The introduction of the Internet, followed by the advent of mobile telephony, has been instrumental in driving innovation in vital sectors such as education, healthcare, economic livelihood, and local entrepreneurship, to mention a few areas. ICT and Innovation scholars project not only more ICT-driven innovations in emerging markets, but also the transfer from those innovations into developed countries (reverse innovation).

column1: This seminar offers students a critical, analytical, historical, and practical insight into the various ways in which Emerging Markets have been taking advantage of the development process to become central to the ICT-driven innovations. Students historically explores the transition from the previous approach, one that was mostly centred on international development policies, to the current home- grown, ICT-driven innovation approach to poverty alleviation. In this seminar, students get an insight into real-life ICT-driven innovations that involve various actors (e.g., local startups, NGOs, governments, multinationals) and in different areas and sectors. The seminar focuses on the following key areas: education (in the broader sense), healthcare, rural entrepreneurship (income- generating activities), economic livelihood, and banking (and related services). While exploring these areas, students are invited to go beyond the surface (the hype) to critically consider underlying concepts such as power, gender, sustainability, inclusiveness, and ethics.
Note: The course will be cancelled if there are less than 10 students. The maximum number of participants is 25. IBCoM students take priority over other students.
Students have gained knowledge and understanding of:
* The range and usage of ICTs in communication for social development and profit
* The history and politics of ICT use in emerging economies
* The workings of real time based ICTD projects in emerging economies and the range of challenges with the market, the state and the public intersecting
* Think strategically on real time public-private sector communicative approaches to contemporary issues involving ICT in education, politics, healthcare, and entrepreneurship
* Think critically on social and public policy
* Obtain information from/communicate with private sector professionals in the ICT4D (ICT for development) field in emerging markets

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/104524,2021,IPSERA Summer School: Theories for Purchasing and Supply Management Research,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof.dr. JYF Wynstra'],,"Inhoud

In this IPSERA Summer School, the emphasis is in educating participants on the (classical) management theories suited for studying research questions related to Purchasing and Supply Management. Since the 1960s, Purchasing and Supply Management (PSM) has developed from a predominantly administrative process into a strategic function of the firm. While one could argue that the academic literature has reflected developments in practice, or perhaps even has helped stimulate some of these developments, there is still debate how one could best define what exactly constitutes PSM research. It is our view, based on the developments PSM research has gone through the five decades since its emergence in the 1960s, that PSM research is most appropriately seen as a multi-disciplinary field. Acknowledging this diversity, and mapping the patterns of prevalence and influence over time, could help raise our understanding of the historical development of PSM research, and may provide helpful insights regarding future development opportunities.

Each of the six interactive lectures (sessions) will be hosted by a different faculty member. Faculty consists of international top scholars both from the PSM field itself, but also from contributing disciplines, primarily Strategy &amp
All participants are expected to be engaged in doctoral studies (fulltime or part-time), or to have just completed their PhD degree.
• Doctoral students are ideally in year 1 or 2 of their doctoral studies
• No specific training or prior expertise in data analysis is required, but the participant does need to have a basic understanding of empirical research methods.
Please submit the following documents to the course coordinator Prof. Finn Wynstra by the registration deadline 16 May 2022.

This IPSERA Summer School is sponsored by the International Purchasing and Supply Educations and Research Association (IPSERA) and the Dutch Purchasing Management Association (NEVI). Also, this sponsorship provides a number of bursaries, which cover the registration fee (€ 750) and travel cost (up to € 750). In a knowledge-based and innovation-driven business environment, managing ideas is an essential capability if an organization is to gain a sustainable competitive advantage. All innovations begin with ideas and managing these ideas is needed during the entire innovation process. Employees in any job and at any level of the organization can contribute to innovation with creative ideas. Thus idea management is important for everyone and at any moment.&nbsp

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100399,2021,Images & Power: Foundation of Media Studies,Engels,Erasmus University College,,['S Koevoets'],,Inhoud

Today’s culture is a visual culture. Since the 1970s, the social sciences and the humanities have increasingly turned their attention to the many ways in which visual technologies and images have come to play a central role in the construction of the shared meanings, or mental representations, through which our social practices are structured. Images reproduce power relations as much as they can contest dominant ways of seeing, and thinking about, the world. In this course we will analyse representations of class, gender, race and sexuality that circulate in the media by discussing and applying various key texts and methodologies from the fields of media studies and cultural analysis. Students read foundational texts by authors such as Roland Barthes, Stuart Hall, and Laura Mulvey and apply various visual methodologies in order to analyse a self-selected set of images in our weekly workshop.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100383,2021,Impact Evaluation,Engels,Erasmus University College,,['dr. F Vargas Lopes, MSc']",,"Inhoud

Does increasing legal retirement age maintain individuals longer at work? Does development aid raise economic growth? Do changes in schooling laws improve health? The answer to any of these questions requires valid methods to evaluate the impact of different interventions.

The objective of this course is to provide students with a set of theoretical and practical skills that will allow them to evaluate the causal impact of different policy interventions and social programs. The course will introduce students to a variety of econometric methods in impact evaluation and a set of reasoning skills to help them design an evaluation study and assess critically existing studies. Students will get hands‑on experience with applying the techniques in Stata.
At the end of the course students will be able to:
• Understand and apply a variety of impact evaluation methods
• Critically analyse impact evaluation research
• Draw policy implications from impact evaluation research

<li>Draw policy implications from impact evaluation research
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/99214,2021,Impact Evaluation,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['prof.dr. JLW van Kippersluis'],,Inhoud

Does a university degree raise your future wage? Does increasing the legal retirement age maintain individuals longer at work? Does restricting the bonuses of portfolio managers lead to less risk taking? Does development aid raise economic growth? Answering such questions requires a valid method of evaluating the effect of interventions.

In medicine one patient group is randomly assigned to a treatment while others receive a placebo. Identifying the effect of treatment is then relatively straightforward. In business, economics and social policy, such randomized experiments are often infeasible, unaffordable or considered unethical. Statistical methods must then be used to estimate the effect of an intervention relative to a counterfactual. This often calls for a great deal of creativity on the part of the analyst.

This course will give a non-technical overview of the intuition behind the most frequently applied evaluation methods in economics. The students will learn the required steps in a valid evaluation, the distinction between correlation and causal effects, the assumptions of different methods and in which situation each method can be used.

The main concepts are introduced in the first five weeks. The second part of the course is devoted to a group assignment, which will consist of a critical assessment of an existing evaluation, providing suggestions for improvement, and implementing these suggestions yourself. The students will hand-in a written report.
• Describe the difference between a correlation and a causal effect using the Potential Outcomes Framework.
• Critically assess an existing policy evaluation/academic paper that aims to estimate causal effects.
• Determine which Impact Evaluation method is best suited to study a research question.

• Estimate causal effects using statistical software for the most often applied Impact Evaluation techniques (multiple regression, matching, fixed effects, difference-in-difference, instrumental variables, regression discontinuity).
• Work in a team to successfully complete a group assignment.
<body>The required literature is different this year
column2: the course now uses ""Causal Inference: the Mixtape"" by Scott Cunningham. This book covers new developments in Impact Evaluation like the use of DAGs and Synthetic Control methods better than the previous book (Handbook on Impact Evaluation).</body>

<span style=""font-size:9pt"">New products, services and business models are generally implemented through projects. In this course students will have a “hands-on” experience in which they will plan and execute one of such projects. The goal of the course project is to transform an innovative idea into a tangible product. During the class sessions and through the course activities, students will be able to discuss concepts and theories that will allow reflecting on their work and help them improve their team’s project.&nbsp

The course is divided in four different modules. The first module focuses on providing students with the basic tools for setting up and starting the execution of the project. The second module focuses on the management of the parties involved in a project, the project
column3: and other stakeholders. The third module focuses on the&nbsp
column4: discussion of risk management and project governance as mechanisms of project control. Lastly, in the fourth module, the course discussion assumes a critical perspective on project management practices and explores why projects fail and how to overcome those failures.&nbsp

This EUR minor offered by EUC will teach students about the complexities of our communities and will help them understand that not everyone is presented with the same chances in life. The minor is designed to introduce students to and have hands on experience with a community that might be new to them. You will be trained in interpersonal relationships and put this into practice by being a mentor for high school students (i.e., the mentees) from Rotterdam-South during the minor period (and maybe thereafter). Four important elements are part of this minor: 1) theory on inclusive and emergent leadership, service learning, biases, and exclusive decisions, 2) training on mentoring, 3) interaction with the mentees based on mutual respect, and 4) reflection. So, this minor is for students who want to put knowledge into practice.
The student should be flexible in their availability and be able to understand at least basic Dutch.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100818,2021,Indirect Tax Assurance and Technology,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. ML Schippers, LL.M', 'J Gruson', 'prof.dr. P Kavelaars', 'prof.mr.dr. MMWD Merkx', 'prof.mr.dr. W de Wit']",,"Inhoud

Bij Indirect Tax Assurance and Technology gaat het om het herkennen, begeleiden en beheersen van fiscale processen en risico’s als onderdeel van de totale bedrijfsvoering en bedrijfsstrategie en om de inzet van nieuwe technologieën daarbij. Van een incident-gedreven en fiscaaltechnische aanpak naar een (nog) meer procesmatige en risicogerichte benadering om te bereiken dat de organisatie (zoveel mogelijk) in control is met betrekking tot de fiscale positie en inzicht heeft in alle mogelijke fiscale risico's betreffende de bedrijfsvoering. Doordat indirecte belastingen transactiegerelateerd zijn, zijn de fiscale risico's dienaangaande ook bij iedere afzonderlijke transactie aanwezig. Ook dient kort na de transacties aan de fiscale verplichtingen te zijn voldaan waardoor weinig tijd voor reflectie en herbeoordeling bestaat. Dat betekent dat grote behoefte bestaat aan een accuraat fiscaal controlesysteem en het belang van een tax control framework toeneemt. Het fiscale beleid van de onderneming speelt een belangrijke rol in dit vak. Bezien vanuit de belasting- en douaneautoriteiten, is het van belang om kennis te nemen van dit beleid en de implementatie daarvan. Concepten als ‘AEO’ (Authorised Economic Operator) in het douanerecht en ‘CTP’ (Certified Taxable Person) in de BTW nemen dan ook in belang toe. Niet alleen fungeren zij als een kwaliteitskeurmerk richting de belasting- en douaneautoriteiten, maar voor de betrokken bedrijven verlenen zij ook toegang tot vereenvoudigingen in diverse regelingen.
Dit vak brengt de studenten op de hoogte van de ontwikkelingen op bovenomschreven gebied.
<body>Na het volgen van dit vak is de student:
<li>op de hoogte van de ontwikkelingen en laatste stand van zaken omtrent tax assurance &amp
• in staat om fiscale processen omtrent indirecte belastingen en de fiscale risico’s die daarmee gepaard gaan, in kaart te brengen:

• bekend met de systematiek van de digitale technologie die kan worden gebruikt bij de fiscale risicoselectie en risicobeheersing ten aanzien van indirecte belastingen en in staat in praktijkgerichte cases te beoordelen welke technologie ingezet kan worden:

• op de hoogte van ethische leerstukken en hoe die in de fiscaliteit toepassing kunnen vinden en hoe deze de fiscale werksfeer kunnen beïnvloeden. Tevens is de student in staat om daarin zelfstandig een positie te bepalen.
• Het eindcijfer bestaat uit het gewogen gemiddelde van het cijfer voor het door de student geschreven essay (40%) en het cijfer voor het schriftelijk (her)tentamen (60%).
• Het college wordt verzorgd door de gezamenlijke capgroepen fiscale economie en fiscaal recht. De coördinatie ligt bij fiscale economie.

B Jacobs', 'prof.dr. P Kavelaars', 'prof.dr. S Cnossen', 'prof.mr.dr. MMWD Merkx', 'prof.mr.dr. W de Wit']",,"Inhoud

Het vak bouwt voort op de theorieën die zijn behandeld in het derdejaarsvak Economics of Taxation uit de Bachelor Fiscale Economie en het tweedejaarsvak Openbare Financiën uit de Bachelor Fiscaal Recht.

Na een algemene inleiding over de inzichten vanuit de welvaartseconomie en de gedragseconomie ten aanzien van de effecten van belastingheffing (verstorende invloed/deadweight loss, tax incidence, internaliteiten en externaliteiten) in de eerste week dat als een rode draad geldt voor specifieke onderwerpen in het vervolg van het blok, wordt in de daaropvolgende weken telkens een actueel onderwerp met betrekking tot indirecte belastingen behandeld. Het vak beoogt daarmee ook een economische kader te bieden bij de bestudering van vakken die zich richten op specifieke onderdelen het indirecte belastingrecht.

In week 1 wordt een algemeen kader gegeven van economische inzichten op het gebied van belastingheffing in het algemeen en indirecte belastingen in het bijzonder. Vanaf week 2 van het blok wordt een specifiek onderwerp op het gebied van indirecte belastingen ingeleid door een gastdocent.

column8: Belastingen op vastgoed door Bas Jacobs

column1: Elk groepje studenten schrijft een beleidspaper over een onderwerp naar keuze, onder de restrictie dat dit onderwerp geen betrekking mag hebben op het toegewezen te organiseren werkcollege.
Aan het eind van week 6 worden telkens gedurende 15min de beleidspapers ‘gepitched’ waarna een korte discussie volgt.
Voor de hoorcolleges en het pitchcollege geldt een verplichte aanwezigheid.
Het eindcijfer wordt voor 40% bepaald door de kwaliteit van het beleidspaper en de pitch en voor 60% door het tentamenresultaat.</body>

Het vak brengt de student op de hoogte van de (recente) ontwikkelingen in het economisch denken over verschillende kenmerken van het (Nederlandse) belastingstelsel in het algemeen en indirecte belastingen in het bijzonder en ontwikkelingen in het fiscaal beleid op het gebied van indirecte belastingen.

Bovendien daagt het vak studenten uit het belastingstelsel op het gebied van indirecte belastingen te evalueren en eigen ideeën, gebaseerd op economische theorie, te ontwikkelen over hoe het belastingstelsel op het gebied van indirecte belastingen optimaal kan worden georganiseerd.&nbsp
Na het volgen van het vak:
<li>Zijn studenten geïnformeerd over de actuele beleidsdiscussies over indirecte belastingen
<li>Kunnen studenten het (Nederlandse) belastingsysteem op het gebied van indirecte belastingen op basis van argumenten uit de economische literatuur evalueren
• Kunnen studenten actief deelnemen aan beleidsdiscussies door het combineren van hun kennis van het fiscale recht en de economische theorie.

<body>This course focuses on the processes of individualisation and globalisation, which have transformed western societies virtually beyond recognition since the second half of the 20<sup>th</sup> century. As this is a course in sociology, a key question is what the sociological study of these processes entails. What do sociologists mean by individualisation and globalisation? How do they measure such wide-ranging processes? And what do they focus on in theories and research dealing with individualisation and globalisation? A second key issue entails assessing the consequences of individualisation and globalisation. Combining sociological theories and empirical research findings, students will learn to critically examine the impact of globalisation and individualisation on various domains of social life, such as communities, politics and consumption. During the interactive sessions students will focus on applying their knowledge to real life cases. The course is assessed through a final exam and an essay.</body>
<body>After successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
<li>Explain how sociologists conceptualise and measure individualisation and globalisation
<li>Explain theories about the impact of individualisation and globalisation on various domains of social life, such as communities, politics, and consumption
<li>Explain the similarities and differences between various sociological theories on individualisation and globalisation
<li>Apply sociological theories on individualisation and globalisation to contemporary social phenomena
• Critically reflect on sociological theories on individualisation and globalisation.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/101848,2021,Industrial Epidemics,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. YH Hendlin'],,Inhoud
This course is part of cluster 2. Environment, Life and Technology

There is no entity in our current society more powerful than the corporations. Of the 100 largest economies in the world, 51 are corporations and 49 are states. Therefore, it is impossible to confront the existential climate crisis without addressing the question of corporate power. This seminar will prepare students to understand the mechanisms of corporate power, and the corporate capture of science, policy, and regulation. Taking a public health approach to understanding corporate power, this course will investigate the oroborous of denial, cognitive biases, ideology, profit-incentive, and other mechanisms which incentivize social undermining of our biosphere and health. From climate change, species extinction, air pollution, and other “externalities” of the industrial model in a policy ecosystem inadequately incentivizing good corporate citizenship, we will examine the history of the corporation and the weakening of our epistemological commons. Examining a portfolio of explanations for the current deadlock of corporate global control, in a world where the major tech companies beg countries to regulate them so that they can avoid an almost fatalistic race to the bottom, this course provides a rigorous examination of the factors leading to the health epidemics industries transmit.
Students must attend all seminars except in emergencies communicated before the missed course session in question. Students missing more than 2 seminar sessions are dropped from the class.
Completion of this course will prepare students to:
- gain a historical understanding of the development of the corporation
- distinguish between public-interest businesses and involuted industries
- dissect philosophically the costs and benefits of current modes of production
- adopt sophisticated systems-theory views on the relationships between different types of actors in the public sphere
- understand the health and environmental externalities of current modes of industrial practices
- learn how to analyze arguments from and towards corporations
- identify the health and environmental externalities of corporate behavior and the systemic pressures for malfeasance
- apply philosophy of science concepts to the production of science, social license, and the relationships between science, markets, and law.
Based on the readings and discussions, students will post weekly commentaries on the Canvas wiki group for the course
column2: compose, receive peer-feedback, and publicly post a blog on a linked philosophical issue of their choice based on the course

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/99070,2021,Industrial Organisation,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. D Sisak'],,Inhoud

This course provides an overview of modern industrial organization that blends theory with real-world applications. It acquaints the students with the most important models for understanding strategies chosen by firms with market power and shows how such firms adapt to different market environments. These insights are then applied to study market outcomes and competition policy. Formal theory is complemented throughout by real-world cases that show how it applies to actual organizational settings.
The main analytical tools used are microeconomic theory and game theory.
The main objectives of this course are
• to get comfortable with the use of game theoretical models to analyze firms' strategies and market outcomes
• to connect these theoretical insights with observations and problems from real-world cases
Students should hold a firm background in undergraduate level microeconomics and game theory. An introductory course in industrial organization is helpful but not required.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/98921,2021,Influencing People: psychology and practice,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. B Van den Bergh', 'dr. G Paolacci']",,"Inhoud

Which posts on social media stick to your mind? What commercial makes you buy a product? How can you finish your project on time? How can you sell your bike at the best price? Marketing, economics, and psychology provide answers to these and other questions. This course will give you actionable insights into the psychology of human behavior — improving your ability to “nudge” other people and to resist psychological biases that cloud your judgments. The course is composed of three segments:

The Psychology of Human Decisions. People’s behavior systematically differs from what may be expected of them. You’ll learn the surprising ways in which people behave and misbehave, and how to use this knowledge to make and promote better decisions.

Stick and Switch. For any given idea, there are 100 different ways to communicate it. Drawing from cognition and motivation theories, you’ll learn how to create messages that succeed in persuading people and changing their behavior.

Negotiation. Often times, achieving the best outcome requires implicitly and explicitly negotiating with another party with interests that are not aligned to yours. You will learn the techniques to negotiate a better outcome.

Each segment comprises a different number of modules. Each module explores one theme and comprises a different set of activities (e.g., attending prerecorded videos, reading academic papers, participating in interactive live sessions on Zoom). Modules entail different amounts of work (e.g., more or less readings) and require different amounts of time (e.g., few days or more than a week) to be completed. Think of modules as conceptual units.

Additionally, there will be a group assignment running throughout the course, in which you will put academic theories into practice. You will design and present an influencing campaign aimed at influencing a specific behavior.
Depending on how the pandemic/regulations evolve, some activities (e.g., group discussions) may take place offline.</body>
<body>After following this course, the student is able to:
• Interpreting and explaining behavioral phenomena using theories from psychology, economics, and marketing
• Implementing behavioral insights to persuade, resist persuasion, and negotiate effectively
• Present your ideas to make them interesting and memorable
• Planning and designing a theoretically-grounded campaign to affect people’s behavior

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/104140,2021,Informatiemanagement,Nederlands,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. EAM van de Kar', 'dr. J Karanovic', 'dr. T Brandt']",,"Inhoud

De afgelopen decennia hebben vorderingen op het gebied van informatietechnologie (IT) essentiële aspecten van onze maatschappij, onze economie en ons persoonlijke leven fundamenteel veranderd. Internet en digitale technologieën in het algemeen hebben onze persoonlijke en beroepsmatige bezigheden ingrijpend beïnvloed en vormen een uitdaging voor onze perceptie van fysieke en maatschappelijke grenzen, van afstand en snelheid en van hoe we willen leven, werken, leren, communiceren, concurreren, samenwerken en onze sociale contacten willen onderhouden. Men is er nog niet uit of digitale technologieën ons isoleren of juist dichter bij elkaar brengen, of ze kansarmen een stem geven of hen helpen onderdrukken, of ze welvaart opleveren voor velen of voor slechts een kleine minderheid. Bedrijven spelen een cruciale rol bij het beantwoorden van deze vragen aangezien zij zowel fundamenteel door de digitale ontwikkelingen worden beïnvloed alsook de voornaamste drijvende kracht erachter zijn. Traditionele sectoren moeten vaak worstelen om zich aan te passen aan dit veranderende klimaat, nu hun bedrijfsmodellen worden ontregeld door nieuwe, wendbare concurrenten. Bewijs hiervoor kan worden gevonden in de talrijke startups die een transformatie teweegbrengen in diverse sectoren, zoals energie, mobiliteit, zorg en de

financiële sector. Tegelijkertijd is het afgelopen decennium een aantal nieuwe op een platform gebaseerde megabedrijven ontstaan, waaronder Google, Apple, Uber, Airbnb en Amazon, dat het publieke discours rond digitalisering beheerst en nieuwe vragen opwerpt over macht en regulering in een digitale wereld.

Het vak Informatiemanagement laat studenten kennismaken met de rol die informatietechnologie speelt in de economie en de maatschappij van vandaag. Enerzijds biedt het vak een gevarieerd perspectief op centrale discussies over digitalisering, zoals de macht van digitale platforms en de stimulans die digitale technologieën bieden voor de uitwisseling van kennis en ideeën, maar ook de mogelijke dreiging als gevolg van het ontbreken van regulering. Anderzijds brengt het vak studenten begrip bij van digitale technologieën alsook van de basisvaardigheden op het gebied van algoritmisch denken, databasemanagement en modellering die heden ten dage onontbeerlijk zijn om op de werkplek en in academische programma's te kunnen gedijen. Het vak wordt aangeboden door de Business Information Management sectie van het vakgroep Technology &
• Discussiëren over de evolutie van digitale technologieën en de huidige technologische trends.
• De invloed van gevestigde en opkomende digitale technologieën op bedrijven, de maatschappij en ons persoonlijke leven evalueren.
• BPMN-technieken toepassen om een bedrijfsprocesmodel voor een gegeven bedrijfsproces af te leiden.
• Met behulp van Entity-Relationship-Modelling op systematische wijze een databasemodel organiseren.
• SQL-queries formuleren om databases te manipuleren om tot een gegeven uitkomst te komen.
• In R basisalgoritmen ontwikkelen om een gegeven doel te bereiken.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100620,2021,Information Strategy,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['prof.dr. T Li', 'TAT Thuis, MSc']",,"Inhoud

Information technology (IT) is revolutionizing the way people and firms transact business. This process is only being accelerated with the development of social media and the availability of big data, which has enormous impact on our activities and the way organizations work and compete. This rapid movement towards the new information economy is being led by both established firms such as Wal-Mart, General Electric, and new entrepreneurial firms such as Google, Amazon, Facebook, YouTube, and Dropbox. As a master student of business information management, you need a thorough understanding of the latest technology trends, how firms embrace disruptive technologies, and what new business models emerge that allows firms to compete and lead in the information economy. This course will devote to the study of the strategic use of information, and provide you with the understanding of the role of information, the closely related role of information technology, major developments of e-commerce, and their implications on economics, marketing, and operational issues. This course will focus on problems unique to information-intensive businesses that you will soon encounter as a consultant, analyst, technologist, or entrepreneur.

The course is a combination of lectures and a high degree of case analysis and discussions. In the class, you will work with real world examples ranging across different industries. The course will cover six themes: information strategy, business model and digital transformation, business-to-consumer e-commerce, electronic markets and auctions, information goods, and platform mediated networks.
The objective of the course is to help you to:

Develop an ability to discuss how the presence of IT enables new business models and how digital transformation changes industry structure, and alter marketing, sales, operations, and business practices.
Learn the contemporary issues in e-commerce, the changes in consumer behavior, and the opportunities for different forms of electronic markets and auctions.
Describe pricing and versioning of digital goods and recognize the importance of platform mediated networks.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/102452,2021,Infrastructure and Green Cities,Engels,Institute for Housing and Urban Development Studies (IHS),,['arquitecto(a) JM Skinner, MD MSc', 'dr. CB Pennink', 'dr. Q Ke', 'dr. S Pagliarin', 'JM Waardenburg', 'prof.dr. LM Gerrits', 'S Sharma']",,"Inhoud

If developed and maintained properly, infrastructure becomes a conduit for a greener city. The modules within the specialization therefore focus on the ways in which one can arrive at the green city. The specialization is structured in four principal modules that run in parallel. Modules 1 and 2 focus on applied knowledge and practical examples
column2: modules 3 and 4 focus on the theoretical backgrounds of managing and developing infrastructures. Because the modules run in parallel, students engage in a direct dialogue between theory and practice.

column1: This module introduces the students to the various types of infrastructure and discusses how these can be planned, build and maintained. The types of infrastructure central to this module are (1) public transportation, including integration of modalities
column2: (2) integrated solid waste management and circular economy
column4: (4) digital infrastructure, including smart city technology
column5: (5) energy generation, transportation and delivery. The module shows how such infrastructures may be planned, financed and governed. Attention will be paid to the role of public-private partnerships, forms of contracting, stakeholder involvement and various governance arrangements.

column1: Evaluation of infrastructure projects is a very important aspect of the entire life cycle of said infrastructures. It tells planners, policy-makers and others what was achieved and how it was achieved. Evaluation is complex, especially when it comes to mega-projects that take decades to be developed and build. There are many evaluation methods, each with its own specific goals and operations. This module provides the students with the various ways in which infrastructures may be evaluated. Particular attention will be paid to impact assessments, qualitative comparative analysis and learning evaluations.

The core argument in this specialization is that infrastructures can contribute to a greener city. This requires a holistic approach that acknowledges the interdependencies between infrastructure as technology and society, including aspects of social wellbeing, climate change and environmental health conditions. How does the development of technology intertwine with social development? This module opens the black box of socio-technological evolution and focuses on the ways in which we can analyse and understand that reciprocal relationship. Theories of socio-technological evolution will be discussed and assessed, including transition theories and behavioural theories.

The goal of this module is to highlight under what conditions infrastructure projects may be promoted or come to a standstill. The students will be made familiar with theories of policy change and stability, including in the agenda-setting stage and the decision-making stage. This will aid them in understanding and anticipating the sometimes-unstructured decision-making situations and arenas that infrastructure projects often find themselves in. Understanding how these arenas work is pivotal in becoming more efficient in getting good infrastructure programs up and running.

The specialization organizes field trips to observe infrastructure development and maintenance in practice. Planned are visits to the local public transportation operator RET, to the Maasland Storm Surge Barrier, and to the green roof (Delfshaven dakpark) and water square (Hofplein). Site visits may be subject to change, depending on the circumstances (e.g., COVID-related restrictions)
<body>At the end of this specialisation, students are able to:
• Describe the core elements of different types of infrastructure development and of infrastructure maintenance
• Analyse different types of infrastructure development and maintenance in terms of theories of change and stability
• Apply tools of planning and evaluation to improve the development and maintenance of infrastructures.
• Propose finance models and governance arrangements to improve the development and maintenance of infrastructures
• Reflect upon the reciprocal relationship between infrastructure and society, including aspects of social wellbeing and environmental concerns.
• To propose possible solutions for such issues in terms of governance
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/98394,2021,Infrastructures of Power,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. JL Bier'],,Inhoud

This course sensitizes you to the social and material groundedness of public issues in intersectional systems of power related to gender, class, ancestry and (post)colonialism, economic class, technology. It familiarizes you with cutting edge work in social theory, as told through cases that reveal the varied power of the socio-technical infrastructures that provide the context for public contestation (by authors such as Haraway, Hall, Roy, Star, Bowker, Edwards, Kitchin, Starosielski, and Mattern). Infrastructure here includes both the material settings of—to give two possible examples—water or internet infrastructure, and the social organization and work practices that go into the making of publics and issues, such as standards for ‘clean’ water or debates over corporate control of internet bandwith.

You will learn a selection of major approaches in contemporary social theory, and willl yourself form strategies for thinking with/against these approaches and applying them to relevant public issues. The aim is to come up with new ways to address the varied infrastructures of power that infuse struggles over contemporary issuess in particular places and times. The course also highlights the ways that the legacies of past power imbalances continue to shape current debates, and how the uneven form and contexts of social issues, such as legacies of sexism and colonialism, can change through an awareness of the lives and theorizing of actors who were traditionally omitted from public debates. It puts socio-material power imbalances at the core of social theory, and uses these to better address which publics and issues become visible and how more heterogeneous solutions can become viable.

One way to think about infrastructures is as the concrete manifestation of power across time and space. So the role of space and the uneven effects of power in infrastructures are also central to this course. It also pays attention to the significance of relatively recent technological infrastructures, in particular to ‘digital infrastructures’ and to the ways these transform, and are transformed by, public debates. For example, you may learn to empirically study how online algorithms sort out what can become visible and what counts as public knowledge, and the ways that technology can alternately alleviate or deepen social injustice.
After successful completion of this course, students will:
1. be familiar with the social scientific theories and analyses of infrastructures
2. be able to sociologically analyze public interventions in terms of their dependency on infrastructures
3. be able to sociologically analyze the relevant infrastructures for major current public issues
4. be familiar with social scientific analyses of space and power
5. be able to empirically apply perspectives on space and power to current public issues
6. be able to empirically study the role of technological infrastructures in public issues</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/101062,2021,Inkomstenbelasting,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['AHE Bruin, LL.M', 'mr. A Schoneveld', 'mr.dr. EW Ros']",,"Inhoud
In het vak Inkomstenbelasting raakt de student vertrouwd met de Wet inkomstenbelasting 2001 en de Wet op de loonbelasting 1964.

Op grond van de Wet inkomstenbelasting 2001 wordt een belasting naar het inkomen geheven van natuurlijke personen. De wet onderscheidt verschillende bronnen van inkomen die ondergebracht zijn in 3 ‘boxen’. De eerste box, die voor de inkomsten uit werk en woning, is daarbij weer onderverdeeld in een groot aantal nadere bronnen van inkomen, zoals winst uit onderneming, loon, periodieke uitkeringen en inkomsten uit eigen woning. De Wet inkomstenbelasting 2001 wordt integraal behandeld, zij het dat dit voor een aantal onderwerpen minder diepgaand of zelfs summier gebeurt, omdat die in een latere fase van de studie aan de orde worden gesteld. Een voor de schatkist zeer belangrijke bron van inkomen binnen box 1 is die van het loon. Mede vanwege dat belang wordt op dat loon in de meeste gevallen reeds bij de betaling van dat loon een belasting geheven (een bronbelasting) onder het motto: wat je niet in handen krijgt, kun je ook niet uitgeven. Die belastingheffing berust op de Wet op de loonbelasting 1964. Deze wet wordt op hoofdlijnen behandeld.</body>

<li>kent u de verhouding tussen die beide belastingen
<li>heeft u inzicht in de verhouding van beide belastingen tot andere belastingen en tot andere rechtsgebieden
<li>bent u op hoofdlijnen bekend met Europese regelgeving en jurisprudentie die van invloed is op de Nederlandse inkomstenbelasting
<li>kent en begrijpt u de belangrijkste jurisprudentie op het gebied van de inkomsten- en loonbelasting, kunt u deze analyseren en op basaal niveau kritisch beoordelen

De Wet inkomstenbelasting 2001 heeft het oogmerk om over het inkomen naar draagkracht belasting te heffen. Dit geschiedt door middel van een inkomensbegrip dat is gebaseerd op het zogenoemde boxenstelsel. Aan de heffing zijn alle inwoners van Nederland onderworpen, alsmede niet-inwoners die inkomen genieten uit Nederland. In het onderhavige vak wordt met name aandacht besteed aan de structuur van de inkomstenbelasting, de wijze waarop met name arbeidsinkomsten in de heffing worden betrokken, alsmede de heffing over arbeidsinkomsten voor de toepassing van de loonbelasting en de premieheffing sociale verzekeringen. Daarnaast komt een aantal algemene regelingen van de inkomstenbelasting aan de orde. De volgende onderwerpen worden besproken.
• Inkomen uit arbeid die in dienstbetrekking is verricht
• Het loonbegrip in de loonbelasting en inkomstenbelasting
• Inzicht te verwerven in de structuur en opzet van de loon- en inkomstenbelasting, in het bijzonder van de belastingheffing over inkomen uit arbeid die is verricht in dienstbetrekking.
• De vaardigheid te ontwikkelen de juiste rechtsbronnen aan te boren om te komen tot een verantwoorde wetstoepassing in concrete situaties.

• Het kritisch vermogen te ontwikkelen om op zelfstandige wijze te kunnen toetsen of de rechtsontwikkeling op het gebied van de loon- en inkomstenbelasting in overeenstemming is met de aan deze heffing ten grondslag liggende beginselen en haar economische betekenis te kunnen overzien.
<body>Het cijfer van de paper is ook geldig bij het hertentamen.</body>

De Wet inkomstenbelasting 2001 heeft het oogmerk om over het inkomen naar draagkracht belasting te heffen. Dit geschiedt door middel van een inkomensbegrip dat is gebaseerd op het zogenoemde boxenstelsel. Aan de heffing zijn alle inwoners van Nederland onderworpen, alsmede niet-inwoners die inkomen genieten uit Nederland. In dit vak worden behandeld de winst uit onderneming en uit zelfstandige arbeid en het inkomen uit aanmerkelijk belang, zowel voor de binnenlandse belastingplichtigen als voor de buitenlandse belastingplichtigen. De volgende onderwerpen komen aan bod:
• Wat is een onderneming en welke belastingplichtigen genieten winst uit onderneming
• Objectieve vrijstellingen en andere inbreuken op de totaalwinst
• Gevolgen van de overdracht van een onderneming en mogelijkheden tot geruisloze dooschuiving
• Wanneer is er sprake van een aanmerkelijk belang en wie genieten inkomen uit aanmerkelijk belang
• De inbreng in en de terugkeer uit de BV
• Overdrachtsficties en doorschuivingsfaciliteiten bij schenking, overlijden en echtscheiding van ondernemers en aanmerkelijkbelanghouders
• Terbeschikkingstelling van vermogen aan verbonden ondernemers en lichamen

• Niet behandeld worden de inkomsten die worden verkregen uit arbeid die in dienstbetrekking is verricht, het inkomen dat wordt verkregen als resultaat uit overige werkzaamheden, uit eigen woning, uit inkomensvoorzieningen en uit sparen en beleggen. Deze problematiek wordt behandeld in het vak FEB42001-Inkomstenbelasting A.

Inzicht verwerven in de wijze waarop natuurlijke personen die een onderneming drijven, hun fiscale winst moeten bepalen en worden belast voor hun winst uit die onderneming in de inkomstenbelasting en de verworven inzichten kunnen toepassen op realistische praktijksituaties.

Inzicht verwerven in de wijze waarop natuurlijke personen mer een aanmerkelijk belang worden belast in de inkomstenbelasting en de verworven inzichten kunnen toepassen op realistische praktijksituaties.

De doelstellingen, methodes en toepassingen van de logica worden besproken en geïllustreerd. De nadruk ligt op propositielogica
Aanwezigheid bij werkcolleges verplicht voor voltijdstudenten.

Studenten mogen één werkcollege missen. Indien ze meerdere werkcolleges missen, moeten er ter compensatie opgaven gemaakt worden die bij het (de) gemiste werkcollege(s) horen en welke beoordeeld worden. Het tentamenonderdeel dat overeenkomt met de gemiste werkcolleges zal beoordeeld worden met het laagste cijfer behaald voor (i) de compenserende opgaven (ii) de tentamenopgaven behorende bij de gemiste werkcolleges.</body>
1. De student is vertrouwd met de notie van een deductief argument
column2: en hiermee samenhangende noties zoals propositie, geldigheid en correctheid, en is in staat om deductieve argumenten van andersoortige argumenten

column1: 2. De student is vertrouwd met de formele taal van de propositie logica (welke de logische voegtekens voor “en”, “of”, “niet” “als dan” bevat), bekend met de (beperkte) uitdrukkingskracht van deze formele taal en in staat om alledaagse deductieve argumenten te vertalen naar de taal van de propositielogica.

3. De student is vertrouwd met de methode van waarheidstafels en hij/zij kan deze methode inzetten om argumenten op hun (on)geldigheid te beoordelen en formules op hun geldigheid / contingentie / consistentie.

4. De student is vertrouwd met de notie van een structurele eigenschap van de geldig gevolg relatie en is in staat om te bewijzen / weerleggen dat deze geldig gevolg relatie zekere structurele eigenschappen wel /niet heeft.
5. De student is vertrouwd met de notie&nbsp
column3: van een afleidingssysteem en de gerelateerde eigenschappen van betrouwbaarheid en volledigheid. De student is op de hoogte van het bestaan van diverse afleidingssystemen voor de propositie logica en kan de belangrijkste verschillen tussen deze systemen benoemen.

column1: 6. De student is in staat om het tableau (afleidings-) systeem te gebruiken om na te gaan of een argument (on)geldig is en, indien een argument ongeldig is, een tegenvoorbeeld te construeren.

7. De student is bekend met Quine’s drieledige onderscheid tussen veridical paradoxen, falsidical paradoxen en antinomieën. De student kent enkele centrale antinomieën en kan uitleggen hoe deze een niet-klassieke logica kunnen motiveren.
8. De student kent de basisbeginselen van, en motivatie voor, enkele niet- klassieke, met name meerwaardige, logica’s.
9. De student kent de basisbeginselen van de syllogismenleer en kan de (on)geldigheid van syllogismen beoordelen aan de hand van Venn diagrammen

<body>Inleiding Criminologie vormt voor studenten een inleiding in de Criminologie, een multidisciplinaire empirische objectwetenschap die zich richt op de vraag wat criminaliteit is, wie de daders en slachtoffers van criminaliteit zijn en welke verschillende (formele en informele) manieren de samenleving omgaat en reageert op criminaliteit. Het vak Inleiding Criminologie biedt studenten aan de hand van diverse (recente) (inter)nationale en criminologische onderzoeken een eerste kennismaking met de verschillende aandachtsvelden en thema’s van de criminologie: de criminografie, de etiologie, de victimologie, de penologie en het criminaliteits- en veiligheidsbeleid. Tijdens het practicum schrijven de studenten een inleiding op een wetenschappelijk artikel op basis van zelfstandig geselecteerde wetenschappelijke en beleidsmatige bronnen.</body>
Na afloop van dit vak is de student in staat om:
<li>een overzicht te geven van de aandachtsvelden en centrale thema’s van de criminologie
<li>het multidisciplinaire karakter van de criminologie te beschrijven en te illustreren
<li>het empirische karakter van de criminologie te beschrijven en te illustreren
<li>enkele recente ontwikkelingen te beschrijven op het gebied van criminaliteit, criminaliteitsbestrijding en criminologisch onderzoek
<li>de opgedane kennis mondeling en schriftelijk te reproduceren en verbinden met concrete casussen
<li>wetenschappelijke, beleidsmatige en maatschappelijke bronnen te selecteren en te beoordelen op bruikbaarheid en (wetenschappelijke) relevantie
• informatie te halen uit wetenschappelijke, beleidsmatige en maatschappelijke bronnen over de omvang van criminaliteit.

• Basaal begrip van het oplossen van eenvoudige algoritmische problemen
• Het identificeren van het belang van ICT in het bedrijfsleven.
• Het onderscheid maken tussen spreadsheets en databases.
• Het modelleren van een praktisch economisch of bedrijfseconomisch probleem in een spreadsheet.
• Het ontwikkelen van een spreadsheet model voor optimalisatie en simulatie.
• Het toepassen en opvragen van een kleine database.
Het vak wordt dit jaar geheel online gegeven in verband met de Coronacrisis. De inhoud en structuur zullen (grotendeels) overeenkomen met afgelopen jaar.
Voor 2021 heette dit vak ICT. De inhoud van het vak is niet veranderd.
Er zijn twee toetsen in het vak die afzonderlijke modules toetsen.
De eerste toets telt voor 40% en gaat over de modules IT Basics en Computational Thinking.
De tweede toets telt voor 60% en gaat over de modules Spreadsheets and Databases.
Er is een enkele herkansing die voor 100% telt. Deelname aan deze herkansing betekent dat de cijfers voor beide toetsen worden vervangen door het resultaat van uw herkansing.
De herkansing gaat over alle vier de modules en bevat dus vragen die normaal gesproken op beide toetsen gesteld kunnen worden.

Het relatieve gewicht van de onderwerpen binnen de herkansing zullen ongeveer vergelijkbaar zijn met het gewicht van de originele toetsen, dus ongeveer 40% IT basics en Computational Thinking, en ongeveer 60% Spreadsheets en Databases.</body>
